29 March. An unidentified armed group sets fire to a residential building in the Coconut Island area of Limbe in Fako during a ""ghost day"", likely part of ongoing fighting between Ambazonian separatists and military forces.

column6: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 29 March (or 30 March). Boko Haram and BIR military forces clash near Limani-Gourgui area of Kolofata, killing 2 Boko Haram members and retrieving military equipment.

column6: Police Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Prison Guards
column17: 30 March. Prison guards torture civilians in prison with machetes in Menda Nkwe of Bamenda 1, suspected to be former Ambazonian separatists.
30 March. A group of pirates from Nigeria hijacked a Liberian ship and kidnapped the crew off of the coast of Cameroon. The ship continued after the abduction to the docks at Douala port.
01 April. Cameroon gendarme forces clash with Ambazonian separatists at the Kombe market in Penda Mboko of Fiko. 3 soldiers were shot and one police officer is missing following the battle.
01 April. Military and Gendarmerie forces attack civilians during searches for Ambazonian separatists at the Baptist Hospital Mbingo in Mbengo of Belo, killing a civilian and wounding another.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Early April. An international task force (presumably Cameroon and Nigerian military forces) clash with Boko Haram members in Ardebe, killing 5 fighters.

02 April. Two Central African nationals attempt to steal motorcycles by attacking the moto drivers in Garoua of Bardanke. Riots erupt following the attempted theft, burning one of the thieves to death. [size=no report]
02 April. A business person from Tiko of Fako was abducted and beaten by Ambazonian separatists, they released him after a ransom was paid.
02 April. Military forces burn buildings in Mbipgo area of Ndu in Donga-Mantung as part of operations against separatists in the region.
03 April. A gendarme soldier attacks and kills a civilian in Muyuka of Fako, suspected of being an Ambazonian separatist.

column7: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Gendarmerie; Police Forces of Cameroon (1982-)
column17: 04 April. Military forces, gendarmerie and police attack civilians, burn and bulldoze buildings and homes in Jerfon neighborhood of Meluf in Kumbo of Jakiri, forcing many civilians to flee. 5 civilians are killed, with some reports of mutilation and beheading.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Between 05-09 April. 2 soldiers are abducted and killed by Boko Haram members near Ardebe of Makary.
05 April. A soccer coach is abducted by an unidentified armed group in Bamenda of Mezam. Reasons unclear.
06 April. Ambazonian separatists and military forces clash in Limbe of Fako at Mile 2. No casualties were reported.
07 April (night of). An unidentified armed group, suspected to be Cameroon military forces, kills a civilian following overnight gunshots in Bulu Native area of Buea in Fako.
07 April. Boko Haram faction of Islamic State clash with military forces in Fotokol of Hile Alifa, killing or injuring 20 soldiers. Unknown if dead or injured coded as 0 fatalities.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 06 or 07 April. Boko Haram forces clash with soldiers in Sagme of Hile Alifa. 3 soldiers were killed, 4 wounded and another missing following the clash. A number of Boko Haram militants were also neutralized (unknown coded as 10).
08 April. Military forces kill the Fon of Fuh village in Ndu, after the traditional leader was accused of leading an Ambazonian rebel faction.
On or before 08 April. Ambazonian separatists raped a young girl in Mbandi of Ako, leaving her hospitalised.
09 April. The president of a local court is kidnapped by an unidentified armed group near Mile 15 in Buea of Fako.

column7: MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
column17: 09 April. Supporters of Maurice Kamto protest at the court in Yaounde of Mfoundi against his ongoing imprisonment and trial. Police arrest 18 people part of the protest. [size=scores]
10 April. Military forces kill a civilian thought to be providing spiritual protection to Ambazonian separatists and burn the neighborhood of Dohseh Leghi in Bamenda of Mezam.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 12 April. Boko Haram detonate an IED within a military vehicle, killing one person and injuring 8 others in Kerawa of Kolofata.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 12 April. 4 soldiers are killed by Boko Haram after an IED was triggered near their vehicle near the axis of Vouzi-Vreket-Gouzda in Mayo Moskota.
12 April. A group of 6 secondary school children are abducted in Fongo-Tongo area of Menoua by an unidentified armed group.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 11 or 12 April. Boko Haram forces invade Nigue of Goulfey, stealing goods and forcing civilians to flee.
On or before 12 April. A farmer is beaten by military soldiers in Buea of Fako, forced to guide the soldiers to hideouts of Ambazonian separatists.
12 April. Police forces torture and kill a civilian involved in telephone repair in Douala of Wouri.
13 April. A soldier is killed and 8 others injured when a vehicle passed over a landmine, planted by an unidentified armed group.
Night of 13 April. Military forces kill a civilian while patrolling at Mile 14 Depanda near Douala of the Mutengene-Buea road.

column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Night of 13 April. Military forces clash with Boko Haram members in Sandawadjiri of Kolofata, killing 2 Boko Haram members.
14 April. Ambazonian separatists and military forces clash in Bali of Mezam, killing 3 separatists and 4 military soldiers.
15 April. A street trader is abducted by an unidentified armed group in Kumba of Ekondo Titi.
15 April. Military forces clash with Ambazonian separatists in Kosala area of Kumba, killing ""several"" soldiers. Unknown fatalities coded as 10.
15 April. Military forces burn civilians' houses in Luh village of Ndu in search of Ambazonian separatists.

In April, unidentified armed groups abduct over 30 people from Jakiri subdivision of Bui, a region of ongoing fighting between Ambazonian separatists and military forces. Many civilians were released following ransom payments.
In April, Ambazonian separatists abduct a woman from Fundong district as a wife for a separatist fighter, demanding a ransom for her release.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 16 April. Boko Haram steal oxen from pastoralists in Maloumri of Kolofata. BIR respond late and are unable to intervene in the theft.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 16 April. Boko Haram members kill 3 civilians in Kerawa of Kolofata while they are fetching firewood.
16 April. An unidentified armed group, which some suspect to be military forces, detonates an IED on a corpse, killing a civilian and wounding 2 others.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 18 April. Boko Haram members attack civilians, steal goods, and burn property in Tchakamari of Mayo-Sava, killing 7 civilians, injuring 5 others.
""One male national NGO staff member was kidnapped outside of his office in Buea town and held for several days by a non-state armed group active in the area.""

20 April. Security forces burn a home in Malende area of Muyuka in Fako, causing neighbors to gather and retaliate with machetes, killing a member of the military forces. Many flee from the village in fear of military retaliation.
21 April. Ambazonian separatists abduct 3 civilians connected to SDF National Chairman, Ni John Fru in Bafut of Mezam, demanding money and guns as ransom.
22 April. Military forces attack civilians in several areas around Bafut, including Mambu, Manka'a, Nikong areas of Mbebali and Njinteh neighborhoods. Two civilians are killed and ""tens"" arrested.
22 April. Military forces attack civilians in Tole Tea area of Buea of Fako, beating civilians, making arrests and removing some from their homes.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 22 April. More than 50 Boko Haram members attack civilians in Blangoua of Logone-Et-Chari, killing 8 civilians and injuring a dozen others.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 22 April. More than 50 Boko Haram members clash with military forces near Blangoua of Logone-Et-Chari. After the initial confrontation, military forces search the area for any remaining Boko Haram members, causing civilians to flee the area.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 22 April. Boko Haram members attack civilians in Madagascar area of Lake Chad near Blangoua, with 7 deaths recorded, 2 serious injuries and another slightly injured.

column6: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
column17: 23 April. Ambazonian separatists clash with BIR military forces in Kumbo of Jakiri after Ambazonian separatists attacked a military escort. 3 soldiers are wounded in the clash.
23 April. Four armed Ambazonian separatists break into a Saint Frederick high school in Bamenda of Mezam and abduct a civilian at gun point.
23 April. Prisoners in Mbouda Prison of Bamboutos protest over living conditions. 15 of the protesters were moved to the central prison in Bafoussam. [size=280]
24 April. Military forces clash with Ambazonian separatists in Muyuka of Fako. Ambazonian separatists abduct and kill a gendarme by dismembering and beheading him.
24 April. Ambazonian separatists burn the house of the mayor and Inspector General of Public Works in Ngwaikuma neighborhood on the outskirts of Fundong of Boyo.
Week of 24 April. Ambazonian separatists behead a soldier in Bamenda of Mezam.
24 April. A woman is abducted by Ambazonian separatists in Bambili of Mezam.
24 April. Military forces burn four civilian homes in Wat village of Nkambe sub division in search of Ambazonian separatists, but there was no direct confrontation between armed groups.

24 April. A man hailing from the Haoussa group was killed in Obala of Lekile in suspected communal violence. Clashes erupted between Obala and Haoussa communities the next day as a result (coded separately).

25 April. Obala and Haoussa communities clash using machetes and arrows, while others carry placards denouncing the lack of police intervention, in Obala of Lekie after the murder of a Haoussa man the day before.
26 April. The SDF Senate Vice-President, Emilia Nkeze, is abducted by Ambazonian separatists in Bamenda of Mezam near the residence of SDF National Chairman Ni John Fru.
26 April. Military forces attack civilians in Ikata of Muyuka, killing 4 civilians, burning homes and causing other civilians to flee.

column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 26 April. A member of a communal militia group in Maloumri of Kolofata is killed in a clash with Boko Haram.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: One night between 26-28 April. Boko Haram members clash with military forces on Kofia island of Lake Chad in Blangoua. 3 civilians and 1 soldier are killed and 5 are injured, as well as a military post burned and shops raided.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 27 April. Boko Haram members attack civilians in Bourouvare area of Kolofata, killing one person.
28 April. Ambazonian separatists kidnap a civilian from Mantum village in Jakiri, releasing the civilian 2 days later after a ransom payment.
29 April. Ambazonian separatists kill a police commissioner in Sabongari village in Donga-Mantung.

30 April. Military forces clash with Ambazonian separatists at separatist military camps in Wum and Echuan areas of Menchum, killing ""several"" separatists and 4 soldiers. Military forces also burn around 10 houses near the Ngoh public school. Total fatalities coded as 14.
30 April. Military forces burn 9 homes in the Tsenla area of Kikaikelaki (approx 5km north of Kumbo) in operations to find Ambazonian separatists, causing many civilian to flee.
30 April. Military forces clash with Ambazonian separatists in Kokibue area of Babessi in Balikumbat, killing ""several"" separatists. Unknown fatalities coded as 10.
01 May. Military forces shoot and kill a civilian in Mankon of Bamenda 2 returning from Labour Day festivities.
01 May. An unidentified armed group abducts 4 students from GBHS school in Mbefi quarter of Nkwen in Mezam,  demanding a ransom payment for their release.
03 May. Ambazonian separatists and military forces clash in Wowo village of Ndu, killing 2 civilians in the fighting.
04 May. Soldiers kill a mother and child while firing indiscriminate shots searching for Ambazonian separatists in the town of Bambui of Tubah.
05 May. Military forces retaliate against Ambazonian separatists following an attack on a military post the day before, killing 17 separatists and recovering equipment.
Near 05 May. An unidentified armed group abducts a civilian called Zachee Nzongandembou, CEO of Eden Media Group. He is released on 05 May.

05 May. Military forces attack civilians during searches for Ambazonian separatists in Ntamruh and Ntayi villages of Ndu. 7 civilians are killed, 42 homes burned and 400 cows are reported missing following the attack.
04 May. Ambazonian separatists clash with military forces at a military post in Dibonda of Mundemba, injuring 3 soldiers.
06 May. Ambazonian separatists and military forces clash in Santa of Mezam.
06 May. Police forces arrest over 200 civilians in Buea of Fako.

06 May. Ambazonian separatists clash with military forces in Bamnagam area of Bui, killing 2 separatists, injuring others and 2 missing following the fighting. Soldiers dismember the bodies of the separatists killed during the fighting.
07 May. Two villages in Mokolo sub-division clash over a land dispute, killing 6 people, leaving 300 homeless and destroying property.
09 May. Ambazonian separatists abduct 8 students, many female, from schools in Buea of Fako for violation of ""dead zone"" mandates, demanding payment for their release.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 05 September. Boko Haram forces attacked civilians and looted goods from Kordo, Kolofata. One civilian was killed in the attack.
10 May. Ambazonian separatists clash with military forces in Mah village of Nkum, setting houses on fire and forcing civilians to flee. No casualties reported.
10 May. Women's group, WTF, protests against ongoing violence in English-speaking regions of Cameroon. [size=200]

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 11 May. Boko Haram members attack civilians, as well as steal goods and cattle, in Dissalam of Fotokol. One civilian killed in the attack.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 11 May. Boko Haram members clash with military forces in Goshi town in Mokolo of Maya-Tsanagaburn, burning 67 homes, 11 stores and a church. 1 Boko Haram member is killed in the clash.

column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 12 May. Military forces and Boko Haram members clash in Sakme of Logone-et-Chari, killing 3 military soldiers and ""several"" Boko Haram members. Boko Haram members steal equipment and vehicles following the clash. ""Several"" coded as 10.
13 May. Military forces shooting sporadically to disperse a crowd, injuring a woman at the Tu Ngandeh Market in Nkambe of Donga-Mantung.
13 May. Military forces shoot and kill a 14 year old boy in his home in Mbakem of Akwaya, mistaken for an Ambazonian separatist.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column8: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
column17: 13 May. Boko Haram members clash with military BIR in Amchide of Kolofata.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 22 May. 3 brothers abducted by Boko Haram earlier in the year were found dead in Greya of Maroua 2.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 15 May. Boko Haram members loot motorcycles and other property from Milka area of Mora in Mayo-Sava. No deaths or injuries reported.
Mid-May. Ambazonian separatists tortured a civilian at an abandoned school in Bali, Mezam. Separatists forced the man to sit on burning paper in his underwear and beat him with machetes and sticks.

15 May. Ambazonian separatists and military forces clash in Mankon of Bamenda 2. Separatists kill 2 soldiers, while a civilian is killed by military forces. A clinic and scores of houses are burned in the fighting by military forces and indiscriminate shooting reported.
16 May. 30 Ambazonian separatists surrender to military forces in Kumba of Ekondo Titi.
16 May. Ambazonian separatists clash with military forces in Molyko and Dirty South areas of Buea.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 16 May. A civilian vehicle detonates a mine, likely planted by Boko Haram, killing 2 people and injuring 2 others.
14-19 May. Military forces fire shots and loot houses, businesses and government buildings in Kumbo of Jakiri, forcing civilians to flee.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: One day between 14 and 21 May. Boko Haram attack civilians in Malika of Mora. No casualties reported.
18 May. Military forces shoot and kill 12 people in Ebam of Eyumojock in Manyu.
18 May. Military forces shoot and kill 6 civilians, burn houses and make arrests in Nchang of Mamfe.
19 May. A police officer drops a grenade into a crowd of civilians in a bar at the Pont Vert area of Maroua of Diamare. 1 civilian is killed and around 25 injured.
19 May. Military forces shoot and kill a child in Muyuka of Fako during military operations in the area.

19 May. Gunshots in Balikumbat of Ngo-ketunjia are exchanged, likely between ongoing fighting between Ambazonian separatists and military forces, following the raising of the Ambazonian flag and grandstands being painted Ambazonian colours.
19 May. Police arrests ""hundreds"" of civilians in Marche Congo area of Douala before May 20 National Day. Civilians may be linked to opposition parties.
19 May. Military forces clash with Ambazonian separatists in Mantum village of Jakiri in Bui.

20 May. Military forces and Ambazonian separatists clash in Bamenda of Mezam. Military forces shoot and kill a civilian bar owner in Old Town area with shooting heard near Hotspot area in Up-Station as well.
20 May. Military forces shoot and kill a civilian in Leo village near Ekondo Titi and Mundemba of Ndian.
20 May. Ambazonian separatists clash with military forces in Buea of Fako.
20 May. Military forces clash with Ambazonian separatists in Kumba of Ekondo Titi.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 20 May. Boko Haram members clash with military forces in Ardori of Mora, with one serious injury reported.
20 May. Military forces clash with Ambazonian separatists in Kumbo of Jakiri. One separatist and a civilian are killed in the fighting, as well as another civilian injured.
21 May. Ambazonian separatists and military forces clash in Santa of Mezam, forcing civilians to flee or stay indoors.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 21 May. Military forces clash with Boko Haram members in Ardori, near Bonderi of Kolofata. 1 civilian and 1 soldier are killed in the fighting, as well as a Boko Haram member shot (coded as an injury) and buildings burned.
21 May. Ambazonian separatists kill and dismember a teacher in Bamenda of Mezam.
21 May. Ambazonian separatists and military forces clash in Nkwen of Mezam, with a soldier killed and dismembered in the clash.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 22 May. Boko Haram members clash with military forces in Sagme of Hile Alifa. No deaths or injuries reported.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 22 May. Boko Haram members attack civilians and steal goods 4 kilometres from Talkomari in Kolofata. 1 civilian is killed in the attack

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 22 May. Boko Haram abducts a man from a rural part of Gouderi of Kolofata, taking him towards the Nigerian border.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 22 May. Boko Haram attack civilians in Malika of Mora, killing one and injuring others.
22 May. Around 60 civilians are arrested by police and gendarme forces in Buea of Fako, suspected to be Ambazonian separatists.
23 May. Military forces kill a civilian moto-taxi driver, injure others, shoot indiscriminately and burn motorcycles at Mile 90 of Bamenda in Mezam.
23 May. Military forces clash with Ambazonian separatists in Essu of Fungom, with 9 deaths recorded following the clash including civilian casualties.
23 May. Military forces kill a civilian moto-taxi driver in Kumba of Ekondo Titi, suspected of connections with Ambazonian separatists.
24 May. Ambazonian separatists abduct three teachers and steal goods from Bakweri Town area of Buea in Fako, demanding a ransom for their release.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 25 May. Boko Haram members attack civilians on the island of Boram on Lake Chad in Blangoua. 1 civilian is killed and several injured.
25 May. Military forces shoot and kill 5 civilians from the same family in Sang area of Bali in Mezam, with 2 others injured. Some civilians in the area flee into hiding.
26 May. Police forces clash with 2 Ambazonian separatists attempting to smuggle arms on a bus from Bomako to Buea in Fako. 2 Ambazonian separatists die in the clash.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 27 May. Boko Haram members attack civilians and steal goods in Choloba of Fotokol, killing 1 civilian.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 27 May. A Boko Haram suicide bomber detonates a suicide vest in Magdeme of Mora after being stopped by a communal militia, killing the bomber and injuring other civilians.
30 June. Ambazonian separatists attack civilian refugees in Upkwa Resettlement Camp near Lake Nyos in Wum. Separatists attack civilians and burn around 40 homes. No casualties reported.

column7: MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
column17: 01 June. MRC protesters demonstrate in Yaounde of Mfoundi for the release of Maurice Kamto, with police dispersing protesters with water canons. [size=no report]

column7: MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
column17: 01 June. MRC protesters demonstrate in Yaounde of Mfoundi for the release of Maurice Kamto, with police intervening and making arrests. [size=at least 300 between all protests on the same day]

column7: MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
column17: 01 June. MRC protesters demonstrate in Douala of Wouri for the release of Maurice Kamto, with police dispersing protesters with water canons and making arrests. [size=at least 300 between all protests on the same day]

column7: MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
column17: 01 June. MRC protesters demonstrate in Bafoussam of Mifi for the release of Maurice Kamto, with police dispersing protesters and making arrests. [size=at least 300 between all protests on the same day]

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 01 June. Boko Haram members abducted a young boy near Tourou and Ngosi, Mokolo during cattle raids.
02 June. Ambazonian separatists attack civilians and destroy houses in Aghem area of Wum, killing one civilian.

03 June. Hausa and Aku militia attack Fulani civilians in Naikom and Waindo areas of Wum, with military forces standing by to allow the attack. The armed group kills 2, wounds 5 others and destroys several buildings including the palaces in Naikom and Waindo. Aghem claim these were retaliatory attacks for separatist attacks in their village.
04 June. Military forces attack and kill 3 civilians suspected of being Ambazonian separatists in Balikumbat of Ngo-ketunjia.
06 June. A mob riots and injures a gendarme soldier who killed a taxi driver in Bafoussam of Mifi. [size=no report]
06 June. A gendarme soldier shoots and kills a taxi driver while in pursuit of another vehicle in Bafoussam of Mifi.
07 June. Military forces attacked civilians and burned homes in Essu, Menchum. Twelve civilians were killed during attacks on the town from 07-09 June. (Fatalities are spread across events).

column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 08 June. Military forces and Boko Haram members clash in Nguetchewe of Mayo-Tsanaga.
08 June. Military forces attacked and kill 8 civilians in Ekona, Muyuka. The soldiers accused the victims of being Ambazonian separatists.
08 June. Two girls were abducted by Ambazonian separatists in Nkwen, Mezam. The girls were beaten and released three days later after a ransom was paid.

column7: MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
column17: 08 June. MRC supporters demonstrated calling for the release of Maurice Kamto as part of ""white marches"" in Yaounde. Police intervened to disperse the protest, beating some and arresting around 200 people. [size=at least 200]
08 June. Military forces attacked civilians and burned homes in Essu, Menchum. Twelve civilians were killed during attacks on the town from 07-09 June. (Fatalities are spread across events).

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 08 June. A woman was killed by Boko Haram, during an attack in Kolofata, Mayo-Sava.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 08 June. Boko Haram members attacked civilians in Nguetchewe, Mayo-Tsanaga, killing 2.
09 June. Military forces attacked civilians and burned homes in Essu, Menchum. Twelve civilians were killed during attacks on the town from 07-09 June. (Fatalities are spread across events).
09 June. Military forces attacked civilians in Weh (Zoa), Menchum. One civilian was killed in the attack.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 06 September. ISWAP/Boko Haram forces fired rounds and ""stormed"" the market in Bargaram, Hile Alifa. One civilian was killed while fleeing the attack.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column16: L'Oeil; Mimi Mefo; UN (unspecified); Journal du Cameroun
column17: Night of 09 June. Around 300 Boko Haram members clash with military forces, destroy property, loot and kill civilians around Lake Chad in Darak, Diamare. 16 soldiers , 8 civilians and 64 Boko Haram members killed, with many others injured. 7 soldiers are missing and 15 Boko Haram combatants were arrested by military forces.
06 September. Ambazonian separatists abducted 2 civilians from Baligham, Mezam.

column6: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
column17: 09 June. A BIR soldier opened fire on 2 moto taxi drivers, killing one, in Moroua, Diamare. The BIR soldier flees to a local police station after upset taxi-moto drivers pursue him, upset about the death of a colleague.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 10 June. Boko Haram members killed 2 merchants on the route between Amchide and Kolofata.
10 June. Ambazonian separatists clashed with military forces in the Bui region of the Nord-Ouest. Eight separatists and one soldier were killed.
12 June. Ambazonian separatists and military forces clash in Hausa Quarter in Santa, Mezam, killing one separatist.
12 June. Ambazonian separatists abducted a civilian in Bamenda, Mezam.

column6: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 12 June. BIR forces and Boko Haram members clash in Kolofata of Mayo-Sava after Boko Haram attempted to raid shops. At least three Boko Haram combatants were killed in the clash, while some sources. Indicate four.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 13 June. Boko Haram members attacked civilians and pillaged goods from Tagawa, Waza. Two civilians were killed and 2 others injured.
13 June. Military forces shoot and killed a civilian, in Santa of Mezam.
14 June. Military forces attack civilians and burn homes in Akwese village, Ako (no coordinated available). 4 civilians were killed, 6 homes burned, and many others fled to Nigeria.

14 June. Military forces detained 10 farmers suspected to be Ambazonian separatists in Babanki, Boyo. The security forces killed 6 of them, burying the bodies nearby. The other 4 may still be detained, as no bodies were found.
15 June. A police vehicle hit a land mine planted by Ambazonian separatists in Eyumojock, Manyu, killing 4 and injuring 3.

column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 15 June. Boko Haram members clashed with military forces in Ngouma, Hile Alifa, killing 3 Boko Haram members.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 16 June. Boko Haram members burn houses and steal goods from civilians in Menensoe, Fotokol.
On or before 16 June. A man is found dead in Domayo Bololo quarter of Maroua in Diamare, which some suspect may have been a Boko Haram attack.

One day between 16-18 June. Ambazonian separatists clashed with military forces in several villages of Mbengwi of Momo including Njindom, Barakwe and Nyen (no coordinates available) around Miles 19 and 20.
17 June. Military forces burn civilian homes in Bai Panya, Meme in ongoing operations against Ambazonian separatists.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 17 June. Boko Haram steals livestock from civilians in Tchika, Hile Alifa.
17 June. Police forces clash with Ambazonian separatists in Mamfe, Manyu, killing one police officer.
18 June. Ambazonian separatists abducted 40 civilian road workers outside of Wum on the Wum-Bafut-Bamenda road near Mile 24. They are beaten and released the next day.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 18 June. Boko Haram members abducted 4 civilians and looted goods in Boungour village of Makari (no coordinates available).

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 18 June. Boko Haram members abducted 4 civilians from Afade, Makary in Logone-Et-Chari. 1 civilian was later found dead.
19 June. Ambazonian separatists abducted 6 vehicles on the road between Wum and Bamenda in Menchum. They are beaten and released the next day.

column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 19 June. Military forces defused a land mine planted by Boko Haram in Kolofata zone of Mayo-Sava.

column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 19 June. Military forces clashed with Boko Haram forces in Ngouma, Hile Alifa, capturing 1 Boko Haram member, recovering goods and weapons and killing 3 Boko Haram members.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 20 June. Boko Haram forces looted a village in the Kolofata area of Mayo-Sava.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 20 June. Boko Haram forces, force pastoralists in Ngouma to bury their dead, loot their livestock, and then kill some of the civilians. Unknown fatalities coded as 10.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 21 June. Boko Haram combatants attacked and killed 2 civilian farmers in Makary, Logone-Et-Chari.
21 June. Military forces attacked and killed a civilian in Mbah village, Nsoh (no coordinates available) in the Nord-Ouest region.

column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 21 June. A soldier was killed during a clash with Boko Haram, between Waliassi and Wambashe, Kolofata.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 21 June. Boko Haram members attacked 6 fisherman on a boat near the island of Bouaram, Darak. One fisherman escaped, while the other 5 were killed.

column7: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
column17: 21 June. BIR and military forces killed a civilian and raped a woman in Kumbo, Bui.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 22 June. Boko Haram clashed with a local militia in Malia, Waza. Two civilians were injured in the fighting.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 22 June. 2 civilians are stabbed and killed by Boko Haram members in Amchoukouli village in Fotokol, Hile Alifa.
23 June. Ambazonian separatists burned and destroyed two vehicles carrying World Food Programme food aid in Mezam, Nord-Ouest.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 23 June. Boko Haram members abducted and killed 2 civilians in Amchide, Kolofata.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 23 June. Boko Haram clashed with military forces during an ambush near Waliassi and Wambashe areas, Kolofata. 1 soldier was killed in the fighting.
On or before 24 June. Military forces killed 2 civilians after removing them from their homes and shooting them in Mbiam, Babessi.
25 June. Ambazonian separatists abducted a civilian, the Archbishop of Bamenda, near Belo, Boyo. He was released the next day.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column8: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
column17: 27 June. Boko Haram forces coming from Nigeria clashed with Cameroon BIR military forces at the border town of Moussafari (no coordinates available) near Double-Alagarno, Mayo-Sava. BIR forces recovered stolen livestock from Boko Haram forces.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 28 June. Boko Haram militants attacked two civilians and abducted two others in Krawa, Mayo-Tsanaga.

28 June. Chairman of the SDF, John Ndi Fru Ndi, was abducted by an unidentified armed group in Bamenda, Mezam. The attackers also shot his guard in the leg during the abduction. This was his second abduction in recent months.
30 June. A civilian was killed by military forces in Bamenda, Mezam.
01 July. Military forces clashed with Ambazonian separatists in Kumbo, Jakiri.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 01 July. Boko Haram militants attacked civilians in Nguetchewe, Mayo-Tsanaga (no further details available).
01 July. Ambazonian separatists and military forces clashed in Batibo, Momo leaving several casualties on both sides (Coded as 10).
01 July. A civilian was killed by military forces in Mpundu Balong, Muyuka as they suspected the victim of being a separatist.
02 July. One child is killed and 2 others wounded by a bomb explosion in Liabelem, Sud-Ouest.
03 July. Around 30 Ambazonian separatists clashed with military forces after separatists ambushed a transport boat in the Ekpambiri area of Manyu. Several soldiers are injured.
04 July. Ambazonian separatists clashed with military forces in Bamenda, Mezam. Military forces attacked and killed a civilian following the killing of a soldier during the fighting.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 05 July. Boko Haram militants attacked civilians, burned houses and looted goods in Geldavi, Mayo Moskota. 1 civilian was killed and two severely injured in the attack.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 06 July. Boko Haram and military forces clashed in Gtia Wulgo, Longone-Et-Chari. 2 military forces are severely injured during the fighting.
07 July. An unidentified armed group abducted a Christian pastor from Buea. He was released on 10 July.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 07 July. Boko Haram and military forces clashed in Zelevet, Mokolo after a raid by Boko Haram in this area. 2 civilians were injured and a motorcycle was stolen.
08 July. A soldier fired shots at a civilian during an altercation in Mokolo, Mayo-Tsanaga. A gendarme stopped further action by the soldier, but it is unclear if the shots hit the civilian.
09 July. Gendarme forces and Ambazonian separatists clashed in Bamessing, Ndop. 2 Gendarme were killed and three others injured in the fighting.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 07 September. Boko Haram militants attacked civilians and looted goods in Madakar, Mayo Moskota. One woman was seriously injured in the attack.
10 July. Ambazonian separatists and military forces clash in Alachu area of Bamenda, Mezam. 2 civilians are killed in security operations with another killed by a stray bullet during the fighting.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 10 July. Boko Haram looted goods and destroyed buildings in Tourou, Mokolo.
11 July. An unidentified armed group attacked and killed a civilian in Amchide, Kolofata.
11 July. Military forces clash with Ambazonian separatists in Essu, Fungom. 7 separatists were killed in the fighting.

column6: Police Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Prison Guards
column9: Women (Cameroon); Prisoners (Cameroon); MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
column17: On and before 11 July. Prison guards attacked, tortured and beat MRC supporters, including women, in Yaounde, Mfoundi. Prisoners were arrested during protests in early June.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad

Around 1 July 2020 (between 28 June - 4 July), the military forces attacked an Ambazonian separatists camp in Bum village (Boyo; Nord-Ouest) during a 7 day-long operation in Ngo-ketunjia and Bui departments, that resulted in a total of 17 separatists and one soldier killed. Fatalities split across 5 events.

Around 1 July 2020 (between 28 June - 4 July), the military forces staged a 7-day military operation dubbed ""NgokeBui"" against Ambazonian separatists camps in Ngo-ketunjia and Bui (Bui, Nord-Ouest) departments. It included the Ebal, Verkei, Ngebsiba, Oku in Ndum, Njikijem, Elak, Njotim, Tadu, Bim and Kumbo central villages. Due to severe rain the separatists were alerted to the military's presence and fled before they arrived, but in some cases separatists stayed and engaged in armed clashes, that resulted in a total of 17 separatists and one soldier killed. Fatalities split across 5 events.

column17: On 9 April 2012, clashes between Chadian rebels led by Baba Lade and local militia in the Galafondo area set up in response to their increased exactions left at least three dead, including one militia member.

column7: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Government soldiers fired shots in the air in Bangassou to protest authorities failure to pay their food pension for a month and a half.
Residents of Libi village north of Bangui, near Galafondo, set up barricades on national road II to protest insecurity in the region due to the presence of Chadian rebels led by Baba Lade.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column9: Military Forces of Chad (1990-); Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019)
column17: Tripartite CAR/Sudan/Chad force attacked by Sudanese SLM/A Minnawi rebels on their base in Am-Dafok in a cross-border ambush. At least 78 people were killed, including 11 CAR and 65 Sudanese soldiers. Two Sudanese soldiers were also abducted.
Chadian Mbarara militiamen attacked Ngapele village in Ouassi, killing a man, injuring several and looting and burning at least 82 properties. Populations fled to Batangafo.
At least three people were killed in Bozoum in the northwest of the country.
UPDF capture Caesar Achellam, along with his wife, daughter, and assistant, one of the top 5 commanders in the LRA after an ambush of LRA camp.
Bandits attacked a school truck traveling from Bangui to Cameroon between Baboua and Garou-Boulai, severely injuring several children and robbing all of them of their belongings.

column6: APRD: Popular Army for the Restoration of the Republic and Democracy
column17: Surrender/Defect:Former APRD rebel group was dissolved during an official ceremony after its elements were all disarmed and demobilised.
Nomad cattle herders have killed five villagers in clashes that displaced 3 500 in the northern Batangafo region of the Central African Republic
Clashes between two families led to the use of a grenade which, when it detonated, killed one person and injured several others in Gbafio de Boy Rabe neighborhood of Bangui.
Gunmen attacked Sudanese traders on their way to Birao from Amdofock in Sudan, at Kafragada village, leaving two severely injured and property looted.

column6: CPJP: Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace
column17: Looting: Suspected CPJP elements attacked seven public transport vehicles 80km from Ndele. No casualty but property looted. CPJP denied the accusations.
The Ugandan rebel group, the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA), carried out attacks between June 21-25 killing at least two civilians and abducted at least 14 others.
In Lengo, 10 kilometers from Bakouma, LRA combatants killed a fisherman near the river on June 23. The same day, they stabbed an elderly carpenter with a bayonet and then decapitated him.
Rebels attacked and looted a plant operated by French nuclear giant Areva, according to some sources workers were kidnapped and later released
At least 10 other civilians were abducted in and around Ouanda and Denguiro.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: The LRA attacked the field base of French company, Areva, clashing with soldiers at the base. They occupied the base for a while, keeping four people hostage, including 3 French nationals.
At least 10 other civilians were abducted in and around Ouanda and Denguiro.
Looting: Bandits suspected of supporting a new rebellion in the area burnt down and looted property and weapons at a safari area in Bamingui Bangoran. They were arrested a few days later.

column6: MICOPAX: Mission for the Consolidation of Peace in Central African Republic (2008-2013)
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013) Gendarmerie
column17: Clashes between Chadian soldiers of MICOPAX and CAR policemen of the gendarmerie left three killed in Bangui.

column6: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column17: Clashes between CAR forces and suspected FPR gunmen in Boali in Ombelle MPoko prefecture. No known casualty from the fighting. The gunmen then killed a herder whom they suspected of having given their location to the government forces.

column6: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Clashes between CAR forces and suspected FPR gunmen in Boali in Ombelle MPoko prefecture. No known casualty from the fighting. The gunmen then killed a herder whom they suspected of having given their location to the government forces.
A group of around 25 gunmen attacked Boali Poste in Ombelle MPoko, looting and damaging property, killing livestock and assaulting civilians and robbing them of their belongings.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: an officer of the presidential guard killed a young girl selling food when he opened fire on a crowd while residents were asking for his help to carry the body of a man killed in a hold-up

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013) Prison Guards
column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Candidates who failed the military entry exam protested in Bangui against the results, setting up road blocks and burning tyres on roads and roundabouts in three neighbourhoods of the capital, as well as breaking doors of the Ngaragba prison, enabling prisoners to flee. Shots were fired by prison guards as they approached, but the guards retreated. The rioters also threw stones at soldiers stationed at various places in the town.

column6: CPJP: Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Last rebel group CPJP signs deal with Central African Republic
Gunmen abducted five gold diggers at a mining site at Kouzindoro village in Boali region. One of them escaped.
Several shops got looted and 5 people abducted by 18 unidentified armed men.
Gunmen raped several women, shortly abducted four men and stole property at a mining site at Malinguinza village in Ombella MPoko around 11 August.
Suspected LRA gunmen attacked Ouanda village in Bakouma, abducting 16 people and looting property. 14 later escaped.
unidentified armed men attacked the village of Boutili. A 75 year old man and his 25 year old grandson got killed by the attackers.
On or around 22 August 2012, gunmen abducted three people in Boali.
On or around 22 August 2012, a local militia went looking for the kidnapped civilians in Boali and clashed with gunment responsible for the kidnapping.

On 23 August 2012, clashes between local militia and unidentified gunmen in Boali left at least one gunman killed and another injured. The militia were looking for three people the gunmen had earlier abducted.
Ugandas army clash with LRA 70km west of Djema

column6: CPJP: Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace
column8: Government of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: The Conventions of Patriots for Justice and Peace (CPJP) signed a peace deal with the government on Saturday that was designed to end years of violence in the country

column7: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013); Military Forces of the United States (2009-2017)
column17: Uganda, CAR and US forces attacked and destroyed the LRA base of its number 3 Lt Dominique Ongwen in a CAR forest, capturing ammunition and household equipment from the group and forcing them to retreat into the forest.

LRA raided Balifondo and Zobe Mbari villages of Bangassou in Mbomou on 1 September, abducting 55 people, mostly girls, including 41 in Balifondo. 52 girls were released a week later by the LRA. They were reportedly sexually abused while being detained.

LRA raided Balifondo and Zobe Mbari villages of Bangassou in Mbomou on 1 September, abducting 55 people, mostly girls, including 41 in Balifondo. 52 girls were released a week later by the LRA. They were reportedly sexually abused while being detained.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: At the start of September, a soldier and two civilians were killed during clashes between Peul stockbreeders and troops.
Between September 1-3 LRA forces killed 2 civilians in Mbomou.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013) Presidential Security Unit
column8: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column9: MINURCAT: United Nations Mission in the Central African Republic and Chad (2007-2010)
column17: Surrender/Defect:Abdel Kader Baba Ladde surrenders himself to CARs army forces
Ugandas army forces attack Onweng camp. Three rebels are killed. Ongwen survives

column6: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column17: FPR rebels abducted three herders in Ouroudjafoune (east) commune of Bambari as the herders refused to let them steal livestock. This comes a day after FPR leader Baba Lade was extradited to Chad after having surrendered to the CAR armed forces in Ippy. They were released soon after.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: 30-40 LRA members ambush convoy carrying CAR soldiers on the main road from Zemio to Obo near Kitessa. One soldier is killed and seven wounded

column6: CPJP: Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column9: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: CPJP rebels raided the towns of Damara and Sibut Saturday and tried to take control of strategic points such as police stations, customs posts and administrative buildings. At least one soldier was killed as the CPJP moved from Damara to Sibut. In Sibut, the rebels freed prisoners and looted property.

column6: CPJP: Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Dekoa was attacked by a group called the Fundamental Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace. They were driven back by CAR forces. Injuries on both sides.

column6: CPJP: Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column9: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: CPJP rebels raided the towns of Damara and Sibut Saturday and tried to take control of strategic points such as police stations, customs posts and administrative buildings. At least one soldier was killed as the CPJP moved from Damara to Sibut. In Sibut, the rebels freed prisoners and looted property.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column8: CPJP: Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace
column17: Col Hache Ha, who recently proclaimed himself spokesman of a dissident faction of the Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace was killed in clashes with the army in Daya village in Dekoa.
CAR gunmen abducted two Chinese workers on the Bouar Garou-Boulai axis as they retreated from an attack at a border post in Cameroon.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013) Presidential Security Unit
column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Members of the presidential guard kidnapped a Corporal in the armies special services unit and his brother in Bangui.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Three people died in the capital of the Central African Republic when a soldier stabbed a civilian and then used a hand grenade, killing himself and a paramilitary policeman

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013) Presidential Security Unit
column17: Two soldiers from the presidential guard opened fire against civilians under alcohol influence, killing four. Members of the gendarmerie and of the armed forces confronted the members of the presidential guard, leaving two killed.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013) Presidential Security Unit
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013) Gendarmerie
column17: Two soldiers from the presidential guard opened fire against civilians under alcohol influence, killing four. Members of the gendarmerie and of the armed forces confronted the members of the presidential guard, leaving two killed.

column6: Government of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column8: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column17: 400 out of 3000 militants of Chadian former rebel leader of FPR (Popular Front for Recovery) were sent back to Chad from Sido.
Residents of Dekoa staged a peaceful march in the town to express gratitude to the government in tackling insecurity in the area.
LRA rebels attacked populations near Obo, leaving a child killed and his father kidnapped. The abductee escaped six days later.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: A soldier shot a youth in Kissedjia village for refusing to pay an illegal toll as he was traveling with a group of people from Obo, leaving him severely injured. Members of the Gendarmerie later arrested the soldier.
Clashes between LRA and Ugandan army 50km from Obo around 20 October. A child who had been abducted by the group three years prior managed to escape.
Looting: Gunmen looted three vehicles of the Solidarites NGO in the northern part of Batangafo town.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013) Gendarmerie
column17: Pitched fight between elements of the Gendarmerie and members of a big family in Sosso-Nakombo (west) commune over a mistaken summon. Some people were arrested. Soldiers were sent to the commune the following day and fired shots in the air, forcing dozens of people to flee to the bush.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column8: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column17: An army vehicle was attacked by FPR. A civilian who was travelling with the soldiers was killed

column9: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Two civilians and one policeman are killed while travelling to Bangui by a group of armed men in the village of Libi ,near the capital Bangui

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Armed men attack a transporting vehicle carrying troops

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Chadian soldiers shot and killed four CAR soldiers at the tripartite forces base in Birao after a dispute. Another five were injured, while shots were fired in the town throughout the night, forcing dozens of people to flee.
LRA attacked Kpete and Kpiawo villages in Mbomou, killing a farmer as he was returning from his field and looting property.
LRA attacked a goldmining site in Fode, Mbomou, leaving one person severely injured and causing significant material damage. A number of people were abducted by the rebels.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column8: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column17: Rebels attack army base in Kabo. Two soldiers and 8 rebels are killed

A truck driver was killed and his passengers were beaten and robbed by a group of unidentified gunmen, who ambushed the truck as it was passing between Damara and Sibut. The assailants were similar to those described after a November assault on the prefect of Ouaka by armed men who ""spoke Arabic and wore armbands a foreign force."" After the incident, the gunmen also stopped and looted a humanitarian vehicle travelling on the axis.

column6: UFDR: Union of Democratic Forces for Unity
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column9: CPJP: Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace
column17: Ndele was attacked and suddenly captured in a raid by UFDR rebels on Monday. Ndele, located near the Chadian border, is an especially important crossing point for convoys coming from Sudan and Cameroon. Rebels took several prisoners and vehicles. At least four died and 22 government troops were captured in clashes at Ndele and Sam Ouandja. A report claims CPJP supported the army during this attack. However, CPJP is later listed in alliance with UFDR.

column6: UFDR: Union of Democratic Forces for Unity
column7: CPJP: Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace
column17: New Group:After an offensive by the Union of Democratic Forces for Unity (UFDR, under Michel Am Nondokro Djotodia) that overtook three towns in northern CAR, four rebellious factions formed an alliance to oppose CAR President Bozize, creating a force of 4,600 combatants. The movement, calling itself Seleka, is comprised of the UFDR, the Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic (CPJP) under Nourredine Adam, the Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic (FDPC) under Abdoulaye Miskine, and a separate CPJP faction under d Abdoulaye Hissene.

column6: UFDR: Union of Democratic Forces for Unity
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Three towns--Ndele, Sam Ouandja and Ouadda, fell under the control of UFDR rebels in a series of attacks on military bases on Monday. Ndele, located near the Chadian border, is an especially important crossing point for convoys coming from Sudan and Cameroon. Rebels killed 4 at Ndele and Sam Ouandja, and took several prisoners and vehicles.

column6: UFDR: Union of Democratic Forces for Unity
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Three towns--Ndele, Sam Ouandja and Ouadda, fell under the control of URDR rebels in a series of attacks on military bases on Monday. Ndele, located near the Chadian border, is an especially important crossing point for convoys coming from Sudan and Cameroon. Rebels took several prisoners and vehicles.

column6: UFDR: Union of Democratic Forces for Unity
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: CARs defence ministry claimed it reclaimed Ndele after rebels gained control over the city on Monday.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Rebel troops recaptured Ndele in an attack on Saturday, nearly a week after its first raid.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013) Presidential Security Unit
column17: According to several families in Bangui and rebel spokesman Col. Juma Narkoyo, members of the Presidential Guard have kidnapped roughly a dozen people suspected of supporting the rebels in recent weeks. Interrogations, arrests, and kidnappings target Muslims, as the CAR is predominantly Christian and the rebels Muslim. The U.S. State Department claims to have heard reports of hundreds of arrests and disappearances of members of ethnic groups associated with the rebels.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Rebel forces attacked and captured Bamingui. 14 CAR troops are confirmed dead, with 30 missing and 7 wounded.
Townspeople looted shops in Bria after the rebels overtook the city.
Rebel troops killed a customs agent, detained several women to extort ransom payment, and looted shops after taking control of the important mining town of Bria.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Around 4 am, the Seleka rebel coalition used heavy weapons to overtake a military base and seize the central mining town of Bria, located about 600 kilometers (370 miles) northeast of the capital, Bangui.

column7: Government of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: A small march was held by MPs along the streets near the National Assembly in city center, followed by a brief address by Celestin Le roi Gombalet. The MPs demonstrated for the CAR to sustain a policy of non-violence.

column7: Government of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Deployment:About 2,000 Chadian forces arrived in CAR after an appeal to Chad by CAR President Bozize for help guarding against the Seleka rebel coalition, following rebels attack on Bria. The troops will are being used to secure strategic routes through Sibut and fortify the capital, Bangui. They were also deployed in a squadrom of around 20 vehicles near Kaga-Bandoro.
One rape and one significant looting occurred in Kabo after rebels took the town on Wednesday.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Seleka fighters said Wednesday they had taken the northern town of Kabo early Wednesday. Batangafo is 300 km north of the capital of Bangui. Doctors without Borders reported tending to four wounded.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Military forces previously stationed at Batangafo retreated to Bossangoa.

Army authorities in Kampala claim that CAR military attention to the recent rebellion has left a military vacuum in teams persuing the LRA, which has allowed the LRA to attack and abduct civilians in recent days.

column8: Government of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Rebels captured a 7th town shortly after releasing a statement that they would stop all violent action. Entrance into Batangafo met with no resistance, as military had retreated to Bossangoa 48 hours before for unknown reasons. Hours before the invasion, rebels had stated to the press their intention of ceasing all troop movements while awaiting dialogue demanded by the CEEAC.
Hundreds of people protested in Bangui, Banguassou, Bouar and Boali against violence in the north and the overtaking of seven towns by the Seleka coalition.
Hundreds of people protested in Bangui, Banguassou, Bouar and Boali against violence in the north and the overtaking of seven towns by the Seleka coalition.
Hundreds of people protested in Bangui, Banguassou, Bouar and Boali against violence in the north and the overtaking of seven towns by the Seleka coalition.
Hundreds of people protested in Bangui, Banguissou, Bouar and Boali against violence in the north and the overtaking of seven towns by the Seleka coalition.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: After a skirmish with incoming military vehicles at previous positions, rebel forces seized two separate towns in succession: Ippy and, the next day, Ndassim. The seizure of new towns comes one day after rebels conceded to a temporary ceasefire awaiting negotiations in Libreville.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: After a skirmish with incoming military vehicles at previous positions, rebel forces seized two separate towns in succession: Ippy and, the next day, Ndassim. The seizure of new towns comes one day after rebels conceded to a temporary ceasefire requested by CEEAC, awaiting negotiations in Libreville (Chad designated as mediator).

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Seleka forces overtake Koukourou near Ndele after clashes with CAR soldiers.
Suspected Seleka gunmen apprehended a shopkeeper and the custom posts chief over allegedly taking their picture. They freed the custom post officer and killed the shopkeeper.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Rebels in Central African Republic have taken the key town of Bambari under their control. Government forces fled the city of about 40,000 after about two hours of gunfire that left two of them killed, and several of their vehicles were seized by the rebels.
An anonymous local source claims to have received reports of ""hunts"" for women by rebel forces in Bambari.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: The rebel coalition seized the town of Kaga-Bandoro, located about 385 kilometers (240 miles) from the capital, Bangui. They shot with heavy weapons towards strategic points like the basic military detachment, gendarmerie, customs office, and police station before resisting forces retreated toward Sibut. Five or more wounded, with an unknown number of fatalities.

100 rioters carried clubs and threw stones at the French Embassy in Bangui in a demonstration against French inaction against rebel forces threatening the capital city. The riot began at a protest at the U.S. Embassy. French President Francois Holland has declared that he would send military only to protect French interests and citizens in the capital, and would not prop up the Bangui government.
An anonymous local source claims to have received reports of the rape of young girls by Chadian forces in Sibut.

column6: FOMUC: Multinational Force in the Central African Republic
column7: CEMAC: Economic and Monetary Community of Central Africa
column17: On 28 December 2012, the Multinational Force in the Central African Republic reinforced its military presence in Damara (75 km de Bangui) as Seleka rebels threatened they would enter Bangui. The following Sunday, the Economic Community of Central African States (CEMAC) declared Damara as the ""line not to be crossed"" lest rebels trigger retaliation from FOMUC, which now numbers 560 in the region. The CEMAC later suggested it would increase FOMUC presence in CAR.

column6: FOMUC: Multinational Force in the Central African Republic
column17: A diplomatic team from FOMUC sent a delegation to the rebel-held strategic town of Ndele in the north to meet members of the rebel coalition Seleka. The delegation is composed of the Congolese general Guy-Pierre Garcia, the deputy secretary general of the CEEAC, and five others.

column7: OFC: Organization of Central African Republic Women; Women (Central African Republic)
column17: 300 women marched throughout the capital to demonstrate against rebel violence in the north and deliver a petition of non-violence to Prime Minister Faustin Archange Touadera.

column7: Government of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: A squadron of troops from Chad attacked rebel troops at Bambari. An early report (Associated Press) reported military recapture, but a subsequent report (Xinhua) confirmed that rebels repelled the attack. According to rebels, Seleka killed 41 and captured a dozen heavy arms as well as one vehicles, and their opponents killed 2 and injured 1.

column6: UFDR: Union of Democratic Forces for Unity
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Military forces attempted to retake the rebel-controlled city of Bamingui but were repelled and retreated to Sibut, then Damara. Rebels reported one dead and three injured, while the military reported unspecified ""losses.""

Rebels seized the city of Sibut, 185 kilometers (114 miles) from Bangui. Rebel forces overtook the city without a battle because the CAR army and forces from Chad had pulled back to Damara, 75 kilometers (46 miles) from Bangui on Friday.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column7: Government of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Arrests: Police forces conducted about 50 ""arbitrary arrests"" of civilians suspected of rebel involvement, including two former deputies of the National Assembly.

column6: Government of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column7: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Looting: Government officials mandated an indefinite 19:00 to 5:00 curfew as rebels position themselves outside of Bangui and threaten attack. Military is deployed throughout the streets to prevent looting.

180 French troops and two French military helicopters arrived in Bangui in the threatened capital, increasing in-country military presence to 580 troops. The Minister of Defense has claimed that the soldiers are intended to assist in EU citizen evacuations and protecting French interests, not defending the capital.

column7: Government of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: African Union president Thomas Boni Yayi, in conjunction with CAR president Francois Bozize, addressed Seleka rebels in Bangui with an offer to form a coalition ""government of national unity"" with Bozize, which would include representation from the rebels. Rebels agreed to dialogue but responded that they would retain their positions until the stated offers were enacted. They further threatened attacking Bangui unless Bozize stepped down unconditionally.

column6: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column7: Government of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: 120 troops from Republic of Congo arrived at sunset on New Years Eve in Bangui and began heading toward the governments defences at Damara. Troops from Gabon and Cameroon are also expected in the coming days to join extra forces already sent from Chad.
UN BINUCA Special Representative Zainab Bangura reports sexual violence from rebel and non-rebel forces in CAR, particularly by rebels in of Bria.
Looting: OCDH (Observatoire centrafricain des droits de lhomme) investigators report looting in Ndele and Bria, as well as Kaga Bandoro (noted above).
Looting: OCDH (Observatoire centrafricain des droits de lhomme) investigators report looting in Ndele and Bria, as well as Kaga Bandoro (noted above).
Looting: OCDH (Observatoire centrafricain des droits de lhomme) investigators report looting in Ndele and Bria, as well as Kaga Bandoro (noted above).

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column7: Government of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: A Muslim man was shot dead after an altercation at a military checkpoint. The man was interrogated and attempted to flee the checkpoint in a vehicle before being shot.

column7: Government of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: The ""Kororas"" youth group commissioned by the military to barricade Bangui burned and destroyed the house of a Muslim man suspected of affiliating with the rebels. Arbitrary attacks on Muslims are feared throughout the city.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Riots occurred the morning following the killing of a Muslim man suspected of rebel affiliation by police officers. Riots resulted in the death of one police officer.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column7: Government of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Arrests: 50 people have been ""arbitrarily arrested"" including 2 members of Parliament in Bangui. The arrests were conducted in a search for associates of rebels.

column7: Government of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: 120 troops from Gabon arrived in the morning in Bangui to join 120 Congolese troops sent the day previous. The forces will join peacekeeping troops of the CEEAC to oppose the rebellion threatening to overtake Bangui.
Four people died -- two rebels and two townspeople -- in clashes that broke out when villagers intercepted a group of rebels trying to loot a local sugar refinery.
Rebels damaged and removed equipment at several radio stations, including Radio Kaga in Kaga Bandoro.

column6: FOMUC: Multinational Force in the Central African Republic
column7: Government of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: The Ministry of the Interior accused rebels of taking two new towns preceding peace negotiations, during a supposed ceasefire. However, rebels argue that they sent a guard to resist incursion by the Ugandan army to the towns, but are not occupying these areas.

column6: FOMUC: Multinational Force in the Central African Republic
column7: Government of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: The Ministry of the Interior accused rebels of taking two new towns preceding peace negotiations, during a supposed ceasefire. However, rebels argue that they sent a guard to resist incursion by the Ugandan army to the towns, but are not occupying these areas.
Radio Magbadja, a radio station recently installed in Alindao by the staff of Radio France Internationale, was ransacked by members of the Seleka rebel coalition, who took all of its equipment.

South Africa begins sending 400 troops to assist the CAR defence force against rebels. Cameroon, Gabon and Republic of Congo already have sent about 120 troops each to help stabilize the country. President Zuma claims that the troops are a force to train the CAR army and assist in transition to the unity government.
The journalist Elisabeth Blanche Olofio, presenter at Radio Be Oko of Bambari, was killed by rebel forces occupying the town.
Looting: Reports of looting and harassment in Sibut.
Rebels took a civilian hostage in Kabo and demanded ransom.

UNICEF received reports of child recruitment from pro-government and rebel military forces. 2,500 children are already involved in CAR military. The rebellion has increased the practice of forcing children to fight, carry supplies, perform other support roles and serve as sex slaves for armed groups.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Deadly clashes were reported in areas under rebel control. Location unspecified.

Ugandan military forces killed a key bodyguard of Joseph Kony, an operative with a reputation for child abduction, in a clash with the LRA 280 kilometres north of the settlement of Djema in Eastern CAR.
Last week, several men from the Seleka group attacked a diamond mining zone at Dimbi in Kembe, carrying out ""looting"" and numerous ""murders"" according to the defence ministry.
Last week, Seleka rebels conducted raids in the Awakaba Park.

column9: ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross and Red Crescent
column17: An armed group attacked the headquarters of the Red Cross in Ndele. They stole a vehicle.
On 25 January, a group of armed elements suspected to belong to the Seleka coalition made a foray into the market of Satema. These elements seized gooods and individuals' personal property.

Looting: Seleka militia destroyed police posts and the town hall, and raided a church to steal motorcycles of the Catholic charity Caritas. Looting activities spark fears that Seleka is not respecting the peace pact signed this month in Gabon.
Seleka militia laid siege to the town of Satema and looted the town the following day.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Rebels released seven prisoners from the CAR military they had previously captured.
Seleka militia looted Satema.

column9: OCDH: Central African Observatory of Human Rights
column17: A member of OCDH was captured by Seleka because of the assistance he had given to civilians captured by them in the area. He was tortued, and escaped after five days.

On a joint UNHCR-Mercy Corps assessment mission to Bambari, a village chief reported being flogged on 3 February by rebels who were trying to get him to reveal where villagers were hiding their possessions. Looting has also taken place.
Property destruction: The Catholic church in Mobaye was ransacked, in an apparent escalation of conflict between religious communities (Christian and Muslim) in the region.
Shooting blamed on the Seleka Coalition rebels sparked a mass exodus of refugees fleeing CAR near Mobaye. Many buildings destroyed, including a doctors home where a health staff member was shot dead.
Seleka attack civilians and burn down their homes. This results in four deaths, eight seriously wounded civilians, and 211 burned houses.
Rebels in Central African Republic threatened on Monday to resume fighting, accusing President Francois Bozize of failing to honour a peace deal signed last month.

Seleka rebels abducted and tortured three security agents of the World Food Programme after publishing a report denouncing lootings by the rebels in Kaga Bandoro. 2 agents were abducted in Damara, the other one in Kaga Bandoro.

Seleka rebels looted a catholic church and properties in Kaga Bandoro, as well as assaulted at least four people in the area.

In Bambari, six Seleka gang rape a woman for three hours.

column8: Government of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Surrender/Defect:Seleka rebels in Sibut gave the CAR government a 72h ultimatum to fully implement the Libreville accords and advance towards the disarmament and demobilisation of their forces. Demands included the liberation of political prisoners, integration within the CAR forces, and the departure of south African troops on the territory. The CAR government issued two decrees three days later, which were judged insufficient by the rebels. The Seleka called for the removal of president Bozize.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: On the morning of March 21, 2013, Seleka troops have seized seized Seleka new towns in the centre-north of the country.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)

Bangui, Central African capital, was plagued by violence and looting following the Seleka coup.

Incidents in Berberati during a demonstration against the violent activities (looting, murder, etc.) of the Seleka. ""The Seleka was not in favor of the event, and they started shooting at people"".

Number of VAC events in Bangui by the Seleka militia on 14 April: in one incident, a Seleka soldier shot dead a man for not possessing a mobile phone and money; Seleka rebels also raped a woman at her home in Boy Rabe, and looted and assaulted another man at his house.

This gave rise to vigilante militias in villages of Paoua.
