column17: Seleka forces beat and abducted a member of the militaries gendarmerie as she was controlling vehicles at Boganda in Bangui. She was released soon after, following high-level negotiations.

Teachers at the University of Bangui held a March on Monday July 1, and issued a strike notice to the Prime Minister Nicolas Tiangaye. They are demanding the payment of three months salaries in arrears and the costs of vacations.

column9: Aid Workers (Central African Republic); Women (Central African Republic)
column17: ""One INGO staff member was beaten by Seleka members at a checkpoint.""
13 SANDF troops killed and 27 wounded in fighting at the weekend outside the capital, Bangui.

A man suspected of conniving with the deposed president, Francois Bozize, was taken into custody Saturday, July 6, by the elements of Seleka in the city of Nola. He was also suspected of being responsible for the vandalism of a buisnessmans house. The man was tortured.
A man in his thirties was abducted on the night of Sunday 7th July by members of the Seleka coalition at the Boeing headquarters in the town of Bimbo. His family does not know his whereabouts.
A mining craftsman died after torture by elements of Seleka last week in the village Beka Gazi Gomi about 160 kilometers from the city Boali. Looting and racketeering also reported.
The hospital in the town of Ndjoukou was robbed on July 9, by elements of the Seleka. The population also complained of racketeering on the part of these men.

A woman in her early thirties was killed at the end of last week by members of the Seleka in the city of Bouka. The armed men asked the victim to give them money. Not having the required amount, they shot her. Looting also reported.

Five bodies were found with their hands and feet tied in the Oubangui River in Bangui on July 16 and 17. Witnesses said the victims appeared to have been the missing passengers of a car that was stopped by Seleka rebels at a checkpoint in Bangui on July 13. Witnesses said rebels took the passengers away after finding T-shirts for ousted president Francois Bozize in the car.
Traders refused to pay money to Seleka soldiers who demanded it. The soldiers shot and killed two traders. retaliation.
Following a shooting by Seleka militants of traders who refused to pay them money, a third trader tackled one of the soldiers. Residents killed the soldier in retaliation.retaliation.
Report of killings, lootings and burnings of homes in Kouango and Ndkoukou by Seleka militia since took over power in the town in February, forcing dozens of people to flee.
Looting: Looting by Seleka in Nana Outa villages.

Around 15 July 2013, a mother of seven children, suspected of witchcraft, was beaten and held by members of the Seleka based in the city of Damara. The victim was accused of causing the death of the son of her co-wife.

Following the killing of a Seleka soldier the previous day, soldiers hunted down village residents who were hiding in the forest and killed as many as 200 people, including children. The soldiers also torched at least 10 houses in Badalao and looted many others.

In Paoua, elements of Seleka burned houses and engaged in physical assaults, extortion, looting, arbitrary arrest and torture. By end of September, six months after they established a base in Paoua, the Seleka were said to have killed 82 people, injured 107 and displaced more than 8,000. 70 cases of rape, 712 cases of houses burnt down, 3,700 victims of lootings and 1,630 cattle stolen. column9: Former Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Seleka fighters kidnapped an ex-government soldier and one of his brothers on July 16 in Fouh neighborhood of the capital. Their other brother was killed in the operation. The ex-soldier was found dead a few hours later, while his brother remained missing. On the same day, Seleka fighters also abducted and beat a couple, including a pregnant women, from Banguis 5th arrondissement - while the woman was released, her husband remains missing, and looted the home of another soldier in Kagamangoulou neighborhood.

A boy was killed on July 17, by members of the coalition Seleka in the town of Ouham-Bac, 45 kilometers from Bossangoa. Elements of Seleka opened fire on the village. A woman was also robbed of money by the gunmen.
Looting: Cases of looting were reported in the night of 17th July in the town of Bossangoa.
A man was tied up, tortured and robbed of his money by elements of Seleka. He was released later that day.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Three men from the same family were kidnapped on the night of 17 July. It was a policeman and his cadets. Their bodies were found on the 18th.

The population of the town of Nola was terrorized on July 18, by warning shots made by elements of Seleka. Some people in this town have taken refuge in the countryside, in order to avoid stray bullets.
Michel Djotodia signed a decree regarding the transitional constitutional charter.
Looting: Seleka fired shots and looted the town of Bouca. A a young boy drowned in the Fafa River as he tried to flee

""An INGO Country Director was wounded after being shot. Two unidentified men attacked him as he was parking his car, asking for the keys to the vehicle and, as he tried to escape, he was hit in the leg by a bullet.""
On July 19, Father Elisha Guendjade, Secretary General of Caritas Central, was shot in the leg by armed men.
The body of a taxi driver was found on July 20 in the city of Bangui by men in civilian clothing. They fled with the car.

A man was killed by a bullet in the head on July 23 in the city of Kaga-Bandoro, by elements of the Seleka. Inhabitants of this city have decided to stop all activities for three days in disapproval of this act.
Two suspected witches were beaten on July 24, by young people in the town of Lesset.
A young man was murdered on the night of July 25 in the city of Sosso Nakombo 60 kilometers from the city of Berberati by elements of Seleka. Reasons for the murder unknown.
Youth protested on July 26 against the arrest of the former chief of staff of ousted President Francois Bozize, by elements of the coalition Seleka. They barricaded the roads.
A farmer and his son were killed on July 26, in the village of Patcho, 23 kilometers from the city of Kaga-Bandoro (North Central). The murder was committed by members of the coalition Seleka.
A Seleka soldier threw a grenade into a crowd of women and children on the banks of the Oubangui river in Bangui. At least 15 women and several children sustained serious injuries.

Seleka soldiers severely beat four young men and hacked them with machetes. The soldiers accused them of being supporters of deposed President Bozize on the basis of their names which indicated that they came from the same Gbaya ethnic group as the former president. Three were killed and a fourth was severely injured.
A woman accused of witchcraft was killed on July 30 in Bamingui.
A pregnant woman refused advances made to her by a gunman. The elements of the Seleka asked her to pay a fine of 50,000 CFA francs. She could not afford it, so they shot and killed her
A man was murdered by Seleka armed men for unknown reasons.
During the previous week, a woman accused of witchcraft was abused by the people of Lesset.
A man and a woman accused of witchcraft was beaten on 1st August by villagers in Bossako.
A woman accused of witchcraft was beaten on 1st August in the village of Boude.
Cases of abuse and looting by Seleka are reported in the village of Zarami.

There has been violence in Ouhman-Bac, a rural village in the northwest, over the last two weeks. Killings have resulted in the dumping of between 30 and 50 bodies into the river. Other terrified residents fled the area. Seleka has been blamed for the attack, but deny the accusations.

column17: At least 11 people were killed and 35 injured in clashes that erupted when the new Central African Republic government tried to disarm supporters of ousted leader Francois Bozize, hospital sources said Wednesday.
Sustained gunfire and looting broke out overnight in the capital of the Central African Republic, causing many people to flee their homes.

There are reports of fresh tension in Bangui in the Central African Republic. Men of the ex-Seleka rebel army invaded again the Boy-Rabe District and have been carrying out house-to-house searches. The reason for the operation is not yet known. In any case, shootings have been reported but there are no casualty figures.
Two farmers from Ngaoundai City were killed on August 27th by members of Seleka. Two others were seriously injured .
Ongoing fighting in the capital forcess more than 5,000 people to seek refuge at the airport.

Ex-Seleka detained village chiefs, tying up with their hands and feet behind their backs in a painful method of torture. They demanded ransoms which the villagers paid. The chiefs were released and fled the village.
In the village of Bedengui, UNHCR staff found people mourning the kidnapping and murder of four family members.

A pregnant woman was kidnapped and raped on the night of 29 August by an armed man 11 kilometers from the town of Obo. The victim was released the next morning. The perpetrator was an officer in the Ugandan army, based in the area, as part of the fight against the LRA.

When Anti-Balaka members refused to return the body of an Mbororo cattle herder that they had killed to his family, ex-Seleka fighters attempted to get the body by force, but were ambushed by the Anti-Balaka. No casualties reported.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: The authorities attempt to regain control of police stations by calmly evacuating Seleka former rebels who had taken possession of the premises and reinstall police and gendarmerie.
Anti-Balaka members killed an Mbororo cattle herder in the village of Boubou.

column7: ONJC: National Organisation of the Youth of Central African Republic
column17: Between 2,000 and 3,000 youths gathered in Bangui to demand the restoration of security in the country. The protest was organised by the National Organisation of the Youth of the Central African Republic (ONJC).

A group of 17 Seleka militiamen attacked several villages around Markounda in Ouham: after stealing six motorbikes at Mbele village, they killed one person at Gale village, two at Copodochip, nine at Maitikoulou and an unknown number with rockets at Sangbi. They also stole cattle at Gbangoro, Bele and Gale villages. In Markounda, they ransacked a number of public properties including the Gendarmerie

A group of 17 Seleka militiamen attacked several villages around Markounda in Ouham: after stealing six motorbikes at Mbele village, they killed one person at Gale village, two at Copodochip, nine at Maitikoulou and an unknown number with rockets at Sangbi. They also stole cattle at Gbangoro, Bele and Gale villages. In Markounda, they ransacked a number of public properties including the Gendarmerie

A group of 17 Seleka militiamen attacked several villages around Markounda in Ouham: after stealing six motorbikes at Mbele village, they killed one person at Gale village, two at Copodochip, nine at Maitikoulou and an unknown number with rockets at Sangbi. They also stole cattle at Gbangoro, Bele and Gale villages. In Markounda, they ransacked a number of public properties including the Gendarmerie

A group of 17 Seleka militiamen attacked several villages around Markounda in Ouham: after stealing six motorbikes at Mbele village, they killed one person at Gale village, two at Copodochip, nine at Maitikoulou and an unknown number with rockets at Sangbi. They also stole cattle at Gbangoro, Bele and Gale villages. In Markounda, they ransacked a number of public properties including the Gendarmerie

A group of 17 Seleka militiamen attacked several villages around Markounda in Ouham: after stealing six motorbikes at Mbele village, they killed one person at Gale village, two at Copodochip, nine at Maitikoulou and an unknown number with rockets at Sangbi. They also stole cattle at Gbangoro, Bele and Gale villages. In Markounda, they ransacked a number of public properties including the Gendarmerie
Surrender/Defect:Voluntary disarmament campaign is launched in Bangui, targeting Seleka ex-rebels.
Heavily armed gunmen looted a home at Yakite neighborhood of Bangui, beating the residents.
A man was killed on September 6th in the village of Lioto by elements of the Seleka.
Anti-Balaka fighters attacked the ex-Seleka post in the town of Ouham-Bac, killing two ex-Seleka elements.
Anti-Balak supported by Bozize supporters, attacked a number of cattle camps guarded by Mbororos in Bossangoa on or around 6 September. Nearly 26 killed and thousands of cattle stolen.

Following the killing of two ex-Seleka in Zere, Anti-Balaka then attacked civilians. They looted and burned houses. 57 people were killed, including 17 Muslims, and the rest were Mbororo (Islamic pastoralists) killed in the bush with their cattle.
At least 13 civilians were killed when Anti-Balaka attacked the village of Bodora.
12 Mbororo family members guarding a cattle camp were killed by Anti-Balaka. 406 cattle missing.
In Zere, about 100 Anti-Balaka overpowered the ex-Seleka post, killing two ex-Seleka fighters and forcing the remaining three to flee.
Anti-Balaka fighters attacked Muslim homes, killing at least two.
Ex-Seleka forces, who were escorting a Muslim business man to his cattle camp near Bir Zambe, were ambushed by Anti-Balaka. The business man and two ex-Seleka fighters were killed.
Anti-Balaka attacked an Mbororo cattle camp, killing four.

Seleka forces clashed with Bozize supporters in Bossangoa on Saturday and Sunday, and in Bouca on Monday. Government estimates the death toll at 100, including civilians. The four villages around Bassongoa are under the control of the Bozize supporters. The army chief was fired following these events.

Seleka forces clashed with anti-Balaka supported by militiamen led by Bozize in Bossangoa on Saturday and Sunday, and in Bouca on Monday. Government estimates the death toll at more than 110, including civilians, dozens injured and hundreds of people forced to flee. The four villages around Bassongoa fell under the control of the Anti-Balaka. The army chief was fired following these events.

Seleka forces clashed with anti-Balaka supported by militiamen led by Bozize in Bossangoa on Saturday and Sunday, and in Bouca on Monday. Government estimates the death toll at more than 110, including civilians, dozens injured and hundreds of people forced to flee. The four villages around Bassongoa fell under the control of the Anti-Balaka. The army chief was fired following these events.

Seleka forces clashed with anti-Balaka supported by militiamen led by Bozize in Bossangoa on Saturday and Sunday, and in Bouca on Monday. Government estimates the death toll at more than 110, including civilians, dozens injured and hundreds of people forced to flee. The four villages around Bassongoa fell under the control of the Anti-Balaka. The army chief was fired following these events.
Anti-Balaka forces kill two aid workers employed by the ACTED organisation. It is claimed that they were mistaken for informers.
Anti-Balaka fighters attacked Mbororo cattle camps in Bossangoa, leaving three killed and stealing dozens of cattle.
""During an evacuation, two national staffers of an INGO were killed in transit while returning to base from a construction site in the area of Bossangoa.""
In Bouca, Bozize supporters set fire to Muslim homes.
Mbororo cattle camp raided by Anti-Balaka. One Mbororo cattle herded killed.

Seleka forces clashed with anti-Balaka supported by militiamen led by Bozize in Bossangoa on Saturday and Sunday, and in Bouca on Monday. Government estimates the death toll at more than 110, including civilians, dozens injured and hundreds of people forced to flee. The four villages around Bassongoa fell under the control of the Anti-Balaka. The army chief was fired following these events.

Seleka forces clashed with anti-Balaka supported by militiamen led by Bozize in Bossangoa on Saturday and Sunday, and in Bouca on Monday. Government estimates the death toll at more than 110, including civilians, dozens injured and hundreds of people forced to flee. The four villages around Bassongoa fell under the control of the Anti-Balaka. The army chief was fired following these events.

Seleka forces clashed with anti-Balaka supported by militiamen led by Bozize in Bossangoa on Saturday and Sunday, and in Bouca on Monday. Government estimates the death toll at more than 110, including civilians, dozens injured and hundreds of people forced to flee. The four villages around Bassongoa fell under the control of the Anti-Balaka. The army chief was fired following these events.

Seleka forces clashed with Bozize supporters in Bossangoa on Saturday and Sunday, and in Bouca on Monday. Government estimates the death toll at 100, including civilians. The four villages around Bassongoa are under the control of the Bozize supporters. The army chief was fired following these events.

Seleka forces clashed with anti-Balaka supported by militiamen led by Bozize in Bossangoa on Saturday and Sunday, and in Bouca on Monday. Government estimates the death toll at more than 110, including civilians, dozens injured and hundreds of people forced to flee. In Bouca, at least 40 were killed, including civilians who were targeted in lootings and burnings of their homes.

Seleka forces clashed with anti-Balaka supported by militiamen led by Bozize in Bossangoa on Saturday and Sunday, and in Bouca on Monday. Government estimates the death toll at more than 110, including civilians, dozens injured and hundreds of people forced to flee. In Bouca, at least 40 were killed, including civilians who were targeted in lootings and burnings of their homes.
A drivers assistant was killed at Bossangoa bus station after he refused to give fuel to ex-Seleka members.
A woman was killed on the night of September 10th in the town of Sam-Ouandja by an element of Seleka. Four other people were injured.
Over 100 Anti-Balaka fighters attacked Muslim villagers in Gbakora and Bandorok, killing 11 Muslims, including three Mbororo nomads.
Over 100 Anti-Balaka fighters attacked Muslim villagers in Gbakora and Bandorok, killing 11 Muslims, including three Mbororo nomads.
Members of 12 NGOs staged a march to denounce violence targeting them in the country, following the killing of 2 humanitarian staff during the recent Bossangoa clashes.
Sporadic gunfire by elements of Seleka on the evenings od 12 and 13 September. Some civilians fled into the bush.
An inter-community clash in the town of Batangafo resulted in six people sustaining knife injuries.
The bodies of a man and woman were found. Elements of Seleka are believed to be involved in the deaths.

column6: UFDR: Union of Democratic Forces for Unity
column17: President Michel Djotodia announced the dissolution of the Seleka rebel alliance.
Sporadic gunfire by elements of Seleka on the evenings od 12 and 13 September. Some civilians fled into the bush.
A trader en route to Bossangoa market was stopped by ex-Seleka who accused him of being Anti-Balaka. He has been missing since and is presumed to have been killed by the ex-Seleka.

At least 100 people have been killed in the areas of Bossangoa and Bossembele between Saturday 14th and Tuesday 17th Sept. in clashes between Seleka and self-defence groups who have called themselves Anti-Balaka.
The village chief of Bokayanga was kidnapped by Seleka elements, who accused him of harboring a brother of the leader of the rebel Democratic Front for the Central African people.

At least 100 people have been killed in the areas of Bossangoa and Bossembele between Saturday 14th and Tuesday 17th Sept. in clashes between Seleka and self-defence groups who have called themselves Anti-Balaka.
A group of Seleka elements opened fire on a group of people in Kabo, killing one man.

At least 100 people have been killed in the areas of Bossangoa and Bossembele between Saturday 14th and Tuesday 17th Sept. in clashes between Seleka and self-defence groups who have called themselves Anti-Balaka.

At least 100 people have been killed in the areas of Bossangoa and Bossembele between Saturday 14th and Tuesday 17th Sept. in clashes between Seleka and self-defence groups who have called themselves Anti-Balaka.
Ex-Seleka fighters opened fire on a family at the Ouham River, Bossangoa. They killed the husband and injured the baby.
Three young people were kidnapped and tortured by elements of Seleka. They were later released.
A man was killed by elements of Seleka on suspiscion of hiding military equipment.
Elements of Seleka kidnapped 6 people, one of which is a member of the Central African Armed Forces. They also beat their parents.

At least 100 people have been killed in the areas of Bossangoa and Bossembele between Saturday 14th and Tuesday 17th Sept. in clashes between Seleka and self-defence groups who have called themselves Anti-Balaka.
A priest, Father Aurelio, approached elements of Seleka to discuss the possibility of release of an arrestee who was unwell. The priest was threatened and slapped.

At least 100 people have been killed in the areas of Bossangoa and Bossembele between Saturday 14th and Tuesday 17th Sept. in clashes between Seleka and self-defence groups who have called themselves Anti-Balaka.
Two vehicles carrying pharmaceuticals and kits belonging to the NGO ACTED were ambushed by an armed gang of Fulani herdsmen. Those aboard the vehicles were captured and later released.

At least 100 people have been killed in the areas of Bossangoa and Bossembele between Saturday 14th and Tuesday 17th Sept. in clashes between Seleka and self-defence groups who have called themselves Anti-Balaka.

At least 100 people have been killed in the areas of Bossangoa and Bossembele between Saturday 14th and Tuesday 17th Sept. in clashes between Seleka and self-defence groups who have called themselves Anti-Balaka.
A man was tortured and killed by elements of Seleka.
Four people kidnapped by the LRA in Kotto2, a town 30 kilometers from the town of Sam-Ouandja . Looting also reported.
Two grenades were discovered at the cathedral of Bossangoa. No casualties.
Elements of Seleka killed a farmer in Lingoto when he could not provide them with 5,000,000 francs as they demanded.
Two men were killed and another injured on September 20 in Herba by members of the former Seleka. 206 houses were also burned by the gunmen and cases of looting were reported.
Having taken refuge in the bush, two men came out to look for food. They were shot and killed by elements of Seleka.
A man was killed by a Seleka patrol as he attempted to return to his house.

An element of Seleka demanded a man give him 100,000 FCFA. When he could not pay, he was killed. Other elements of Seleka were then ordered to kill this gunman to serve as an example of what can happen if atrocities are committed against the population.
A thief was killed by elements of Seleka to deter others from doing the same.

Anti-Balaka of the Gbaya tribe attacked Muslims and people of the Mbororo ethnicity (due to their Islamic beliefs) in the village of Votovo. 4 Muslim men killed and 21 Muslim women and children missing.
Looting: Gunmen fired shots and held people as they looted a church in Bouar.
Seleka soldiers stopped two Christian brothers travelling on a motorbike and executed them.

Three men were arrested by elements of the former Seleka in Bozoum on the false suspicion of being involved in a motorbike theft. They were tied up and tortured. They were finally released on Sunday, October 6 after the payment of a ransom by their families

column8: AU RCI-LRA: African Union Regional Cooperation Inititiative for the Elimination of the Lords Resistance Army Joint Task Force (2011-)
column17: At least eight rebel fighters of the Lords Resistance Army (LRA) have been killed in an offensive by the African Union in the last week in CAR and DRC.
In late September or early October, ex-Seleka forces arrived in the village of Bogouna, firing into the air to force the villagers to flee, andburning the homes in the village. One body found.
A motorcycle taxi driver who refused to pay a fee set by the former Seleka at a road barrier was tortured and killed.
Two people were killed and several others injured on Tuesday 1st October in Bangui-Bouchia village. The gunmen remain unidentified.

Christians marched in the morning of Tuesday, October 1, to protest against the atrocities committed by elements of the former Seleka. Barriers were erected to prevent the movement of Muslims. Muslim traders also erected road barricades. 10 deaths reported.
Execution by armed men of eight people who were separated from a larger group as they fled by truck [Followed up with wider search; no further references found].
Targeted killing of two men in a village [Followed up with wider search; no further references found].
Seleka members who burgled the house of a public official were attacked and beaten by the local population.
Three women were killed and a man kidnapped on the night of Wednesday 2 October at Maliko neighborhood in the city of Bangassou by elements of the former Seleka.
An armed group of Christians civilians selected eight Muslims from among many other passengers travelling to Bangui from Bossangoa and shot them dead.
Youth in Bangassou protested against violence by Seleka forces in the town, destroying the home of a Muslim in Tchaka neighborhood.
Clashes between elements of the former coalition Seleka and youths in Bangassou resulted in the killing of four people, all of whom were from the Christian community.
Unidentified gunman attack the village of Sabe, including attacks against Christians and Muslims.

On Monday 7th in Gaga, ""Anti-Balaka"" youth vigilante group attacked the position of men in the former Seleka, killing 3. The former rebels responded, killing several in the Christian community. Clashes continued to the next day, with the Anti-Balaka killing also members of the Muslim community. Death toll of at least 52.
Ex-Seleka fighters went house-to-house through the Bonjili district of Bossangoa, killing and burning. At least three dead.

On Monday 7th in Gaga, ""Anti-Balaka"" youth vigilante group attacked the position of men in the former Seleka, killing 3. The former rebels responded, killing several in the Christian community. Clashes continued to the next day, with the Anti-Balaka killing also members of the Muslim community. Death toll of at least 52.
The population of the prefecture in Gazi, in Membere-Kadei, marched through the area for peace and stability in the Central African Republic.

column9: Students (Central African Republic); Health Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: Ex-Seleka fighters, driving towards Ouham-Bac, shot at civilians in Wikamo village, killing five. They then looted the local hospital and school, and burned the entire village.
Seleka on motorbikes attacked Ndjoukou, arbitrarily killing two fishermen and burning 16 homes.
A clash occurred between an Anti-Balaka vigilante group and elements of the former Seleka. Several deaths have been reported and houses were burned.
Two farmers were arrested and tortured by elements of Seleka on suspicion of being involed with Anti-Balaka. They were later released on 12th October.
Ex-Seleka arrived in Ouham-Bac and opened fire on civilians. 12 people died: 9 were shot by ex-Seleka and three drowned in the river as they escaped in panic.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Clashes broke out on Friday between government security forces and the Anti-Balaka vigilante group, resulting in the deaths of six Anti-Balaka members.
On October 12, two elements of the former coalition Seleka were killed by unidentified gunmen.
Eight people were killed and hundreds of burned houses on October 13 by a group of armed Mbororo Fulani people.
A man was tortured and killed by elements of Seleka in the village of Tatale.
A young man was abducted by elements of Seleka.
Two elderly people were killed Friday, Oct. 18, by a group of youths in Bolemba village who suspected them of witchcraft.
A man was shot and killed by an element of the former coalition Seleka, as he suspected him of flirting with his girlfriend.
The LRA attacked and raided the camp of hunters.
Four people were killed and one injured in an attack by unknown armed persons at a camp of livestock breeders.
Four people were attacked by Fulani herdsmen and their possessions were stolen.
A group of armed Muslim cattle herders moving their cows through a field shot the village chief of Tamkouru who was present in the field.
Ex-Seleka opened fire on a group of people working in a field. Three killed.

A farmer was beaten by elements of Seleka on suspicion of selling ammunition. Afterwards, the victim complained to Colonel Ibrahim, who then commanded his troops to beat the farmer, and demanded a ransom to be paid before he could be released.

Anti-Balaka vigilantes attacked Bouar on Saturday morning. They surrounded the city and were confronted by elements of ex-Seleka. 12 people died: 7 from the vigilante groups and 5 from the ranks of former Seleka members. A number of NGOs evacuated the town three days later.
A driver of an ambulance carrying a patient and medication from Mbaiki to Bangui was beaten and imprisoned by an element of ex-Seleka. He also stole 32,000 FCFA from the driver.
A village chief was beaten on October 27, by one of the elements of the former coalition Seleka based in Boganangone.
Residents of Castors set up roadblocks, burned tyres and blocked traffic during the morning to protest against the acts of robbery and persistent insecurity in the area.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka in Mbourouba. Several dead.
An officer of the former Seleka killed four young people in Bossembele on suspicion of their involvement with Anti-Balaka groups.
Elements of Seleka burned about 100 homes in the villages of Vacap and Yongoro. Casualties unknown.
Elements of Seleka burned about 100 homes in the villages of Vacap and Yongoro. Casualties unknown.
A man was attacked by a drunken element of ex-Seleka on suspicion of being involved with Anti-Balaka groups.
A head of Seleka was constructing a house in Bazanga. Local residents complained that it was blocking an alleyway. Seleka attacked those who complained. More than 10 injured.

A man was arrested on November 1st and held at the basis of the former Seleka in the town of Kabo. The victim was suspected of having collaborated with the members of the gendarmerie who were working in that area at the time of former President Francois Bozize.
Clashes between youths and ex-Seleka resulted in the death of an ex-Seleka member.
A man was murdered by gunmen from the former rebel Seleka coalition in Baoro on suspicion of collaboration with Anti-Balaka groups.
Four men were shot dead on November 2 in Ngoroungou village by elements of the former Seleka, who believed them to be part of an Anti-Balaka group.
Seven people killed in an attack in Bossembele.
A man, on suspicion of killing another man, was murdered by elements of ex-Seleka.
Former Seleka rebel groups exchange gunfire at a road block. Casualties unknown.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014) National Security Company
column17: Two young men were abducted on November 3rd by elements of the national security company (CNS) for unknown reasons.
Three people were abducted by elements of the former coalition Seleka on Sunday evening.
Two men were robbed and beaten by elements of Seleka on the way to the market in Bata.

column8: FOMUC: Multinational Force in the Central African Republic
column17: A Congolese FOMUC policeman was shot and injured by unknown perpetrators.
Some workers in Tamboula were abducted by members of the Lords Resistance Army (LRA) of Joseph Kony on November 4th.
Two NGO vehicles were held up by three unidentified armed men.

More than two dozen young people from the city of Boganongone were arrested and tortured on November 5th by elements of the former coalition Seleka, on suspicion of belonging an Anti-Balaka group. They were released the following weekend following the payment of ransoms by their families to Seleka.

Shooting broke out in PK12 when Central African Seleka fighters guarding a road block refused to let Chadian Seleka fighters pass. One death (Chadian) and two injuries. This follows an exhange of gunfire near the same road block the previous Sunday.

The heads of districts and villages in the town of Boganangone protested at the base of the former Seleka based in the town against the fact that of over 20 youths were arbitrarily arrested and tortured the previous Tuesday.

column9: Christian Group (Central African Republic); Women (Central African Republic); Health Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: The head of a Catholic health center in Bagandou was the victim of an attempted rape on November 6th by elements of the former Seleka. Her colleagues intervened.
Shooting continued throughout the morning in PK12 between two groups of Seleka fighters. Casualties unknown.
Heads of villages and neighbourhoods of Boganongone marched to the Seleka base in continuing protest against the arbitrary arrest of 20 young people, by elements of the former Seleka.

""An INGO-contracted driver, while driving from a program site to a hotel parking lot, was shot and killed by most likely ex-Seleka soldiers. There may have been an ethnic/religious component to the attack.""
A five year old girl was raped by ex-Seleka elements in Sarambigazo on November 7th.
The LRA attacked the village of Derbisaka, causing hundreds of people to flee. No casualties reported.
Nine youths were arrested by elements of the former Seleka on suspicion of being in collusion with Anti-Balaka groups.
A five year old girl was raped by ex-Seleka elements in Baleko on November 8th.
Shots were heard fired by elements of the former Seleka in Nola. This follows a message sent by Anti-Balaka asking the Christian population to leave Nola because an attack is coming.

Following the march of the previous day, residents of Boganongone decided to suspend all activities on Friday 8th November in protest against the arbitrary arrest of 20 young people, by elements of the former Seleka.
Seven hunters were kidnapped and robbed of all their hunting equipment before being released on 12th November by members of the Lords Resistance Army (LRA).
Elements of the former Seleka broke into the house of one of the employees of Caritas in Bozoum, demanded a payment of money, and hit his wife.
Many inhabitants of Bouca fled to hide in the bush after sporadic shooting by members of the former coalition Seleka was heard on November 10th.

column8: Former Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014) Presidential Security Unit
column17: A former presidential guard of former president Francois Bozize was killed Sunday, November 10, by a member of the former Seleka following a dispute. Several others wounded and a member of the Central African Armed Forces (FACA) was abducted by ex-Seleka following the killing.

column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka in Camp Bangui. The military also intervened to ""fight the anti-balaka"". Homes were pillaged and up to 300 houses burned. Bodies of 3 civilians found.

column8: FOMUC: Multinational Force in the Central African Republic
column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014) Gendarmerie
column17: Following the killing of a former member of the Bozizes presidential guard and the kidnapping of a member of the Central African Armed Forces (FACA), residents of Miskine took to the streets, erected barricades and burned tyres. The Multinational Force of Central Africa (FOMA) and the National Gendarmerie dispersed the crowd by firing tear gas, causing two serious injuries.
A French national was traveling in Bangui when two armed men tried to steal his car. He refused to comply and his attackers then shot him, wounding him in the back and chest.
Four young men from Bagandou were beaten on the 11th and 12th November by members of the former coalition Seleka.
Two people, including a pregnant woman, were killed with a grenade during a robbery by elements of the former Seleka coalition.

column8: FOMUC: Multinational Force in the Central African Republic
column9: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Following the killing of two people during a robbery by elements of the former Seleka coalition, residents of Camp des Castors took to the streets and burned tyres to protest against this. Gunfire was heard. The demonstrators were dispersed by the Central African Multinational Force (FOMA) and law enforcement.
Elements of the former coalition Seleka attacked a funeral gathering and injured three men with gunshot wounds.
A motorcycle taxi driver was stabbed and his money and motorcycle stolen by an element of the former Seleka.
Four young men from Bagandou were beaten on the 11th and 12th November by members of the former coalition Seleka.

column8: FOMUC: Multinational Force in the Central African Republic
column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014) Gendarmerie
column17: Following the clashes between residents of Bangui and Seleka, FOMAC tried to intervene. They were targeted by ex-Seleka and had to retreat as they came under fire from Seleka and were small in number.

column8: UFDR: Union of Democratic Forces for Unity
column17: Following the kidnapping of a young man by elements of the former Seleka under the false allegation of possession of an automatic weapon, inhabitants of Bangui took to the street, erected barricades and burned tyres in protest. Michel Djotodia was making a ceremonial progression through Bangui, and he had stones thrown at them by the protesters. Seleka elements cintervened to disperse the demonstration, leaving 3 dead, including two members of Seleka.
A young man was kidnapped and tortured by elements of the former Seleka under the false allegation of possession of an automatic weapon.

column6: FOMUC: Multinational Force in the Central African Republic
column17: A young couple was attacked by a Chadian member of the Multinational Force of Central Africa. He robbed them and attempted to rape the woman, who was pregnant.

column8: FOMUC: Multinational Force in the Central African Republic
column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014) Gendarmerie
column17: An element of the Central African Armed Forces was murdered on the night of Friday 15th in Bangui by armed men belonging to the former Seleka in unknown circumstances.

A young man was shot dead by members of the former coalition Seleka, on the night of Friday 15th November. They broke into his home and asked him directions to the house of a member of the Central African Armed Forces. When he did not know, they shot him.
Three elements of Ugandan forces based in Obo in the fight against the LRA were injured by unidentified assailants near their military base.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Ex-Seleka members who assassinated a judge were arrested by security forces. They resisted by opening fire on security agents at the time of their arrest. Three of the criminals were shot dead.
A senior judge, Modeste Bria, and his bodyguard were assassinated by elements of the former Seleka.

column9: FOMUC: Multinational Force in the Central African Republic; Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014) Gendarmerie
column17: The assassination of a judge caused anger among inhabitants of Bangui who took to the streets, erecting barricades and burning tyres. There was an intervention of the elements of the Multinational Force of Central Africa (FOMA) and the National Gendarmerie, but the demonstrators could not be dispersed. Clashes between these protesters and men of the former Seleka, who shot at close range. Two civilians killed.
A member of ex-Seleka opened fire in the city, creating panic among the population after he was accused by young people of having killed a member of the Central African Armed Forces.
Ex-Seleka attempted to drown seven farmers who were wrongfully accused of being Anti-Balaka. Four drowned.
Clashes erupted on Monday and Tuesday between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka after elements of the former Seleka went attacked the base of Anti-Balaka, 10km from the city of Bouca. Two civilians killed.
Clashes erupted on Monday and Tuesday between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka after elements of the former Seleka went attacked the base of Anti-Balaka, 10km from the city of Bouca. Two civilians killed.
LRA rebels attacked inhabitants near the city of Mboki, causing several casualties.

Over 100 Central African magistrates marched in Bangui to honor the memory of their colleague, Modeste Martineau Bria, ex-Director of Judicial Services of the Ministry of Justice, who was killed on November 16 with his bodyguard, by elements of the ex-Seleka. They are calling for a thorough investigation
The principal of Orongou school was arrested and held for five days by elements of the former Seleka on suspicion of having correspondence with Anti-Balaka groups.
A young man was kidnapped by member of the former Seleka because they believed his father to be associated with Anti-Balaka. His whereabouts are unknown.
LRA rebels attacked inhabitants of a village near Mboki, kidnapping three civilians. They were released on November 25th.

To mark the international day of ending violence against women, several women from different communities met at the headquarters of the National Transitional Council (CNT) and held a silent protest. They taped their mouth closed with white tape to show their displeasure with the cruel and inhuman treatment that they often experience in CAR.
A young motorcycle taxi driver was killed by elements of the former Seleka.
Five people, including two women, were killed on November 26th in Nzenga by armed Mbororo herders.
As two elements of the former coalition Seleka fought, a civilian tried to intervene and calm the situation. The ex-Seleka members pursued him and beat him.
Reports of heavy fighting between the Anti-Balaka and former Seleka in Gbagbo on the 28th and 29th of November. 12 reported dead from fighting on the 28th.
Members of former Seleka attacked and burned three homes. No casualties reported.

column8: AU RCI-LRA: African Union Regional Cooperation Inititiative for the Elimination of the Lords Resistance Army Joint Task Force (2011-)
column17: The Regional Cooperation Initiative for the Elimination of the LRA destroyed one of the LRAs key camps located in the CAR. [Wider search conducted, no further information found on location; likely in Haut-Mbomou.

column8: AU RCI-LRA: African Union Regional Cooperation Inititiative for the Elimination of the Lords Resistance Army Joint Task Force (2011-)
column17: 14 rebels killed in a clash between LRA rebels and the joint task force. One hostage freed.
Reports of heavy fighting between the Anti-Balaka and former Seleka in Gbagbo on the 28th and 29th of November. 4 ex-Seleka members reported dead from fighting on the 29th.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: 200 French soldiers and more than 500 Congolese soldiers arrived in Bangui on the night of Sunday as part of the MISCA support mission.
Two IDPs from Eglise Saint Paul were killed by ex-Seleka .
A dozen people were abducted on December 3rd by elements of the Lords Resistance Army (LRA) in the village of Yangoukaga.

column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; RCA (Central African Republic)
column17: 12 ethnic Peul (Fulani) pastoralists died on Monday, a dozen others seriously injured and houses burned by suspected Anti-Balaka who attacked the camp of the Fulani pastoralists around 30km from the town.
Seleka forces attacked Boali town and its surroundings in retaliation for the killing of ethnic Peuls the day before by anti-Balaka elements. At least six people were killed.
A pick-up truck of armed men, believed to be ex-Seleka, opened fire three times in the direction of civilians and French troops. French troops retaliated, killing 4 armed men.
400 additional French soldiers in place in the Central African Republic as part of Operation Sangaris.

column7: Former Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Anti-Balaka, accompanied by ex-FACA, coordinated attacks in PK12, Kasai and the Boy Rabe neighbourhood in Bangui, sparking clashes with ex-Seleka. Fighting then spread across Bangui, resulting in the deaths of at least 394 people between the 5th and 7th of December.
Seleka troops force their way into a home, where they beat the husband, raped the wife, and stole everything from the house. Another two Seleka troops raped a 16 year old girl in Camp Castors.
Clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka. 13 people killed by Anti-Balaka, including civilians.

column9: Christian Group (Central African Republic); Health Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: Summary executions occurred at Hopital de l'Amitie in Bangui, carried out by armed men inside the hospital. The medical teams saw a dozen corpses lying in front of the hospital.
""One off-duty INGO national staff member was shot and killed by armed intruders at his home. The attack seems to have been religiously motivated.""
Anti-Balaka forces in Bangui went door to door and killed approximately 60 Muslim men.
Operation Sangaris, the military intervention of France in the Central African Republic, began. The French forces began patrols.

column7: Former Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Anti-Balaka, accompanied by ex-FACA, coordinated attacks in PK12, Kasai and the Boy Rabe neighbourhood in Bangui, sparking clashes with ex-Seleka. Fighting then spread across Bangui, resulting in the deaths of at least 394 people between the 5th and 7th of December.
Anti-Balaka attack ex-Seleka in Bozoum, resulting in 38 deaths.

Seleka commander Colonel Saleh and his men fired several rocket-propelled grenades into the crowded camp at a Catholic church and repeatedly threatened to attack it unless the anti-balaka left Bossangoa. African peacekeepers negotiated an end to the crisis and got the anti-balaka to stand down.
Surrender/Defect:Nineteen members of the Lords Resistance Army have surrendered to Ugandan forces in the Central African Republic
Seleka militia kills six men in Miskine, blocks access on the roads and continues to loot property in a number of neighborhoods of the capital.
A further 600 French soldiers in place in the Central African Republic as part of Operation Sangaris. Total of 1,600 soldiers in place in CAR.

column7: Former Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Anti-Balaka, accompanied by ex-FACA, coordinated attacks in PK12, Kasai and the Boy Rabe neighbourhood in Bangui, sparking clashes with ex-Seleka. Fighting then spread across Bangui, resulting in the deaths of at least 394 people between the 5th and 7th of December.
French patrol responded after being fired at by ex-Seleka. No casualties reported.
A brief exchange of fire broke out between French forces and Seleka, however no casualties reported.
Firefighting erupted between ex-Seleka gunmen and French soldiers near Bangui-Mpoko international airport. Two French soldiers killed.

column7: Christian Group (Central African Republic); Vigilante Group (Central African Republic)
column17: 9 December 2013, a mob of Christian youths attacked and looted from Muslim civilians in Bangui. ""Several"" Muslims were killed, coded as 10. A combatant of the ex-Seleka rebel movement was lynched and pelted to death with stones by a crowd. French forces intervened killing 3. A Christian man was carrying two grenades was attacked by a group of Muslims who turned him over to the French forces.
Surrender/Defect:French troops begin the disarmament process in Bangui.
A group raided, looted and burned a mosque in Bangui, tearing the sheets, tearing down the walls and yelling out against Muslims.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: A mob of Christians looted Muslim-owned shops with machetes. Chadian MISCA forces fired shots to attempt to disperse the crowd.
27 people, mostly Muslims, were killed on December 10th in the town of Bohong by Anti-Balaka militia. Several houses belonging to this community were burned.

The former chief of staff for operations of the former rebel coalition Seleka, General Mahamat Saleh, and two of his bodyguards were killed during an operation by the French army on Tuesday in Miskine neighbourhood, Bangui. The men apparently fired weapons at civilians
Elements of ex-Seleka beat up a woman in her own home as they wanted to know the whereabouts of her husband.
From December 11th to 18th, the LRA attacked villages around Ouada-Maikaga. Several people were killed, 11 others were abducted, and houses were burned.
Arrest and execution of a man by ex-Seleka.
Following the revenge attack on ex-Seleka by men of Loh, ex-Seleka and Muslim civilians attacked the Christian population in Loh.

Following the arrest and execution of a man by ex-Seleka, a group of men from Loh village launched a revenge attack against ex-Seleka, resulting in the death of at least 25 ex-Seleka and Muslim civilians and 33 injured.
A man on a motorbike was killed with machetes by Muslims as he was on his way to buy chickens. This was a revenge attack following the killing of six Muslims the same day.
From December 11th to 18th, the LRA attacked villages around Ouada-Maikaga. Several people were killed, 11 others were abducted, and houses were burned.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column9: Civilians (Central African Republic); Muslim Group (Central African Republic)
column17: African peacekeepers fired into the air to try to disperse a mob bent on hunting down and killing Muslims taking refuge in a church compound. Young men threw rocks and tried to break into the church compound. The mob hurled rocks at the peacekeepers and their vehicles and only dispersed after shots were fired.

Six Muslims, including a 7 year old child, were murdered by Christians in the predominantly Muslim district of PK-5 in Bangui. A Cameroonian man, his wife and two children were also burned dead. It was a revenge attack by Christians of CAR who accuse Muslims of being associated with the abuses of former Seleka rebels.
From December 11th to 18th, the LRA attacked villages around Ouada-Maikaga. Several people were killed, 11 others were abducted, and houses were burned.
UN sources report that eight Christian and Muslim civilians were killed in Bangui.

Three men from the same family were kidnapped by Anti-Balaka. Anti-Balaka members said they thought these men were Muslims, however they were informed that they were in fact Christians. They asked for money to release them, allegedly received around US$250 from the family, but did not release the men. The family home was later destroyed by Anti-Balaka and their supporters.
The body of a man was found in Mbali River following torture by elements of ex-Seleka.
From December 11th to 18th, the LRA attacked villages around Ouada-Maikaga. Several people were killed, 11 others were abducted, and houses were burned.
A Cameroonian national was murdered by an unidentified gunman on the outskirts of Bangui airport as he and his family were attempting to be repatriated to Cameroon.
An elderly woman was killed and three others abducted by elements of the former Seleka, under the pretext of avenging the theft of a bike by Anti-Balaka militia.
From December 11th to 18th, the LRA attacked villages around Ouada-Maikaga. Several people were killed, 11 others were abducted, and houses were burned.
In a sectarian attack, a mob attacked and killed a Chadian Muslim man, looted his shop, and then attacked his house.
Civilian received injuries following an attack by ex-Seleka.
Two Chadian students were beheaded by Anti-Balaka when they went out to get food.
In a sectarian attack, several Chadian students were stoned or hacked to death by Central Africans.

column9: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Two men from the village of Bobo were aboard a motorbike on the road to Berberati when they were attacked by a member of the former Seleka. Police authorities intervened and arrested the latter.
Ex-Seleka members attacked a journalist of Radio ICDI at his home. He managed to escape, but his house was looted. Following this and other death threats, Radio ICDI has suspended its broadcasts.
The Lords Resistance Army (LRA) shot in the air and abducted 37 people on the night of December 16th in the village of Kotto 3, 25 kilometers from the town of Sam Ouandja.
From December 11th to 18th, the LRA attacked villages around Ouada-Maikaga. Several people were killed, 11 others were abducted, and houses were burned.
A group of 10 women were killed by armed Muslim Peuls (Mbororos).

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: More than 600 Burundian MISCA troops arrived in Bangui.
From December 11th to 18th, the LRA attacked villages around Ouada-Maikaga. Several people were killed, 11 others were abducted, and houses were burned.
Twelve women were stopped by ex-Seleka rebels and killed.
From December 11th to 18th, the LRA attacked villages around Ouada-Maikaga. Several people were killed, 11 others were abducted, and houses were burned.

A mass grave was discovered on a hill in Bangui containing the bodies of at least 30 men dressed in civilian clothing. The mass grave was discovered on 22nd December, and the bodies were believed to be dead for 3-5 days before this.
A march for peace and forgiveness was held in Bangui on the 19th and 20th December, involving all 8 districts of Bangui, to try to reconcile Muslims and Christians.
A 13 year old girl was kidnapped, raped and released for a ransom by Anti-Balaka.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column8: MICOPAX: Mission for the Consolidation of Peace in Central African Republic (2008-2013)
column17: MISCA officialy replaces MICOPAX at a ceremony in Bangui Mpoko airport.

column9: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Clashes occurred between Anti-Balaka and former Seleka. The former Seleka rebels were disguised as police officers and gendarmes, and were accompanied by Chadian soldiers of MISCA. Anti-Balaka militiamen ambushed a Chadian patrol, killing one officer and wounding several soldiers. 33 deaths, including civilians.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Following the incident of 19th December, residents of the northern districts of Bangui mobilised and protested at the base of the Chadian soldiers of MISCA to demand the departure of the soldiers accused of supporting former Seleka rebels who disguised themselves as policemen and gendarmes in attacks that resulted in many civilian deaths. Demonstrators dispersed by members of the police and gendarmerie.

column6: Former Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Shooting broke out in Gbaya Dombia, an area of Muslim majority. Residents accuse ex-FACA and Anti-Balakas of being the attackers. No casualties reported for this day.
Members of ex-Seleka were attacked and kidnapped by Anti-Balaka who indulged in acts of vandalism and looting, causing many deaths and serious injuries.
A mob attacked and destroyed a vehicle of French journalists as they traveled through a mostly Muslim neighborhood in Bangui.
Ex-Seleka opened fire at the Saint Jacques monastery in Bangui, where approximately 20,000 IDPs had sought shelter, killing at least 27.
A march for peace and forgiveness was held in Bangui on the 19th and 20th December, involving all 8 districts of Bangui, to try to reconcile Muslims and Christians.

Idriss Fall, a correspondent for VOAs French-to-Africa Service, says a mob attacked his vehicle Friday with machetes, guns and stones as he traveled through a mostly Christian neighborhood in Bangui. He, his driver and a local assistant escaped unharmed as French soldiers contained the mob.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: A Chadian solider of MISCA was killed by Anti-Balaka in Bossangoa.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Small demonstration against French and MISCA disarmament process. Demonstrators burned tyres and set up road blocks. Congolese soldiers fired shots in the air and used tear gas to disperse protesters.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Two Anti-Balaka leaders that had been detained by MISCA were tied up and tortured for hours, resulting in their deaths. MISCA maintains that the prisoners were injured when they were detained, and that they had tried to take them to hospital.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Thousands of pro-Seleka Muslims protest against the French army in Bangui. This follows the death of three ex-Seleka members who died earlier that day during a clash with French soldiers. Congolese police force of MISCA intervented to moved protesters who were blocking a main road.

column7: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014) Presidential Security Unit
column17: French MISCA soldiers killed three ex-Seleka members during a clash. The Presidential Spokesman later stated that these men were in fact members of the Presidential Guard and that the shooting was unprovoked.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: MISCA raid an Anti-Balaka base. Three Anti-Balaka leaders captured, and their weapons confiscated.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Following the shooting of a youth by a MISCA officer, the crowd wrestled his gun from him, shot him dead, and then mutilated his body with machete blows.
Looting: French forces from the Sangaris operation arrested and disarmed ex-Seleka and other militiamen while the ex-Seleka were looting villages between Bossembele and Yaloke.
LRA attacked a village 40 km from Sam-Ouandja. Shots fired, property looted, no casualties reported.
A march was held in Kaga-Bandoro to protest against the announcement that Chadian troops of MISCA would be deployed to the area.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka in Bozoum on 23rd, 25th and 31st December 2013, and 5th January 2014. 70 deaths in total from these clashes.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Chadian elements of MISCA returned to attack Burundian soldiers of MISCA, following events earlier in the day. No casualties reported.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Chadian elements of MISCA threw a grenade towards Burundian elements of MISCA while they were intercepting six former rebels Seleka. No one was hurt by the grenade. Gunshots were fired and Burundian soldiers responded, wounding three Chadians. Chadian soldiers left with the six ex-Seleka members.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Christian protesters gathered at the entrance to the airport, demanding the resignation of transitional President Michel Djotodia and the departure of the Chadian elements of MISCA. After being pelted with stones, Chadian soldiers opened fire on the demonstrators, killing one and wounding another.
Gunfire erupted in PK5. Residents claim it was Anti-Balaka. 60 bodies found.
A member of the former Seleka has been killed by elements of the Lords Resistance Army (LRA) 21km from Sam-Ouandja. Eight other people abducted, later released. Villages looted.
On 23 December 2013, two Muslims were lynched to death and then mutilated in Gobongo by Anti-Balaka claiming to have acted in response to an attack by Seleka.
A Muslim man fired at Christian demonstrators who were blocking his way. They retaliated with machetes, killed him and burned his car.
Christian demonstrators erected roadblocks to prevents Chadians from evacuating to the airport. The French elements of Operation Sangaris intervened, and dispersed the crowd.

column9: Aid Workers (Central African Republic); UNICEF: United Nations Childrens Fund
column17: Rioters targeted a convoy of UNICEF and threatened to kill its occupants, including two Central Africans, as it entered Bangui.
The Muslim community organised a march on Tuesday December 24th to protest against the disarmament undertaken by French troops. Banners were also held showing the map of CAR split in two.
30 bodies found near Roux camp in Bangui, reportedly committed by ex Seleka.

Forty-seven Chadian nationals were killed in a surprise attack by Anti-Balaka militias on a convoy of Chadian nationals leaving Bangui on 24th December. Among those killed were children, babies, old men and women. Over a hundred others were wounded.
Anti-Balaka attack ex-Seleka members. 10 bodies found. 300 homes burned.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Gunshots in Bangui. Some residents accuse Anti-Balaka, other say it was ex-Seleka. 44 bodies collected (mostly civilian), including those of six Chadian soldiers.
Residents of Bangui have set up roadblocks and barricades in protest against the attacks.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka in Bozoum on 23rd, 25th and 31st December 2013, and 5th January 2014. 70 deaths in total from these clashes.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014) Presidential Security Unit
column17: Four people (two Congolese soldiers and two ex-Seleka) were killed as a result of clashes between the Congolese members of MISCA and elements of the Presidential guard.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Assailants armed with heavy weapons attempted to attack the presidential palace as well as the residence of the Central African Republics leader, but were pushed back by the army, officials said. Although the attackers could not immediately be identified, there are rumours that it may be a Christian militia, believed to be backed by former president Bozize.
The Muslim community of Bambari held a peaceful march against the division of the country and to interreligious conflict.
Youth rioters burnt down a mosque at Gbakondjia neighborhood of Bangui.
Hundreds of Christians and Muslims marched through the streets of Bangui for peace and to denounce the ""bias"" of the French soldiers, whom they accuse of siding with the Anti-Balaka militia.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Gunshots erupted in Bangui. Residents claim it was an attack by Anti-Balaka on elements of Chadian contingency. Five Chadian soldiers killed.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Demonstrators attacked Chadian nationals who were fleeing to Chad. Chadian soldiers of MISCA threw grenades to protect the nationals, killing one person and leaving many injured.
10 youths were abducted by ex-Seleka, under the false excuse that they were Anti-Balaka.

A convoy cars filled with Chadian nationals was leaving Bangui for Chad. Some CAR nationals gathered at the crossroads of PK-4 and wanted to attack these civilians in the convoy. French soldier were present to stop them.
Looting: Ex-Seleka attacked populations of Damara, looting and burning properties and chasing farmers in their fields. No reported casualty.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: 30 December 2013, Anti-Balaka clashe with MISCA and ex-Seleka in Bangui. Reports of some bodies on the ground, coded as 10.

column8: Former Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Ex-military close to Bozize attempted to attack an ex-Seleka camp, which was dominated by young Goula Muslims. Ex-Seleka retreated, no casualties reported.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: 31 December 2013, Anti-Balaka clashed with military forces and Seleka in Bangui at a base of the national army in PK11 and a Seleka camp in PK12. Twenty people dead, including two ex-Seleka and over 15 Anti-Balaka.
Ex-Seleka launched an attack on the police station of Damala neighbourhood, Bangui, which is occupied by Anti-Balaka. No casualties reported.

column7: Muslim Group (Central African Republic); Refugees/IDPs (Central African Republic)
column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Muslim rioters fired shots and burnt and looted property in the fifth arrondissement of Bangui. Angry tenants displaced at the Bangui Mpoko airport site burnt tyres on the road and ransacked Muslim properties in the attacked neighborhood in retaliation. MISCA troops dispersed the rioters.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka in Bozoum on 23rd, 25th and 31st December 2013, and 5th January 2014. 70 deaths in total from these clashes.
24 Christian residents of Bata were killed and several others injured by ex-Seleka and armed Muslim residents of nearby communities.

Three people were killed as they attempted to leave the makeshift IDP camp at Bangui MPoko airport. Shooters unknown. This is because the camp is surrounded by an ex-Seleka cantonment on one side, an Anti-Balaka base on another, and the Peul ethnic community is behind the camp, all of which are known to shoot in all directions.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: A sit-in was staged at Bangui MPoko airport by youths. This prevented planes from landing. It was broken up by Chadian elements of MISCA who opened fire, killing four.
In a reprisal attack, Christian youths burned the nearby homes of people believed to be Muslim. Body of an ex-Seleka member and two Muslims later found.
Clashes in the late morning between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka. One killed, many wounded.
Seleka fighters wearing civilian clothes threw grenades at the houses of people thought to be Christian. No reports of casualties.
Three people killed by unknown assailants in PK12, as the area is surrounded by Anti-Balaka, ex-Seleka and Fulani.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Shots heard as MISCA forces disperse a group of Muslims who took set fire to furniture on the road. No casualties reported.
Looting: Over 100 homes looted and burned in Birlo by ex-Seleka following an altercation between a local butcher and a Fulani man.
Clashes between French forces and an unknown armed group (indications suggest neither ex-Seleka nor anti-Balaka) in Boeing area of Bangui. No reports of casualties.

Anti-Balaka stopped a public transport vehicle at a roadblock and opened fire on those they believed to be Chadian Muslims. At least one reported dead - a Cameroonian man who was mistaken as a Chadian. [No further information on deaths of other passengers]
A teacher was killed by members of the ex-Seleka based in the town of Boda.
Shots heard in Bangui as clashes occur between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka. Red Cross reports 7 people killed.
French troops attempting to hold a position in PK5, a Muslim quarter, resulted in local people burning barricades. They were suspicious of French support for Anti-Balaka.
A grenade is thrown in a market in Bangui. 4 injured, including a Burundian element of MISCA.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka in Bozoum on 23rd, 25th and 31st December 2013, and 5th January 2014. 70 deaths in total from these clashes.
A 67 year old man suspected of witchcraft was burned alive on January 7th by his relatives in Boda.
A Muslim man was attacked by a group who cut him up with a machete. The attackers reportedly engaged in cannibalism.
Anti-Balaka attacks ex-Seleka elements near Boali on 7th and 8th January.
Reprisal violence in Kokoro and Fatimata on 7th and 8th January 2014.
Anti-Balaka attacks ex-Seleka in Combattant on 7th and 8th January 2014.
Reprisal violence in Kokoro and Fatimata on 7th and 8th January 2014.
Mbarara herders killed two people and wounded another, after their cattle had destroyed a field that these people were working on.
Ex-Seleka forces and armed Muslim civilians return to Boyali in a revenge attack, killing several Christian civilians and burning hundreds of homes.
While stopped to fix a flat tyre, two hand grenades were thrown a WFP food truck carrying food to an IDP site.
Following the departure of ex-Seleka, Anti-Balaka overtake Boyali.
A man stopped at a road barrier by Anti-Balaka, would not let them search his car. Angered, he threw a grenade at a group of onlookers, killing himself and one other.

column9: Christian Group (Central African Republic); MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column16: RCA (Central African Republic); World Food Programme
column17: 8 January 2014, Muslim communities demonstrated against disarmament operations conducted by French soldiers by burning tires and clashing with christian rioters in Yakite, Sara, Kokoro and Fatima neighborhoods, Bangui. They they feel the disarmament is unfairly biased against Muslims. The demonstration was dispersed by elements of MISCA.
Anti-Balaka attacks ex-Seleka elements near Boali on 7th and 8th January. 10 deaths on 8th January.
Anti-Balaka attacks ex-Seleka in Combattant on 7th and 8th January 2014.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: The Muslim communities of Yakite and Sara neighborhoods, Bangui, demonstrated against disarmament operations conducted by French soldiers, which they feel are unfairly biased against Muslims. Demonstrators burned tyres. Protest was dispersed by elements of MISCA.
Anti-Balaka launched an attack on civilian residents of Boyali, killing 30.
Reprisal violence in Kokoro and Fatimata on 7th and 8th January 2014.
People of Lakouanga district of, Bangui, demonstrated against the deployment of Chadian soldiers of MISCA in this locality, as they believe them to be brutal and residents are scared of them.

Ex-members of Seleka passing through Boyali village in a vehicle opened fire on a group of civilians who were at the roadside. This caused Anti-Balaka to respond, resulting in gunfire between the two groups. At least 40 Muslims reported dead as a result of the incidences.

column7: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: A Seleka convoy, accompanied by the Deputy Director General of Police of Bangui, came to Bozoum under the pretence of a peacekeeping operation. Clashes with Anti-Balaka ensued, 12 dead, and 1,100 homes were burned.
12 people abducted by the LRA in Yangoubrindi. Later released on 16th January 2014.

Ex-members of Seleka passing through Boyali village in a vehicle opened fire on a group of civilians who were at the roadside. This caused Anti-Balaka to respond, resulting in gunfire between the two groups. At least 40 Muslims reported dead as a result of the incidences.
Gunfire heard as Muslims attack Anti-Balaka in an attempt to avenge the death of the Muslims killed in Boyali on the 8th January.

column7: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Ex-Seleka, accompanied by police, begin to leave Bozoum in convoys. These convoys were attacked by Anti-Balaka. Two dead and a dozen injured.
The announcements of Djotodias resignation caused some rioters to take to the streets and vandalises a mosque in Petevo.

Between 10th and 14th January, young Muslims, armed with kalachnikovs, machetes and poisoned arrows, attack residents in the Sara and Yakite neighbourhoods. Four killed (including one INGO worker), six wounded and 100 houses burnt.

column6: UFDR: Union of Democratic Forces for Unity
column17: Former Seleka rebel leader and transitional President of CAR, Michel Djotodia, resigned from his position as president while at an ECCAS summit in Chad. He has been granted political exile in Benin. Prime Minister Nicolas Tiangaye also left office.
Looting (mostly of Muslim shops) and gunfire erupted in Bangui following the resignation of Djotodia. Red Cross reports 25 deaths between 10th - 13th January in Muslim-Christian clashes.

column9: MEFP: The House of Pygmy Children and Women
column17: Eight family members of a staff member of the NGO MEFP were killed by unidentified individuals.
A fisherman was killed by elements of ex-Seleka who accused him of being Anti-Balaka.
Protesters gathered in Bangui to demand that transitional president Michel Djotodia step down for failing to prevent rampant attacks by both Christian and Muslim militias.

Christian rioters attacked a Muslim as he was leaving a mosque in Sango, in the 2nd arrondissement of Bangui, using machetes and throwing rocks at his car. Another person was injured by rockets thrown in Boy Rabe.

Between 10th and 14th January, young Muslims, armed with kalachnikovs, machetes and poisoned arrows, attack residents in the Sara and Yakite neighbourhoods. Four killed (including one INGO worker), six wounded and 100 houses burnt.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka in Bozoum between 10th - 13th January resulted in 97 deaths, mostly civilians.
Muslims-Christian clashes result in 5 deaths in Mbata between 10th - 13th January.
Following the resignation of Djotodia, unidentified assailants fire shots at Sangaris troops. A bullet hits a Sangaris helicopter.

column6: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Alexandre Nguendet named interim president of CAR following the resignation of Djotodia.
Red Cross reports 25 deaths between 10th - 13th January in Muslim-Christian clashes.
A member of ex-Seleka opened fire at random, killing a number of bystanders.
Muslims youths set fire to a church following the resignation of Djotodia.

Between 10th and 14th January, young Muslims, armed with kalachnikovs, machetes and poisoned arrows, attack residents in the Sara and Yakite neighbourhoods. Four killed (including one INGO worker), six wounded and 100 houses burnt.

Ex-Seleka attacked 'Don Bosco', 'Combattants' and 'Eglise Freres Castor' IDP camps following the resignation of Djotodia. Two IDPs died and eight were injured as a result of grenades thrown at the sites.
Fulani herdsman killed by unidentified assailants.
Four people were killed, several others abducted and goods looted by ex-Seleka. Believed to be a revenge attack for the death of a Fulani herder.

Between 10th and 14th January, young Muslims, armed with kalachnikovs, machetes and poisoned arrows, attack residents in the Sara and Yakite neighbourhoods. Four killed (including one INGO worker), six wounded and 100 houses burnt.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column9: Civilians (Central African Republic); Muslim Group (Central African Republic)
column17: Children looted and set fire to a mosque to avenge the death of a Christian the previous day. MISCA soldiers intervened to interrupt the attack.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka in Bozoum between 10th - 13th January resulted in 97 deaths, mostly civilians.
Muslims-Christian clashes result in 5 deaths in Mbata between 10th - 13th January.
Red Cross reports 25 deaths between 10th - 13th January in Muslim-Christian clashes.
Five people were killed and one was burnt alive on January 12th by members of the Muslim community (accompanied by Fulani) of Yaloke, who were angered following the resignation of Michel Djotodia.
Individual lynched as a result of Christian-Muslim tensions. [No further details found]

Between 10th and 14th January, young Muslims, armed with kalachnikovs, machetes and poisoned arrows, attack residents in the Sara and Yakite neighbourhoods. Four killed (including one INGO worker), six wounded and 100 houses burnt.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka in Bozoum between 10th - 13th January resulted in 97 deaths, mostly civilians.

Between 10th and 14th January, young Muslims, armed with kalachnikovs, machetes and poisoned arrows, attack residents in the Sara and Yakite neighbourhoods. Four killed (including one INGO worker), six wounded and 100 houses burnt.
Muslims-Christian clashes result in 5 deaths in Mbata between 10th - 13th January.
Red Cross reports 25 deaths between 10th - 13th January in Muslim-Christian clashes.
Anti-Balaka ambushes vehicles carrying Muslims on the 13th and 14th, killing 30.

column9: MEFP: The House of Pygmy Children and Women
column17: Staff member of the NGO MEFP was found killed outside his house.
Demonstrations in Bouar following the lynching of an individual the previous day.

Between 10th and 14th January, young Muslims, armed with kalachnikovs, machetes and poisoned arrows, attack residents in the Sara and Yakite neighbourhoods. Four killed (including one INGO worker), six wounded and 100 houses burnt.

Between 10th and 14th January, young Muslims, armed with kalachnikovs, machetes and poisoned arrows, attack residents in the Sara and Yakite neighbourhoods. Four killed (including one INGO worker), six wounded and 100 houses burnt.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka in Bozoum between 10th - 13th January resulted in 97 deaths, mostly civilians.
Muslims-Christian clashes result in 5 deaths in Mbata between 10th - 13th January.
Anti-Balaka ambushes vehicles carrying Muslims on the 13th and 14th, killing 30.

Muslims of Bozoum, opposing the repatriation of Chadian ex-Seleka members, attacked a pastor of the Catholic Church and threw stones at his car after he tried to intervene. Some Muslims helped defend him.
Two people were killed and five others injured following a demonstration in Obo. Following the sound of shots, Ugandan forces based in Obo fired shots to disperse the demonstrators.

Between 10th and 14th January, young Muslims, armed with kalachnikovs, machetes and poisoned arrows, attack residents in the Sara and Yakite neighbourhoods. Four killed (including one INGO worker), six wounded and 100 houses burnt.
