Between 10th and 14th January, young Muslims, armed with kalachnikovs, machetes and poisoned arrows, attack residents in the Sara and Yakite neighbourhoods. Four killed (including one INGO worker), six wounded and 100 houses burnt.
A vehicle carrying Muslims and Fulani herders, escorted by a member of ex-Seleka, was attacked by Anti-Balaka. Latest reports indicate 10 deaths, including the member of ex-Seleka.
Five people killed and a dozen houses burned by Mbarara cattle traders in the villages of Bogama 1 and 2.
Looting: Health post looted by ex-Seleka. Medicines and other materials stolen.
Six decomposing bodies were found in the bush. Residents believe the killings to be perpetrated by armed Fulani herders in collusion with ex-Seleka. Exact date of deaths unknown.

column7: APRD: Popular Army for the Restoration of the Republic and Democracy
column17: Clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka, supported by ex-combatants of the Popular Army for the Restoration of Democracy (APRD), in Beboura, Nana Baria, Markounda and Boguila.

column7: Fulani Ethnic Militia (Central African Republic); Muslim Militia (Central African Republic)
column17: Seleka, Muslim and Peul militiamen set fire to more than 800 homes in Bogoura, near Boali, including 145 which belonged to them, before they left the village for Chad. They reportedly killed dozens of people following the resignation of Djotodia on 10 January.

column7: APRD: Popular Army for the Restoration of the Republic and Democracy
column17: Clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka, supported by ex-combatants of the Popular Army for the Restoration of Democracy (APRD), in Beboura, Nana Baria, Markounda and Boguila. Regional code noted in this event
Three Fulani killed by unidentified gunmen, but believed to be neither ex-Seleka nor Anti-Balaka.
Two people were seriously injured by Mbarara Fulani herders.

column7: APRD: Popular Army for the Restoration of the Republic and Democracy
column17: Clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka, supported by ex-combatants of the Popular Army for the Restoration of Democracy (APRD), in Beboura, Nana Baria, Markounda and Boguila.
Five Muslim men were abducted by Anti-Balaka and beaten. Their families had to pay a ransom for their release.

column7: APRD: Popular Army for the Restoration of the Republic and Democracy
column17: Clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka, supported by ex-combatants of the Popular Army for the Restoration of Democracy (APRD), in Beboura, Nana Baria, Markounda and Boguila.
A mass grave of 12 bodies found in PK12. Date of deaths unknown.

Sangaris troops attacked by unidentified group. They responded, locals say three deaths believed to result from this, none on the side of Sangaris. French military sources deny link to the three deaths.
Following the discovery of three Fulani bodies, the Fulani of Moscou burned houses and ravaged fields, causing many to flee.
Five people killed and a dozen houses burned by Mbarara cattle traders in the villages of Bogama 1 and 2.
Christian residents attacked by ex-Seleka. Four deaths.

Ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka arrange a reconciliation meeting, and ex-Seleka assured they would not harm the unarmed Anti-Balaka leaders in attendance. However, they executed all three of the Anti-Balaka and attacked observers, killing at least 16 more.
Anti-Balaka stormed the central mosque, where numerous residents were taking refuge. 43 Muslims killed in total. No Anti-Balaka deaths.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Deployment:The first 77 Rwandan soldiers arrive in Bangui as part of a MISCA deployment.
Anti-Balaka attack and take control of Bossembele. Some of the Muslims, who had a small cache of arms, engaged in a firefight with Anti-Balaka, but they were outgunned and outnumbered.
20 Muslim civilians killed and dozens injured outside Bouar when the vehicle in which they were fleeing was attacked.
Fulani fire shots on non-Muslims and burn houses. Reports of some deaths.
Clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka on 17th and 18th January. Seven killed (6 Muslims and 1 Christian).
Looting: Ex-Seleka looted and burned 24 houses in Lokoti-Banda/Gbaya district as they fled from clashes with Anti-Balaka in Bouar.
Anti-Balaka threw a grenade at a convoy of Muslims attempting to flee to Cameroon. 22 Muslims, including women and children, were killed, largely by machete wounds. 23 others injured.
Residents attacked and terrorised by ex-Seleka, who also attacked parish premises. At least three dead.

column7: CNPS: National Organisation of Peace and Security
column17: A hundred young people marched through the main streets of Bangui to demand the return of peace in CAR and the involvement of the population in decision-making. Event coordinated by the National Organisation of Peace and Security (CNPS).
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka in Bouar.
Clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka on 17th and 18th January. Seven killed (6 Muslims and 1 Christian).
Clashes in Sibut between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka.

Clashes between Anti-Balaka, and armed Muslim civilians and Seleka remnants. Anti-Balaka take control of Bossemptele. After gaining control, Anti-Balaka attack the Muslim civilian population. 100 dead in total: mostly Muslim civilians (armed and not armed), and two Anti-Balaka. No Christian civilians were killed.

Clashes between Anti-Balaka, and armed Muslim civilians and Seleka remnants. Anti-Balaka take control of Bossemptele. After gaining control, Anti-Balaka attack the Muslim civilian population. 100 dead in total: mostly Muslim civilians (armed and not armed), and two Anti-Balaka. No Christian civilians were killed.
Muslims abducted a taxi driver and executed him in Kilometre Cinq.
Ex-Seleka members did not accept the order of an ex-Seleka commander for disarmament. They fought back. In the exchange of fire, six people were killed, including a civilian.
A man was shot and killed at a barrier by ex-Seleka because he did not have enough money to pay them.

A group of young men blocked off a road with rocks and burning tyres in protest against the killing of a Muslim the previous day. When they appeared to be hitting someone on the ground, warning shots were fired by a Sangaris patrol and the patrol advanced, dispersing the mob. Rioters killed two people and set the corpses alight in the middle of the road.
Four people were killed as Anti-Balaka attacked Muslims who had taken refuge at a church. Sangaris intervened.

column9: Fulani Ethnic Group (Central African Republic); Women (Central African Republic)
column17: Anti-Balaka kill four Peulh women who were hiding in the house of a Christian family.

column9: Former Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka, supported by soldiers of ex-FACA, on 20th and 21st January. Several civilians and ex-Seleka members killed.
Anti-Balaka attack ex-Seleka, killing one.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: A tear gas grenade was thrown at a church housing refugees. It killed a DR-Congolese MISCA soldier and injured four others.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka, supported by armed Muslims, in Bangui areas of PK5, PK11, PK12 and PK13 which resulted in multiple deaths (Coded as 10).
Following the killing of an ex-Seleka member by Anti-Balaka, ex-Seleka attacked residents, looted and burned houses. Six dead.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: A grenade was thrown at a MISCA base by unknown assailants. A Congolese member of MISCA killed, and six injured: four Congolese MISCA soldiers and two civilians.
Ex-Seleka fleeing Bouar arrive in Bocaranga. They kill at least 10 and injured many more.

column9: Former Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka, supported by soldiers of ex-FACA, on 20th and 21st January. Several civilians and ex-Seleka members killed.
Ex-Seleka and armed Muslim civilians kill more than 100 Christian civilians in Baoro.
Anti-Balaka attack Muslim civilians.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka (supported by armed Mbororo Fulani herdsmen) on 21st and 22nd January.

column9: Fulani Ethnic Group (Central African Republic); Health Workers (Central African Republic); Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: Red Cross finds bodies of five Peulh individuals on 22nd January 2014.
In retaliation to the Anti-Balaka attack of Muslim civilians that day, a group of Muslims threw a rocket at some Christians and used machetes to kill one of them.

column8: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column17: Men associated with former Chadian rebel leader Baba Ladde (FPR) attacked the position of Anti-Balaka. No casualty report available.
A Sangaris soldier reports that when some Muslims emerged to shop, they were attacked by Christians.
Clashes between ex-Seleka and civilians. At least 10 dead.
Looting and destruction of property belonging to members of the Muslim community by youths and the Anti-Balaka.
Anti-Balaka attack Muslim civilians, killing at least 80 people and injuring hundreds. 4,000 houses set on fire.

column9: Fulani Ethnic Group (Central African Republic); Health Workers (Central African Republic); Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: Red Cross finds bodies of five more Peulh individuals on 23rd January 2014.
Ex-Seleka shoot at and kill three civilian men.
A mob of angry Christians broke into Ngaragba prison to kill ex-Seleka soldiers. The bodies of six ex-Seleka and four Christians found. Several prisoners escaped.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column9: Military Forces of Rwanda (1994-); Civilians (Central African Republic); Muslim Group (Central African Republic)
column17: A mob of thousands looted and burned Muslim homes in PK13, threatening to kill. Rwanda MISCA troops dispersed the group.
Ex-Seleka killed three people who were part of a crowd calling for the departure of ex-Seleka from their base at Kasai.
Anti-Balaka clashed with ex-Seleka stationed at Kasai on 22nd and 23rd January. Five deaths on 23rd January.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka. 16 deaths.

column6: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Mayor of Bangui, Catherine Samba Panza, is sworn in as the new interim president of CAR. She was chosen by CARs transitional parliament.
Anti-Balaka attacked and destroyed a mosque in PK13. Three dead.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Surrender/Defect:Ex-Seleka, fearing an attack by Anti-Balaka, started firing warning shots everywhere. Rwandan MISCA troops intervened to calm and disarm the ex-rebels.
Anti-Balaka attack Muslim civilians. 40 people killed.
Ex-Seleka broke into the home of the mayor of Sam-Ouandja and fired shots in an assassination attempt. The mayor escaped unharmed.
15 people were killed by Anti-Balaka, including Joseph Kalite, a Muslim former minister. Anti-Balaka rejected any responsibility in Kalites murder.
Anti-Balaka began attacking and looting shops in Miskine, prompting retaliation from ex-Seleka. Gunfire and explosions could be heard.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Exchange of fire during the night between MISCA and ex-Seleka.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Shooting between the Equatorial Guinean contingent of MISCA and ex-Seleka. 12 ex-Seleka arrested.
Two men lynched in the street and burned. Another man is lynched by a mob on suspicion he was involved with Seleka. Police fired into the air to prevent the lynching, to no avail.
LRA abduct two boys in Obo. One boy later released on 30th January 2014.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: HRW reports that Chadian MISCA soldiers escort a convoy of ex-Seleka out of CAR, including the head of military intelligence for ex-Seleka. This was not under the command of the chief of staff of the MISCA force.
Anti-Balaka attack Muslim civilians, killing four.
Woman stabbed to death by unknown assailants.
Mob violence claims a total of eight lives in Bangui on 26th January. Seven others injured.
Clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka.
Two women were killed by Fulani herders who were integrated into ex-Seleka.
Clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka.
At least 10 civilians killed by ex-Seleka in a village close to the Chadian border.
Anti-Balaka attack Muslim residents close to the Chadian border.
Clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka at Camp Kasai.
Anti-Balaka attack the home of a Muslim man and kill him.
Hundreds of ex-Seleka evacuate Camp de Roux.

column9: Christian Group (Central African Republic); Women (Central African Republic)
column17: Two Christian women killed by Fulani herders who were integrated into ex-Seleka. Another woman was raped.
Population of Boda lynch a Muslim man who had been involved in the death of another Muslim man during a fight.

Muslims, who were well-armed as ex-Seleka had equipped them before they left the town, fired shots, erected barricades and attacked Christians. Christians attempt to defend themselves with homemade weapons. 75 Christians dead between 28th January and 2nd February, no death toll established for the Muslims.
LRA attacks two men who were fishing. One was abducted, the other escaped.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and Muslim businessmen who gathered to defend their businesses on 28th and 29th January at Saint Michel de Bangui parish.
Three civilians were detained, tortured and stabbed by ex-Seleka in an effort to make them reveal the location of Anti-Balaka bases, which they did not know. Two died.

Looting: Hundreds of Anti-Balaka fighters chased residents out of PK13. Homes were systematically looted and dismantled. The main mosque was destroyed, and they chanted that they did not want Muslims in CAR.
Clashes between Sangaris and ex-Seleka. Two dead and eight wounded on the side of ex-Seleka.
Looting: Ex-Seleka fire warning shots and loot in Boda.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Dozens of ex-Seleka were peacefully escorted from their base at Camp Kasai by peacekeepers. People celebrated on the street.
Armed Muslims cause unrest and threaten to attack Christian civilians.
Ex-Seleka abduct and execute three civilians.
Two Muslims killed by Anti-Balaka.
LRA approach two young boys. They abduct one, and the other escapes.
Clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka on 29th, 30th and 31st January result in the death of at least 30. 60 others injured.
Ex-Seleka forced a 17 year old boy to drive their vehicles, then shot him dead at the airport.
Four Muslims killed at the entrance to Bangui MPoko airport.
Anti-Balaka take over Baoro, engaging in widespread looting and pillaging. No information on injuries.
Christian civilian killed with a knife; mistaken for a Muslim.
Ex-Seleka abduct nine men in Pata, and execute five of them in Vangue.
Two Muslims were lynched on the road to the airport, their bodies burned and mutilated.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and Muslim businessmen who gathered to defend their businesses on 28th and 29th January at Saint Michel de Bangui parish.
Ex-Seleka abduct nine men in Pata, and execute four of them in Pata.
Rwandan MISCA troops intervened as Anti-Balaka attacked Muslim civilians, saving them.
Clashes between anti-balaka and Muslim militia denouncing attacks against their communities in Miskine, Bangui.
Ten ex-Seleka were killed by French soldiers at RDOT military camp during clashes initiated by ex-Seleka.
Muslim civilian killed with a knife by Anti-Balaka, despite the intervention of French soldiers.
LRA attacks Obo, abducting some individuals, injuring others and looting. Five individuals released the following day.

Muslims, who were well-armed as ex-Seleka had equipped them before they left the town, fired shots, erected barricades and attacked Christians. Christians attempt to defend themselves with homemade weapons. 75 Christians dead between 28th January and 2nd February, no death toll established for the Muslims.
In the absence of other forces, ex-Seleka gain control of Sibut after terrorising the population.
Looting: In Berberati ex-Seleka loot and pillage.
Looting: In Carnot ex-Seleka loot and pillage.
Looting: In Gamboula ex-Seleka loot and pillage.

Muslims, who were well-armed as ex-Seleka had equipped them before they left the town, fired shots, erected barricades and attacked Christians. Christians attempt to defend themselves with homemade weapons. 75 Christians dead between 28th January and 2nd February, no death toll established for the Muslims.

column9: ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross and Red Crescent; Aid Workers (Central African Republic); Health Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: Driver of an ICRC vehicle was beaten by unidentified gunmen, who fled with the vehicle.

Gunmen abducted the chief of Ouham Pende I neighborhood in Boy Rabe, Bangui. He had recently identified and testified youth for an NGO in the neighborhood. He remained unaccounted for two weeks later.
Clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka on 29th, 30th and 31st January result in the death of at least 30. 60 others injured.

column9: Civilians (Central African Republic); Muslim Group (Central African Republic)
column17: Sangaris troops intervened and threatened to use force when a mob attacked Muslim shops.
Seleka set fire to the towns of Fere (Firi) and Mabo. The people protested during the attack, resulting in the deaths of a dozen of the local inhabitants and one Seleka.
Clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka on 29th, 30th and 31st January result in the death of at least 30. 60 others injured.
Seleka set fire to the towns of Fere (Firi) and Mabo. The people protested during the attack, resulting in the deaths of a dozen of the local inhabitants and one Seleka.

Muslims, who were well-armed as ex-Seleka had equipped them before they left the town, fired shots, erected barricades and attacked Christians. Christians attempt to defend themselves with homemade weapons. 75 Christians dead between 28th January and 2nd February, no death toll established for the Muslims.

column9: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014); Health Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: Ex-Seleka fired shots, looted and burned homes, injuring civilians. They disarmed soldiers of MISCA and looted the district hospital.
Report of armed Peul herders occupying Markounda in Ouham, preventing populations to harvest their fields et occupying the farmers lands with their livestock, creating fear among populations.
Seleka set fire to the towns of Ngbondo, Kohoro, Bac, Possel, Croisement, Zenda, Pangbi Kroma, Palingui, Lenge and Bango. During the attack, they systematically burned down about 500 houses.

Seleka set fire to the towns of Ngbondo, Kohoro, Bac, Possel, Croisement, Zenda, Pangbi Kroma, Palingui, Lenge and Bango. During the attack, they systematically burned down about 500 houses. Sibut as main location and this is one of several events in region

Seleka set fire to the towns of Ngbondo, Kohoro, Bac, Possel, Croisement, Zenda, Pangbi Kroma, Palingui, Lenge and Bango. During the attack, they systematically burned down about 500 houses. Two farmers killed in Ngbondo.
Seleka set fire to the towns of Ngbondo, Kohoro, Bac, Possel, Croisement, Zenda, Pangbi Kroma, Palingui, Lenge and Bango. During the attack, they systematically burned down about 500 houses.

Seleka set fire to the towns of Ngbondo, Kohoro, Bac, Possel, Croisement, Zenda, Pangbi Kroma, Palingui, Lenge and Bango. During the attack, they systematically burned down about 500 houses. Sibut as main location and this is one of several events in region

Seleka set fire to the towns of Ngbondo, Kohoro, Bac, Possel, Croisement, Zenda, Pangbi Kroma, Palingui, Lenge and Bango. During the attack, they systematically burned down about 500 houses. Three people shot dead in Kohoro.

Seleka set fire to the towns of Ngbondo, Kohoro, Bac, Possel, Croisement, Zenda, Pangbi Kroma, Palingui, Lenge and Bango. During the attack, they systematically burned down about 500 houses. Sibut as main location and this is one of several events in region
Seleka set fire to the towns of Ngbondo, Kohoro, Bac, Possel, Croisement, Zenda, Pangbi Kroma, Palingui, Lenge and Bango. During the attack, they systematically burned down about 500 houses.

Muslims, who were well-armed as ex-Seleka had equipped them before they left the town, fired shots, erected barricades and attacked Christians. Christians attempt to defend themselves with homemade weapons. 75 Christians dead between 28th January and 2nd February, no death toll established for the Muslims.
Ex-Seleka kill 12 civilians, including four women and four children. Five others seriously wounded.
Anti-Balaka take over control of Carnot.
Anti-Balaka abduct three Muslim IDPs, who were released at a later date.
Anti-Balaka killed at least 27 Muslims as they attacked Guen on February 1st.
An anti-Muslim gang tried to lynch a Muslim and burned a house.
Ex-Seleka shot dead four people who were trying to flee.
Ex-Seleka in Ngaoundaye shot at civilians. When inhabitants fled to the bush, they were pursued by ex-Seleka who continued to shoot at them. Death toll not known.
Heavy exchange of fire between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka.

column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016); Women (Central African Republic)
column17: While interim president Catherine Samba-Panza visits a mosque, she mentions the return of the Central African Armed Forces (FACA). In response, the crowd started throwing clods of earth, sand and water sachets in her direction.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Talks between MISCA and ex-Seleka lead to the removal of ex-Seleka from their positions in Sibut, without violence. MISCA gains control. A Gabonese contingent from MISCA is in place in the town, supported by Sangaris.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Following the event where civilians were beaten by MISCA during questioning, people took to the streets, burned tyres and demanded the departure MISCA, who shot into the air.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: A gunman fired at MISCA soldiers. They attempted to arrest him but he escaped, shooting and injuring one MISCA soldier.
Four people abducted by the LRA.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: After the escape of a gunman, MISCA interrogated civilians about his whereabouts. Two women went to the hospital, one with a broken arm, claiming that they were beaten by MISCA during questioning.

Muslims, who were well-armed as ex-Seleka had equipped them before they left the town, fired shots, erected barricades and attacked Christians. Christians attempt to defend themselves with homemade weapons. 75 Christians dead between 28th January and 2nd February, no death toll established for the Muslims.

Mass grave of about 13 people was discovered on February 12th at an ex-Seleka camp in Bangui. The victims, who are not identified, are thought to have died between a week and ten days before discovery.
Anti-Balaka beat up a Muslim IDP and threatened to kill injured Muslim IDPs in the mission hospital.
An INGO office is attacked by ex-Seleka. [No further info found at present]
Anti-Balaka attack an area where Muslims and Fulani herders had taken refuge, despite the protection of MISCA. One Muslim killed and 14 injured. Three Anti-Balaka injured.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Chadian troops of Misca visited Bossembele to bring Chadian nationals to Bangui. While there they fired on civilians and burned houses. Death toll unknown.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Chadian MISCA peacekeepers opened fire on the civilian population, killing two.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: FACA attempted to recover looted goods from the home of a Muslim man. A group of armed men came to his defense. FACA threw a grenade to disperse the crowd, injuring one man.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Chadian troops of Misca visited Yaloke to bring Chadian nationals to Bangui. While there they fired on civilians and burned houses. Death toll unknown.
Ex-Seleka kill 22 civilians, loot and burn homes in Nzakoun.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Anti-Balaka ambushed Chadian MISCA soldiers, resulting in several deaths, including a colonel of the Chadian army.

Anti-Balaka attacked a compound where the remaining Muslims of Guen were hiding, killing 45 men and boys. Head of Anti-Balaka in this area denied this, claiming that the killing did not occur, and instead they killed 25 ex-Seleka.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016); Seleka Militia
column16: Liberation (Morocco); Radio Ndeke Luka; AFRIK Presse
column17: On 5 February 2014, FACA soldiers lynched a soldier in civilian clothes whom they accused of being associated with ex-Seleka right after an official ceremony with the head of the transitional government gathering all FACA members in Bangui. The victim was then stripped, dismembered and burned, including by angry residents who joined the soldiers in their lynch. MISCA fired tear gas to disperse the crowd. Some of those involved in the attack are believed to be Anti-Balaka. The event was condemned nationally and internationally.
Seleke attack Mbere where they kill four people by setting the village alight.
Seleke attack Bang, where they burn 46 houses.
Anti-Balaka attack ex-Seleka; a stray bullet kills a female civilian.
Seleka attacked Ngaoundaye where they set fire to 8 houses and wounded 7 people.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Armed anti-Balaka attempted to loot a truck that was part of a convoy escorting Chadian nationals from CAR. The convoy had just arrived a Gobongo. Burundian soldiers from MSICA fired shots to disperse the attackers.
Anti-Balaka storm Berberati and take control, asking the residents to voluntarily disarm themselves.
Seleka launch another attack on Bang, killing up to 16 people.

column9: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Anti-Balaka attack a truck that was part of a convoy escorting Chadian nationals from CAR, escorted by Chadian soldiers of MISCA. MISCA intervened. Eight Anti-Balaka and several Muslim passengers killed.
Anti-Balaka storm a house where IDPs were sheltering, kill seven and injure three.
A convoy of vehicles escorting Muslim Chadian nationals from CAR, escorted by Chadian solider of MISCA, was followed by an angry crowd. One man fell off a vehicle and was lynched by the mob.
Seleka attacked Zoulde village, where 200 homes were burned.
Seleka travel in 32 vehicles to again attack the people of Ngaoundaye, killing at least 22, including women and children, before burning down their homes.

column7: Christian Group (Central African Republic); Vigilante Group (Central African Republic)
column17: A crowd killed the Muslim responsible for the death of a Christian civilian and lynched him, burning his body outside of the town hall.

Looting: Anti-Balaka looted and destroyed shops at Banguis central market during the night. Later in the week Anti-Balaka looted several homes in Bangui, entering civilian residences with heavy weapons. No injuries.
A Christian woman was killed by a Muslim. In a separate incident, another Muslim gunman killed five Christians in Bangui on the same day.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: A Muslim civilian was killed by suspected Anti-Balaka. As his body was about to be set alight, Rwandan MISCA soldiers intervened and opened fire, killing one.
Jean-Emmanuel Ndjarouaa, a member of the National Transition Council, was killed by unidentified assailants.

column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: A Muslim civilian was killed by suspected Anti-Balaka. As his body was about to be set alight, Rwandan MISCA soldiers intervened and opened fire, killing one. One the same day, a group of ten Anti-Balaka also attacked former justice Minister Arsene Sende at his home, leaving two people severely injured, including the president of the commercial Court, and looting property.
Seleka militiamen abducted two people at their home in Bangui, Rdot sector, on 8 or 9 February.
Anti-Balaka attack Muslims, killing several.
Seleka abducted 7 Kotto villagers on their way to the field.

column6: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column17: Baba Laddes men raided a village, killed 27 people and burned houses

column6: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column17: Anti-Balaka attempt to remove Baba Laddes men from Ngaoundaye, but to no avail. Babe Laddes men take control of the village.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Looting: Report of repeated lootings by FACA and anti-balaka targeting Muslim communities of Bouar.
Anti-Balaka attack Muslim civilians. 21 bodies found.
Anti-Balaka burned houses and shops of Muslims, killing eight in acts of violence.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column7: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Prison Guards
column17: FACA, supported by prison guards, tried to disarm Anti-Balaka, resulting in clashes and three dead.
Two ex-Seleka attacked, and one killed, at a funeral. Some witnesses claim the funeral crowd attacked the ex-rebels, while other state that Anti-Balaka were involved.
Ex-Seleka open fire in the central market in a revenge attack due to the death of an ex-Seleka member killed the previous night. One killed and two injured.
Men armed with machetes and guns entered the hospital, firing shots and threatening patients.
Several houses burned down in Yamindi and Gbaya neighbourhoods by ex-Seleka.
Anti-Balaka take over the town of Nola.

Following the killing by locals of three Fulani oxen, the population was attacked by Fulani herders, and then by ex-Seleka. Ex-Seleka cut off the ear of a man, and abused people before demanding a fine of 1.5 million FCFA.

column7: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column17: An attack kills at least 14 people. Some blame ex-Seleka for the attack, while others claim it was men of Baba Ladde who were responsible for the violence.
A young man is killed by an armed Muslim.
Following the killing by locals of three Fulani oxen, the population was attacked by Fulani herders, and then by ex-Seleka.
Anti-Balaka attack civilians, killing three Muslims.

column7: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column17: Another attack on Bang, this time attacking government buildings, the homes of the civil servants and churches. No deaths reported. Some blame ex-Seleka for the attack, while others claim it was men of Baba Ladde who were responsible.
Anti-Balaka opened fire and hurled a grenade into a camp for displaced Muslims, leaving one dead and two injured among the displaced.

An angry crowd of Christians severely wounded two Muslims who were trying to flee in a convoy. The crowd set tyres on fire and shouted anti-Muslim and anti-French slogans. French peacekeepers evacuated the two wounded.
Ex-Seleka and some armed members of the Muslim community of Kaga-Bandoro attacked civilians, killing one.
Ex-Seleka fire warning shots as approximately 100 ex-rebels evacuate RDOT camp.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column8: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column17: MISCA, supported by Anti-Balaka and former combatants of the Armed People for the Restoration of Democracy (APRD), removed Baba Laddes men from Bang.
A member of ex-Seleka killed a local pharmacist after he refused to give him money.
Anti-Balaka attack Guen in February, killing 27 on the first day of the attack and 43 on the second day.
Ex-Seleka rob the INGO Solidarites International.

column9: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Armed groups attack civilians and a convoy near the border. Rwandan MISCA soldiers respond to save the civilians.

column6: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column17: FPR gunmen renewed attacked on Bang, leaving at least two people killed, seven missing and more than 300 houses burnt. On the same day, MISCA reported to have removed Baba Laddes men from Bang.
An angry mob of residents attack and kill the ex-Seleka soldier who killed a local pharmacist.
11 people killed as Anti-Balaka attack Boali.
5 French soldiers were accused of having beaten 2 Central Africans in Bangui in early 2014. Disciplinary proceedings were started against them in early June 2016.

column7: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Arrests: Sangaris and MISCA launch a disarmament operation of Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka. As part of this operation, eight Anti-Balaka leaders were arrested.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: During the disarmament operation, MISCA surround the house of Patrice Edouard Ngaissona, a senior leader of the Anti-Balaka. Grenade explosions and gunfire could be heard, with MISCA firing into the air in response to aggression by those inside. Ngaissona was not present and was not detained.

column7: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column17: A further attack on Bang, killing eight people including the pastor of the apostolic church and his two children. Some blame ex-Seleka for the attack, while others claim it was men of Baba Ladde who were responsible for the violence.

column9: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Clashes occurred at a checkpoint erected by the Anti-Balaka when a MISCA patrol refused to comply with the demands of the militiamen. Anti-Balaka and highway bandits attack the convoy of civilians. MISCA respond to subdue the attackers. 11 people dead.

column6: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column17: Baba Laddes men fired shots, resulting in nine deaths.
Anti-Balaka attack Guen in February, killing 27 on the first day of the attack and 43 on the second day.

column8: Wango Bangassou Communal Militia (Central African Republic)
column17: Ex-Seleka attack the village of Wango Bangassou, but are resisted by the youth who use knives and guns, causing the death of seven ex-Seleka.
A group of six suspected Anti-Balaka attacked a woman in Bangui, leaving her severely injured. They were later arrested by authorities.
Ex-Seleka approach the village of Salanze, but are resisted by the youth who use knives and guns, causing the death of four ex-Seleka.
Several people killed in Bazoua and Ngatou villages as ex-Seleka attacked, also burning homes and barns.
Several people killed in Bazoua and Ngatou villages as ex-Seleka attacked, also burning homes and barns.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; RCA (Central African Republic)
column17: Clashes between Chadian elements of MISCA and rioters having erected road barricades in Damara protesting against the Sangaris disarmament of Anti-Balaka. Six people killed and several others injured.

Small groups of demonstrators protesting against the Sangaris disarmament of Anti-Balaka erected barricades on the main road leading to the airport. Despite French interventions, demonstrators managed to repeatedly rebuild the barricades. Report of people injured.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Exchanges of fire between Anti-Balaka and MISCA in Boy Rabe. Three dead, including two Cameroonian soldiers.
Ex-Seleka opened fire on the population of Kamakota and Kouki villages, killing nine.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Protesters (civilians and Anti-Balaka) erected barricades and burned tyres against the presence of international forces as Chadian soldiers attempted to evacuate a convoy of Chadian nationals. MISCA attempt to remove the barricades. Exchange of fire occurs.
Ex-Seleka opened fire on the population of Kamakota and Kouki villages, killing nine.

column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016); Health Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: LRA shoots at an ambulance that was transferring a pregnant woman to hospital. However, two FACA soldiers and two monks were also inside. FACA soldiers shot back. The passengers fled and the LRA burned the ambulance. No casualties.
A convoy carrying people escaping from PK12 was attacked by Anti-Balaka. All 21 men in the convoy were killed.
Armed Fulani herders killed two civilians, injured twelve others, and raped eight women.
A Rwandan trader was assassinated by unidentified armed men.
A Muslim man was attacked with machetes by Christians, towards whom he had made offensive remarks. The attackers were later arrested by MISCA.
Two Muslims killed in PK5. [No further information available at present]
A crowd chanting anti-Muslim slogans forced a taxi to stop, and then killed the three Muslims inside using guns and machetes. MISCA fired warning shots, but to no avail.
Three people killed in Sosso-Nakombo in Mambere Kadei by unknown gunmen between 19-26 February. Two of the victims were beheaded.

column9: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: On 22 February 2014, a mob of people carrying clubs and machetes attempted to lynch a suspected thief, but was saved by the intervention of a policeman.

Ex-Seleka fighters, supported by Peuhl cattle herders, attacked the village of Yakongo, killing at least 19 civilians. During the attack, the villages Anti-Balaka fighters fired back on the Seleka and Peuhl, who retaliated, killing two anti-balaka fighters. The attackers set homes alight.
A 15 year old girl is raped by a member of Anti-Balaka.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Nine people were killed and several others injured in clashes between Anti-Balaka and Chadian MISCA soldiers. Two Chadian soldiers among the dead.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Warning shots fired by MISCA at Ngaragba prison to control a mutiny of prisoners, most of whom are Anti-Balaka. No deaths reported.
Anti-Balaka attack the populatio of Zini, Kafa, Bazoa and Daoune, killing three, abducting one, setting homes on fire and looting.
Anti-Balaka attack the populatio of Zini, Kafa, Bazoa and Daoune, killing three, abducting one, setting homes on fire and looting.
Anti-Balaka attack the populatio of Zini, Kafa, Bazoa and Daoune, killing three, abducting one, setting homes on fire and looting.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Clashes between Anti-Balaka and Chadian MISCA soldiers. Two civilians killed. One Chadian soldier seriously wounded.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: 30 Cameroonian peacekeepers fired into the air to disperse a group of angry Anti-Balaka who congregated outside the concrete walls of the church compound, threatening to kill Muslims who were sheltering inside. They brought 40 litres of gasoline and threatened to burn the church to the ground.
Anti-Balaka attack and kill a woman they accused of witchcraft and being responsible for killing a member of Anti-Balaka.

column16: RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: Suspected Anti-Balaka gunmen shot and killed three people in three separate incidents at KM5 of Bangui. They fled when MISCA soldiers intervened.
Ex-Seleka attack RDOT neighborhood of PK12 , detonating grenades and injuring an unknown number of victims.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Clashes between MISCA, Anti-Balaka, and other bandits.
Four people killed in clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka. Additional unconfirmed reports of civilians drowning as they flee the clashes.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column7: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Human Rights Watch reported that 2 Anti-Balaka militiamen were publicly executed in February 2014 in Mambere by Congolese peacekeeprs serving with MISCA.

Ex-Seleka, joined by Peuhl herders, attacked the village of Bowai, killing eight and injuring at least 10 others. The attackers burned many buildings in the village, in some cases trapping people in their homes prior to setting them alight.

Anti-Balaka and a group of angry Christians attack ex-Seleka, killing one, in a revenge attack for attacking RDOT neighbourhood. Sangaris on scene to preven further Anti-Balaka from crossing a barrier to attack ex-Seleka.
Anti-Balaka attacked a man and detained him for a number of hours after his neighbour complained to the Anti-Balaka of receiving death threats from him.
French troops intervened to avoid a murder after ex-Seleka stabbed a Christian.
Ex-Seleka carried out an attack on the village of Boguila. Three people were killed and an MSF hospital looted.
A Muslim mayor had his throat slit and was killed by Anti-Balaka.
A Peuhl cattle herder entered the Catholic parish trying to hide with the other displaced people. Anti-Balaka spotted him and executed him.
""Two INGO international staff members were wounded during an armed robbery at the office.""
Clashes between Seleka and Anti-balaka in Koki village, near Bossangoa. After being driven away, the Seleka attacked Boguila.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Clashes between Anti-Balaka and MISCA as Anti-Balaka refuse to disarm. Reports of injuries. No reports of deaths.
Unidentified gunmen shot and killed three ex-Seleka as they were travelling in a taxi.

A mob gathered to attack four ex-Seleka, killing three and seriously wounding the fourth. They also lynched to death a mentally ill man, whom they accused of possessing a grenade and wanting to use it.
Two people were killed and several others injured by ex-Seleka at a wedding ceremony of a former Seleka commander.

column6: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column17: Men identifying with Baba Laddes rebels killed 16 civilians.

column9: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Following the shooting of two civilians and a lieutenant of the gendarmerie by Chadian soldiers of MISCA, angry people erected barricade and burned tyres. French and MISCA soldiers intervened to disperse the rioters.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Chadian soldiers of MISCA claim they were attacked by some armed men. Following this, they fired back, killing three: two civilians and a lieutenant of the gendarmerie who were in a crowd.
Anti-Balaka kill a local imam and injure a priest who attempted to protect the imam.
Mbororo Fulani, leaving a Mosque, began to vandalise the houses of Christians nearby by removing the roofs.
For International Womens Day, more than one hundred women gathered at the Cinquantenaire Park in Bangui to rally for peace, reconciliation and non-violence.
After Mbororos vandalised the houses of Christians, Anti-Balaka were alerted. They opened fire on the Fulani, who were unarmed. No deaths.
Ex-Seleka kidnap the head of the district of Dangavo. She was released the following week after the payment of a ransom of 150,000 FCFA.
Anti-Balaka kill one person as displaced Muslims try to flee the area.
While passing through Damba, ex-Seleka kill one person and loot the food reserves of the villagers.

column6: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column17: Looting: Men associated to Baba Laddes men fire shots, loot homes and burn homes. No casualties as the population had fled when they heard rumours of the pending attack.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Thousands took to the streets to protest against the relocation of ex-Seleka to a gendarme school in Kolongo. They barricaded the road and burned tyres. MISCA forces sent to keep the situation under control, resulting in three protesters injured.
People took to the streets to protest against the relocation of ex-Seleka to a school, barricading roads.
On 7 March 2014, a Muslim man was lynched by a group of Christians with machetes in Bangui-5.
Three Muslims killed and their bodies mutilated by Christian militants while their taxi broke down en route to Bangui MPoko airport.
Men armed with machetes killed a Fulani herder and stole his horse.
Five Fulani herders were killed following a confrontation with Anti-Balaka.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Elements of FACA kill a suspected thief who was a member of Anti-Balaka.

column9: ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross and Red Crescent; Aid Workers (Central African Republic); Health Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: Armed men entered a Catholic Mission where four national ICRC members were, killing one of them. According to a Central African military source, the victim was killed by a member of ex-Seleka.
Clashes between ex-Seleka and Sangaris result in five deaths, including four ex-Seleka.

Four people were killed in gunfire between two rival armed looting gangs. This was caused by a dispute between the two groups regarding how to share the spoils of looting in the neighborhood. Two civilians wounded by stray bullets.
Anti-Balaka kill a man on the pretext that he communicates with Muslims in Cameroon who have fled Baoro. Unclear whether this man himself was Muslim or otherwise.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Elements of Anti-Balaka revolted against the killing of one of their members by FACA and demanding the disarmament of FACA. The situation was calmed through the intervention of MISCA and Sangaris some hours later.

column9: ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross and Red Crescent; Aid Workers (Central African Republic); Health Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: A volunteer with the Central African Red Cross Society was gunned down in Bangui.

column9: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Youths, supported by Anti-Balaka, lynched a Muslim when he left his house to look for food. They tried to loot the house of the victim, but were dispersed by MISCA.
A man was shot and killed by men associated with Anti-Balaka.
Three Chadian Muslims were assaulted by Anti-Balaka. Their lives were saved due to the intervention of police.

The people of PK16 took to the streets, erected barricades and burned tyres in protest against rumours that elements of ex-Seleka will be transferred to the nearby Agency of African Muslims centre. Sangaris unsuccessfully tried to clear the roads.
Unidentified gunmen shot and killed a man in Bouar while looting his home.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Anti-Balaka were trying to rob a man when patrolling elements of MISCA surprised them and opened fire on them, killing one and injuring three.
A member of ex-Seleka left Camp Beal to retrieve some food, but was attacked and seriously injured by Anti-Balaka.
Eight people, including a 4 year old child, were kidnapped and robbed by the LRA from a village 20km from Mboki. They were released two days later.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Gendarmerie
column17: Students from the University of Bangui went on strike due to the non-payment of scholarships. They erected barricades and burned tyres. MISCA and the gendarmerie dispersed the demonstrators.
Anti-Balaka killed a member of ex-Seleka, whom they believed to be responsible for many atrocities, including cases of murder and rape of women and girls.

column7: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column17: Looting: Seleka and FPR militiamen attacked and burnt Koki village near Bossangoa, looting and burning properties, as well as ransacking the villages church. Dozens of people fled to Nana Bakassa or to Bossangoa.
A Muslim trader entered the Christian side of the KM5 market to reach his stall. He was attacked by youths who threw stones at him, injuring him, and then stole his bike.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: An imam and director of a Quranic school said he was attacked by a mob of street children and young men wielding machetes, sticks, and stones when he left KM5 to buy vegetables. AU peacekeepers eventually rescued him.

A member of ex-Seleka left Camp Beal to go to the market, but was attacked and killed by a mob of locals with knives and machetes at the market when he was recognised as ex-Seleka. No Anti-Balaka involvement.

People took to the streets, barricading David Dacko Avenue and Bartholomew Bongada Avenue and burned tires, in protest against a rumour that ex-Seleka would be relocated to the nearby SOCATEL premises.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Angry residents erected barricades in the streets to protest against recent violence in the Bea Rex area.
An 18 year old man was killed by Fulani herders in Batcho village, 23km from Kaga Bandoro. Two other youths, aged 13 and 18, were injured.
Looting: Anti-Balaka fired into the air throughout the night to express their anger at finding the body of a comrade who had been killed by armed looters in the area.
Heavy gunshots heard in Fondo as the neighbourhood is attacked and homes burned. Anti-Balaka blame Muslims, while others blame Anti-Balaka.

After Muslims left the area, Anti-Balaka and youths from Combattant, who had armed themselves, looted the area. Shots were fired between these two groups, resulting in the death of an Anti-Balaka and the injuring of others.

column8: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: The new minister-counselor to the prime minister, Joachim Kokate, negotiated an agreement with the Anti-Balaka of Boda, in which they agreed not to attack the population and to cooperate with Sangaris.
Four girls, aged 13 and 15, were raped by Anti-Balaka in the village of Botto and Kologbo.
Four girls, aged 13 and 15, were raped by Anti-Balaka in the village of Botto and Kologbo.
Anti-Balaka attacked Fulani herders and stole their cattle on the road to Bocaranga, 85km from Bozoum. No reports of death toll.
Fulani herders known as ""Alngamba"" attacked Zaire village. Eight people were killed and 250 houses were burnt.

column9: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014); Health Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: Anti-Balaka stormed Bozoum hospital, kidnapping a physician and threatening to return to kill the staff. They left following the intervention of MISCA.

column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; RCA (Central African Republic)
column17: Two people were killed and several others injured by ex-Seleka as they fired shots and looted homes in Batangafo while searching for Anti-Balaka. At least four people suspected of being part of the group were also taken.
Staff of Bozoum hospital cease work following an attack and threats by Anti-Balaka.
More than 100 Muslim women gathered at a shopping centre to protest against the ongoing violence in Bangui.
Armed men, identifying as ex-Seleka, attacked two traders, killing one, stealing two motorbikes and their goods, 70km from Sam-Ouandja.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Exchange of fire between FACA and armed individuals, resulting in the death of a FACA officer.
Conflict between Anti-Balaka and Muslims living in Boda, despite signing a recent agreement saying that they would not attack the Muslims of Boda.
Ex-Seleka burned five houses with people inside in the Camp-Fleur neighbourhood of Kaga Bandoro. No casualties reported.
""One INGO driver was stabbed by armed men who seized a water pump and demanded money for its return.""
Anti-Balaka attacked the Peul community of Bozoum, executing pregnant women and children.
Sangaris report clashes between French forces and Anti-Balaka in Bangui.
A man was shot dead by gunmen associated with ex-Seleka.

column9: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: A mob attempted to attack a Muslim man as he was tranferring money at a bank. Burundian soldiers of MISCA fired to disperse the crowd, injuring six people including four who were under 16.
A UNICEF convoy was attacked by Anti-Balaka. Several people were killed.
Muslim IDPs emerged from the Mosque and started shooting at the people of Boeing. Anti-Balaka responded.
Anti-Balaka militia attacked the predominantly Muslim neighbourhood of KM5.
Ex-Seleka injured eight people at a site 12km from Kaga Bandoro, including two women and two girls, aged twelve and seven.
Seven people were killed by ex-Seleka who accused them of being Anti-Balaka.
Clashed between armed youth of Boeing, supported by Anti-Balaka, and armed men from the Mosque, supported by ex-Seleka. Two women injured.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Burundian soldiers of MISCA open fire on the people while passing through Damara. MISCA denies this accusation. No deaths reported.
Anti-Balaka attacked Muslims in Km5, killing four.

column7: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Another attack by Anti-Balaka on KM5. Residents say that some of the assailants were wearing FACA uniforms. Some Muslims residents armed themselves with rifles and threw a grenade. They killed one Anti-Balaka.
One person was killed by ex-Seleka when they could not afford to hand over the money they demanded.
Twelve people were killed and thirty houses burned in the village of Godawa, 70 km from Gamboula, in an attack by armed Fulani herders.

column9: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Four people, including two Muslims, were killed and seven injured in PK-5 in clashes between Anti-Balaka, and Sangaris and MISCA.
Upon hearing that Fulani herders had attacked Godawa, Anti-Balaka retaliated, killing six of the armed Fulani herders, and injuring another.
Anti-Balaka ambushed and killed two ex-Seleka.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Two MISCA soldiers stationed at Hopital de l'Amitie in Bangui were attacked with grenades. No serious injuries reported.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Clashes between Anti-Balaka and armed looters, and MISCA and Sangaris. Approximately 20 killed in these clashes on the 22nd and 23rd March.
The uncle and father of a young man who had died were killed by Anti-Balaka on the suspicion of witchcraft that resulted in the death of the young man.
Two were injured after a grenade exploded during a dispute between ex-Seleka members over looted goods.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: A MISCA peacekeeper from the DRC was wounded in an attack by unidentified assailants.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column7: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: In February a mass grave was exhumed near a base of DR-Congo peacekeepers in which at least 12 bodies were found in Boali. They had reportedly been detained in March 2014 by the DR-Congo peacekeepers.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Congolese MISCA soldiers severely beat a local police officer at a checkpoint following a dispute
Angry youths set up barricades to restrict the movement of peacekeepers.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: After Congolese peacekeepers investigate shots and attempt to confiscate weapons from an anti-balaka leader known as ""General"" Maurice Konoumo, a group of anti-balaka fighters attacked a MISCA vehicle near Boalis central market, throwing a grenade and opening fire with automatic weapons. The attack killed one Congolese peacekeeper and wounded four others.
Anti-Balaka barricade Independence Avenue.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Clashes between Anti-Balaka and Burundian soldiers of MISCA on the 23rd and 24th March.
Anti-Balaka attack Muslims of PK12 and KM5 on several occasions on the 25 March. At least 1 killed.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Clashes erupted between MISCA, supported by Sangaris, and Anti-Balaka, when Rwandan and Burundian soldiers began to dismantle barricades erected on Independence Avenue by Anti-Balaka.
Gunmen looted and destroyed houses in Miskine in the context of tensions and gunshots heard throughout the town on 25 March.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Clashes between Anti-Balaka, and MISCA and Sangaris.
11 people were killed and twenty others injured in a grenade attack on a Christian funeral. Local community blames Muslims.
Suspected Chadian soldiers from the regular army occupies all villages in Bemal in Paoua, killing at least three people and looting property.
Members of the local community held protest on Friday, blaming Muslims for the recent grenade attack on a Christian funeral.
Armed Fulani herders attacked Godawa, burning thirteen houses. Death toll not yet established.
Armed Fulani herders burned four people and four houses in the village of Ore, located 25km from Gamboula.
A group of at least nine detainees, including some Anti-balaka members, escaped from Ngaragba prison. The whereabouts of these people remain unknown as of the end of May 2014.

column7: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column8: CPJP: Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace
column17: Anti-Balaka target house of Abdoulaye Hissene of the former rebel group the Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace (CPJP), where he was meeting with ex-Seleka. MISCA and Sangaris intervened. One ex-Seleka killed.

column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; UN (unspecified); RCA (Central African Republic)
column17: Chadian soldiers from the regular army fired indiscriminately at civilians at a market in Banguis Pk12 area, leaving 30 killed and more than 300 injured. MISCA soldiers intervened to disperse the Chadian soldiers. Anti-Balaka were initially accused of having attacked the soldiers, while a later UN investigation revealed that the soldiers were unprovoked and acting independently from MISCA.
Gunmen, suspected of being Fulani, attacked the villages of Korondo and Dilapoko, killing two. A woman was also seriously injured in Korondo.
Gunmen, suspected of being Fulani, attacked the villages of Korondo and Dilapoko, killing two.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: An anti-Balaka element reportedly threw a grenade at Chadian soldiers, before being killed by French troops.
Ex-Seleka killed three cattle breeders from Chad and stole their cattle.
17 people were abducted by the LRA in the village of Yangou, 90km from Sam Ouandja. The LRA also looted various properties.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Clashes between Anti-Balaka and Cameroonian elements of MISCA following the launch of a disarmament operation in Potopoto district of Berberati. One Anti-Balaka dead and four wounded persons, including two MISCA soldiers.
When ex-Seleka refused to pay a fine for killing cattle breeders and stealing their cattle, the cattle owners attacked and occupied the village of Votmata. No reports of casualties.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Chadian elements of MISCA on patrol in Zefio, 6km from Kaga Bandoro, attacked Anti-Balaka. The clash killed seven: six Anti-Balaka and one civilian.
Anti-Balaka killed a Muslim civilian on Miskine bridge, a few hundred meters from the Central Mosque in Bangui where he was a refugee.
Anti-Balaka fired on people who were travelling by taxi, causing injuries.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Gunfire heard as clashes continue between Anti-Balaka and Chadian elements of MISCA. No deaths reported.
Looting: Anti-Balaka looted and destroyed all the shops and homes of Muslims in Poumayassi village.
Anti-Balaka destroyed homes in Wawa village, 70km from Grimari.
Ex-Seleka based in Bambari, having heard that Anti-Balaka had raided Poumayassi village, confronted and clashed with Anti-Balaka in Poumayassi. One death reported.

column9: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Anti-Balaka attempted to attack a man who had converted to Islam. When Burundian peacekeepers intervened, and they were fired upon, injuring one. One Anti-Balaka killed.
A man walking through the town was tied up by ex-Seleka, who took him to their base and killed him.
A farmer was kidnapped by ex-Seleka.

Suspected Chadian soldiers attacked Ngbengbere village, 45km from the border with Chad, leaving 7 dead, 21 injured and more than 500 homes burned. Similar attacks took place in Paoua a few days prior. The gunmen returned to Chad after the attack.

column9: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014); Women (Central African Republic)
column17: Having abducted two girls from a bar, Anti-Balaka asked moto taxi drivers to take them to Benz-Vi, where they then stabbed one of the drivers and stole the motorbikes. They fled upon sighting a MISCA patrol approach nearby.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: A man was killed by Chadian elements of MISCA who opened fire on him as he bathed in the Badiri River.

column6: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: A youth was abducted by Chadian elements of MISCA.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: During a disarmament operation, Sangaris beat an ex-FACA soldier, who subsequently had to go to the hospital for treatment.
Armed men kill a Christian merchant and two young girls who were passing by. The gunmen are believed by some to be young armed men who engage in criminal acts in the area.
Armed men kidnapped a resident of M'Poko & killed him in Zone 11
Anti-Balaka kidnapped a young man in M'Poko. He was released when his parents paid a ransom
Three bodies were found in a hole near an ex-Seleka base. One of these people had been arrested and detained by ex-Seleka a few days previous.

column9: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Anti-Balaka attacked Dekoa, clashing with ex-Seleka in the locality, who were supported by Chadian elements of Misca from Kaga-Bandoro. Clashes last for two days. Red Cross reports 37 bodies collected, many of which were civilians hit by stray bullets.
Detonation: A member of Anti-Balaka detonated a grenade in Gobongo. Intended target not known.
Property destruction: Unidentified individuals set an Evangelical church alight. No casualties.
Armed Fulani herders open fire on civilians. The Anti-Balaka intervened to defend the civilians. The fighting lasted two days and several people were killed.
The mayor of Bilolo was shot by Anti-Balaka after he tried to intervene in a disagreement between Anti-Balaka and local youths. He later died in hospital on April 14th 2014.
Anti-Balaka kidnapped 3 people in MPoko on April 8, 9 & 10. 2 young men were released after 3 days
A young man was returning to Ramandji neighbourhood, M'Poko, where he was killed
Muslim women and children are abducted and held by Anti-Balaka at their base.
Anti Balaka killed three people in Damara, Ombella Mpoko, after a clash over cattle stealing.
Clashes continue for a second day between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka. Red Cross reports 37 bodies collected, many of which are civilians hit by stray bullets.
Fighting continues between Anti-Balaka and armed Fulani herders. The fighting lasted two days and several people were killed.

column6: EUFOR RCA: European Union Force in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Deployment:The first EUFOR RCA soldiers are deployed; they begin operating in Bangui on patrols.
Muslim women and children are abducted and held by Anti-Balaka at their base.
Anti-Balaka kidnapped 3 people in MPoko on April 8, 9 & 10. 2 young men were released after 3 days
The body of a tortured man was found in M'Poko camp
Ex-Seleka were heard firing shots at the entrance to Dekoa. They also began searching homes.
Clashes between armed Fulani herders and Anti-Balaka, 10km from the Bozoum-Bouar road.
A man was shot by ex-Seleka while he was on the phone to a parent, describing the security situation in Bambari to them. Ex-Seleka suspected him of speaking with Anti-Balaka.
Two French Sangaris soldiers injured when a grenade was thrown at them.

column9: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: A group of young Muslims were mobilised by ex-Seleka to throw stones against Sangaris and MISCA. A Central African was killed during this act.

column9: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Sangaris and Congolese MISCA soldiers were ambushed by ex-Seleka in front of the hospital. Two MISCA soldiers were injured.
Anti-Balaka kidnapped 3 people in MPoko on April 8, 9 & 10. 2 young men were released after 3 days
Anti-Balaka kidnapped a man who stole from another family. He was released 2 days later

column9: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: A convoy of twenty trucks that was evacuating the last 540 Muslims from Bossangoa to Gore in Chad was attacked by Anti-Balaka as it passed through Boguila. The convoy was escorted by Chadian soldiers of MISCA who were also leaving CAR, thus leading to clashes.
Anti-Balaka threw a grenade into a slum, killing a Muslim mother.
Anti-Balaka kidnapped an ex-Seleka in Bangui. He was released four days later in an official ceremony. He was allegedly well treated in detention.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Clashes continue between Anti-Balaka and Chadian elements of MISCA after Anti-Balaka attacked a convoy of fleeing Muslims the previous day. Casualties unknown.
Anti-Balaka kidnapped a boy who was accused of witchcraft. He was released the next day with indications of beating.
Ex-Seleka arrived in Grimari with Muslim herders. They knocked down doors, set fire to homes and slit the throats of several people.
Anti-Balaka kidnapped a Muslim man in Bangui. He was released three days later in an official ceremony. He was allegedly well treated in detention.
Ex-Seleka attack an Anti-Balaka base, killing at least two.
Following an ex-Seleka attack on their base, Anti-Balaka counter-attack an ex-Seleka base. Sangaris intervene in an attempt to stop the fighting. Several deaths reported.

column6: FSRJ: Special Forces of Revolutionary Justice
column17: Between the 14th and 18th April 2014, 17 people were killed in clashes between armed Fulani and the Special Forces of Revolutionary Justice, after the Fulani stormed Bedam, Begouladje 1 and 2, Bekadon and Bingui villages. The armed Fulani comprised of Mbarara, Misseria and Ouda of Sudan, Alagamba of Nigeria, and Zaghawa of Chad.

Three people of the same family, including one child, were killed when unidentified armed men entered their home, shot them and ransacked the house. Relatives of the family transported the bodies to the prime minister to express their anger at the recurring insecurity in Bangui.
Six civilians were killed and houses burned in Blogue village, 20km from Boguila, during an attack by ex-Seleka, supported by armed Fulani.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka in Bea village. No reports of casualties.
Anti-Balaka responded to the attack on Blogue village by ex-Seleka and Fulani by kidnapping eight Fulani. These three children and five women were later released on 16th April 2014.

column7: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Between December 2013 to June 2014, at least 10-12 children were reportedly sexually abused by French soldiers and AU peacekeepers at a camp for IDPs at MPoko airport, according to an internal UN report.
Clashes continue for a second day after Anti-Balaka counter-attacked an ex-Seleka base. Casualties unknown.

column6: FSRJ: Special Forces of Revolutionary Justice
column17: Between the 14th and 18th April 2014, 17 people were killed in clashes between armed Fulani and the Special Forces of Revolutionary Justice, after the Fulani stormed Bedam, Begouladje 1 and 2, Bekadon and Bingui villages. The armed Fulani comprised of Mbarara, Misseria and Ouda of Sudan, Alagamba of Nigeria, and Zaghawa of Chad.
The bishop of Bossangoa, three other priests and his driver were abducted by ex-Seleka in Batangafo. They were released the following morning thanks to the intervention of MISCA.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Ex-Seleka arrived in Bouca, firing gunshots, but were pushed back by the Gabonese contingent of MISCA who were present in the town.

column6: FSRJ: Special Forces of Revolutionary Justice
column17: Between the 14th and 18th April 2014, 17 people were killed in clashes between armed Fulani and the Special Forces of Revolutionary Justice, after the Fulani stormed Bedam, Begouladje 1 and 2, Bekadon and Bingui villages. The armed Fulani comprised of Mbarara, Misseria and Ouda of Sudan, Alagamba of Nigeria, and Zaghawa of Chad.
The parish priest of Paoua Diocese was killed by armed Fulani herders who were close to ex-Seleka.
The village chief of Yobe was shot dead by Anti-Balaka when he resisted while they tried to steal his bike.

column6: FSRJ: Special Forces of Revolutionary Justice
column17: Between the 14th and 18th April 2014, 17 people were killed in clashes between armed Fulani and the Special Forces of Revolutionary Justice, after the Fulani stormed Bedam, Begouladje 1 and 2, Bekadon and Bingui villages. The armed Fulani comprised of Mbarara, Misseria and Ouda of Sudan, Alagamba of Nigeria, and Zaghawa of Chad.
A priest was killed by gunmen believed to be Fulani and ex-Seleka who opened fire on him while he was in traffic on a motorcycle. They then mutilated his body.
Ex-Seleka stormed the hospital in Bambari, threatening the staff and telling them not to treat anyone with injuries from the incidents that recently occurred in Grimari.
Armed men, suspected to be ex-Seleka, attacked Libala village, 55km from Gamboula, killing three and wounding others.

column9: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Fifteen Muslims armed with guns and knives started shooting at civilians in Yakite. MISCA intervened, killing three attackers and arresting three others. No civilian casualties reported.

column6: FSRJ: Special Forces of Revolutionary Justice
column17: Between the 14th and 18th April 2014, 17 people were killed in clashes between armed Fulani and the Special Forces of Revolutionary Justice, after the Fulani stormed Bedam, Begouladje 1 and 2, Bekadon and Bingui villages. The armed Fulani comprised of Mbarara, Misseria and Ouda of Sudan, Alagamba of Nigeria, and Zaghawa of Chad.
Armed Fulani burned Bongoro village and killed two people.
A man was dragged from his home in Saragba village, 1km from Batangafo, attacked and injured by ex-Seleka who mistook him for Anti-Balaka.
Father Alain Gbangbanzi, priest of Alindao Diocese, was abducted by ex-Seleka. He was released the following day.
93 Muslims were transported from Bangui to Bambari in convoy, accompanied by vehicles from Sangaris, UNHCR and IOM. The convoy was pelted with stones as it passed through the town of Sibut.

After being fired upon after intervening in clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka, Sangaris chased down the Anti-Balaka, killing several of them. Witnesses say that most of those killed were armed, but three did not appear to be.

Clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka. Sangaris tried to intervene but was fired upon. A number of people killed in the clashes, including civilians, dozens injured, and nearly 10,000 people displacd in the town.

column8: AU-RTF: African Union-led Regional Task Force (2011-)
column17: Confrontation between the LRA and Ugandan troops of the Regional Task Force led to the capture of Charles Okello, an LRA commander. Three women and seven children captives were rescued.
Ex-Seleka entered Bouca from Batangafo in three vehicles. They fired shots in the air for two hours to scare the population.
Anti-Balaka clashed with ex-Seleka, who raided Bouca the previous day. Calm restored by afternoon. Two believed dead on each side, but true death toll unknown as many people still in hiding.
A soldier & his wife were killed in Bazanga
A group of hunters were attacked by the LRA and had their equipment stolen by them.
Ex-Seleka take control of Bouca.
The people of Boali took to the streets to protest against a rumoured replacement of the Congolese MISCA troops by the Burundian contingent.
Ex-Seleka attacked the town of Botto. Exact death toll currently unknown, but multiple reports of dead bodies on the street.
Five people, including two women, were attacked 20km from Kaga-Bandoro on the Kabo road by Mbarara Fulani while they returned to their village after participating in a training workshop.
Anti-Balaka attacked the Km5 area, but met resistance from a self-defense group. Two bodies were seen after this attack.

column9: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Unidentified armed men opened fire on a joint Sangaris and MISCA patrol convoy. International forces return gunfire. Seven deaths reported.
Armed Fulani from Chad attack Bemal village - dozens of persons were killed, several others wounded, and houses burned.
""One national INGO aid worker was assaulted in Bangui while on his way home after work. He later died in the hospital as a result of his injuries.""
The LRA opened fire on a vehicle of civilians. They killed one and kidnapped another, who was released some hours later.
The LRA opened fire on a vehicle of civilians in Kolongo village. They killed one and kidnapped another, who was released some hours later.

column9: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Health Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: 18 people, including three MSF staff, were killed when suspected ex-Seleka and people of Fula ethnicity targeted a hospital in Nanga Boguila, following an attack in the town. MSF have since suspended their activities in this area. Ex-Seleka strongly denies this attack.

""Three INGO staff members were killed by armed ex-Seleka members during a meeting with community leaders to discuss medical care and access. The ex-Seleka proceeded to rob the office. Fifteen other individuals, all local chiefs, were killed as well.""

Unidentified assailants abducted a girl as she was washing clothes along the Oubangui river in Bangui. She was found dead the following day, having suffered from rape and torture at the hands of the group.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: A Cameroonian MISCA soldier was killed in an incident in Paoua.
Four people were killed when suspected ex-Seleka and people of Fula ethnicity attacked Nanga.
Ex-Seleka killed 2 people in Boningi village
More than a hundred women and youths marched to show their dissatisfaction with the proposed transfer of ex-Seleka to Sibut.
Ex-Seleka kill five in Kouki village.

column16: RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: Ex-Seleka kill seven people in Bodjomo and burn the village.
As soon as a convoy of Muslims left PK-12, hundreds of youths invaded PK-12 to loot and raze abandoned homes. More than 200 homes were destroyed.

Two civilians were killed and six others wounded when Anti-Balaka ambushed a convoy of Muslim Peuls fleeing violence in Bangui. MISCA troops returned fire on the armed men but were unable to catch them.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Two civilians were killed and six others wounded when Anti-Balaka ambushed a convoy of Muslim Peuls fleeing violence in Bangui. MISCA troops returned fire on the armed men but were unable to catch them.

column7: Students (Central African Republic); Teachers (Central African Republic)
column17: Students from the University of Bangui demonstrated on campus in support of the teachers strike. They barricaded office entrances, trapping administration staff inside.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
