As Sangaris attempted to disarm some elements of FACA, passers by started throwing stones at the Sangaris soldiers.
Unknown gunmen kill a Muslim trader in Selim near Zemio, raising tensions among religious communities in the town resulting in clashes a few days later.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column9: Military Forces of France (2012-2017); EUFOR RCA: European Union Force in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Ex-Seleka demonstrated in Bangui against plans to send them back to their rural homes. They barricaded the roads with pieces of iron, wood and car parts, and were armed. Soldiers of MINUSCA, Sangaris and EUFOR-RCA were deployed to contain the ex-rebel protesters. Shots were fired into the air by both sides.

Armed Fulani herders demanded that residents of Balenguere village give them food. When they refused, they attacked the village, killing two people, and taking others hostage. Several injuries also reported.
More than thirty houses were burned in Bougou village, 35 km from Zemio on the Rafai road, by armed Muslims from Selima village (35 km from Bangassou).

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Police were protecting a crowd of 28 Muslims (who were reportedly ex-Seleka) from an angry crowd. Ex-Seleka based in Bangui shot at the police, who returned fire. One death reported, and three injuries on the side of ex-Seleka.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Looting: Shooting erupted in the Camp Beal area followed by looting on the part of ex-Seleka, leading to an intervention of international forces.
Unknown gunmen abduct three Seleka and kill one of them, leaving his body near Radio ama in Bangui. One managed to escape, while the other was injured.
Students of the National School of the Arts staged a protest to demand that the government pay nine months of scholarships arrears, and to denounce the poor conditions of in the institution.
Looting: Ex-Seleka looted, burned four shops and fired shots into the air on Avenue des Martyrs.

Armed Muslims attacked the population of Zemio, notably the Christians. Several houses belonging to Christians were ransacked and burned, and gunshots were heard. Three people were killed and 13 wounded. Many residents have fled to the bush.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; RCA (Central African Republic); USAID
column17: MINUSCA peacekeepers attempted to disarm some Anti-Balaka suspected of being thieves in Cantounier. Anti-Balaka fired on MINUSCA, leaving at least seven people dead and dozens injured.

column9: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Ex-Seleka protested once again against the plans to relocate them to other regions of the country. Some ex-Seleka were armed, but there we no reports of any incidents. The protest was contained by Sangaris, MINUSCA and EUFOR-RCA troops.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: A MINUSCA convoy was attacked by Anti-Balaka at Kabo village (20km from Boali). An Anti-Balaka element was killed during the exchange of gunfire while two MINUSCA soldiers were wounded.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Prison Guards
column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: After a fellow inmate died from TB, prisoners of Ngaragba prison rioted against the staff. MINUSCA intervened and calmed the situation after dialogue with a representative of the prisoners. One prisoner died during the riot and 13 were injured, while one MINUSCA peacekeeper was seriously wounded, and six others injured.
A man suspected by the Anti-Balaka of being an ex-Seleka fighter left the Carnot enclave to visit the town center. Anti-Balaka captured and lynched him near the market.

column6: PCUD: Central African Party for Unity and Development
column17: The Anti-Balaka announced officially its commitment to abandoning the armed struggle with a view to transforming its armed wing into a political organisation. The movement therefore transformed itself into a political movement, which is to be known henceforth as the Central African Party for Unity and Development (PCUD).

In late November 2014 a Peuhl man was attacked by the Anti-Balaka when he tried to leave Carnot at night with his wife to flee to Cameroon. The attackers tried to cut off his hand, broke the bones of his feet with machetes, and the next morning slit his throat, killing him.
Thirty elements of the LRA kidnapped several people, including children, from the village of Fode. 15 abductees later managed to escape.

column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Gunmen attacked members of the mission supporting the transition to a new prefect in Bamingui Bangoran, leaving three injured, including the new prefect. The incident took place in Ndele.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: The FPRC, a political party headed by a former Seleka leader, entered Kaga-Bandoro and took control of the town.

column16: Resolve Crisis Initiative; RCA (Central African Republic); UNHCR
column17: A group of Mbororo reportedly attacked the community of Bahr, CAR, early in the morning. They reportedly killed 3 civilians and injured 2 others, and set fire to around 40 households. The assailants also looted the community shop.

Three men and two women were kidnapped by members of the LRA in Kouango, 5km from Mboki. Food and other goods were also stolen. Others reports state that 9 people were kidnapped, with eight later escaping on 5th December 2014.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Shots were fired between the Rwandan contingent of MINUSCA and an unidentified armed group in Gobongo and Fouh neighbourhoods. No fatalities.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; RCA (Central African Republic)
column17: Ex-Seleka killed an element of FACA and seriously injured another as the FACA prepared for the arrival of the president of the National Transitional Council, Alexander Ferdinand Nguendet, in Bambari. A Seleka rebel was also killed.
Suspected Anti-Balaka gunmen kill a Peul taxi driver in Bambari. Peuls from the Seleka militia carried out revenge kilings in the town following the incident.
A member of Anti-Balaka was recognised by a group of people in Bouaka village as being responsible for the killing of some of their parents and burning down their house. They beat him to death.

column8: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: A local administrative building was set on fire in Bria, CAR, during the night. The identity of the culprits is not yet known.

After a Peul taxi driver was found dead in Bambari, Peul members of the Seleka militia launched reprisals against Christians, leaving dozens of people dead, several others injured and dozens of houses burned.

column6: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column17: En route to the town of Bateldje (25km from Kabo), Babe Laddes men killed five people.

column6: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column17: Baba Laddes men killed a man on the bridge in Vafio.
Fulani herders abducted and killed two men in Belarmon, 40km from Baboua.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka in the villages of Tomboi and Karoungba (20-30km from Batangafo). Eight Anti-Balaka and eight ex-Seleka killed, and eight injuries on the side of ex-Seleka.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka in the villages of Tomboi and Karoungba (20-30km from Batangafo). Eight Anti-Balaka and eight ex-Seleka killed, and eight injuries on the side of ex-Seleka.
Fulani herders abducted and killed a woman and burned 42 homes in Ndongori, 70km from Baboua.
Two people were killed by Fulani herders in Bolome (24km from Batangafo) and Gbadene villages.
Nine people, including a 13 year old girl, were abducted by the LRA.

column7: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016); Women (Central African Republic)
column17: Over 100 women in uniform - those of the police, gendarmerie and MINUSCA - participated in a march to protest against violence against women and girls. This march was held as part of the 16 Days of Activism Against Gender-Based Violence campaign.
A group of Muslims organised a march to demand the resignation of Alexander Ferdinand Nguendet, chairman of the National Transitional Council (NTC), in Bornou neighbourhood of Bambari.
Two people were killed by Fulani herders in Bolome (24km from Batangafo) and Gbadene villages.

column6: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Arrests: Chadian rebel Abdel Kader Baba Ladde, leader of Chads Popular Front for Recovery (FPR), was arrested by MINUSCA officers in Kabo district, close to the Chadian border.

column9: Aid Workers (Central African Republic); Health Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: An NGO ambulance that was transporting a child and his father was attacked 17km from Boda by an armed group presumed to comprise Anti-Balaka elements. The vehicle was found 8km from Boda the following day. The child was unharmed, but his father and the driver had been beaten.

Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka from 11th December to 14th December 2014 in villages surrounding Batangafo, including Kambakota, Mbali, Doubabounou, Karagba and Kagomon. This has resulted in six deaths, including the mayor of Mbali and his son.

Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka from 11th December to 14th December 2014 in villages surrounding Batangafo, including Kambakota, Mbali, Doubabounou, Karagba and Kagomon. This has resulted in six deaths, including the mayor of Mbali and his son.

Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka from 11th December to 14th December 2014 in villages surrounding Batangafo, including Kambakota, Mbali, Doubabounou, Karagba and Kagomon. This has resulted in six deaths, including the mayor of Mbali and his son.

Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka from 11th December to 14th December 2014 in villages surrounding Batangafo, including Kambakota, Mbali, Doubabounou, Karagba and Kagomon. This has resulted in six deaths, including the mayor of Mbali and his son.
An unidentified group of armed actors attacked staff from the Agency for Technical Development and Cooperation (ACTED). Two staff injured.
A member of the ex-Seleka shot dead a man in his own home

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: A young girl was raped by a member of the Congolese contingent of MINUSCA.

Anti-Balaka counter attack the armed Muslims that threw a grenade and killed a member of the Anti-Balaka. Members of ex-Seleka arrive from a nearby town to join the clashes. The clashes continue between the 16th and 18th November 2014. 28 deaths reported in total.
A member of the Anti-Balaka is killed by a grenade thrown by a group of Muslims.

Anti-Balaka counter attack the armed Muslims that threw a grenade and killed a member of the Anti-Balaka. Members of ex-Seleka arrive from a nearby town to join the clashes. The clashes continue between the 16th and 18th November 2014. 28 deaths reported in total.

Anti-Balaka counter attack the armed Muslims that threw a grenade and killed a member of the Anti-Balaka. Members of ex-Seleka arrive from a nearby town to join the clashes. The clashes continue between the 16th and 18th November 2014. 28 deaths reported in total.
Four people were killed and four injured in Maromba village during an attack by the ex-Seleka.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka and Peul, resulting in at least 12 deaths.

Combo Bombo village, 37km from Amada-Gaza, was attacked by a group of armed Peuhls in retaliation for the theft of their cattle by Anti-Balaka elements, resulting in 7 deaths, the burning of several houses and the displacement of an unverified number of people who sought refuge in the bush.
Ex-Seleka rebels and armed Peul herders launched a reprisal attack on the village of Kouango, killing at least eight people, injuring dozens and setting several homes on fire.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Anti-Balaka elements clashed with MINUSCA troops in Berberati. One Anti-Balaka member and one civilian were killed.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka. Two ex-Seleka killed and ""a large number"" of Anti-Balaka fighters killed.

column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: Clashes occurred between Anti-Balaka and UPC members in Gbotobadia village, 30km from Bambari. There were at least four UPC militiamen killed and four others wounded, one Anti-Balaka fighter killed, and three civilians also died.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: MINUSCA and Anti-Balaka clashed in Nola. A peacekeeper and one civilian were slightly injured during the clash and four Anti-Balaka members were apprehended and disarmed.
Armed Peuhl clashed with Anti-Balaka in Nola, killing 8 and forcing populations to flee to the bush.
Armed Peuhl attack Gamboula, killing 10.
At least eight people were killed in the villages of Bombo and Tanga in attacks by Mbororo militia. All houses in the villages were burned down.
At least eight people were killed in the villages of Bombo and Tanga in attacks by Mbororo militia. All houses in the villages were burned down.
Two ex-Seleka killed by Anti-Balaka members.

column9: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 11 armed elements of the LRA moved into Moussa village in Mbomou prefecture and took several villagers hostage and injured others. MINUSCA troops in Rafai responded by moving into the area, resulting in the LRA elements to flee, leaving behind all hostages.

Clashes between Anti-Balaka and Peul militia in Bambari over two days. Large numbers of Peuls, Muslims and Selekas reportedly arrived in the town following the clashes, raising fears among populations.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: MINUSCA arrested a member of Anti-Balaka. Displeased by this, other Anti-Balaka members exchanged fire with MINUSCA.
LRA elements attacked Dabiapali village, 5 km from Moussa (Mbomou prefecture). The group took six hostages and fled in the direction of Zemio.

Clashes between Anti-Balaka and Peul militia in Bambari over two days. Large numbers of Peuls, Muslims and Selekas reportedly arrived in the town following the clashes, raising fears among populations.

column8: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
column17: Clashes between Congolese soldiers of MISCA and Anti-Balaka left two people dead in Loppo village, near Nola. The MISCA soldiers had come to the area to encourage populations to return to their homes following prior clashes in the area.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Anti-Balaka stabbed a member of FACA to death after he refused to hand over his weapon.

column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; RCA (Central African Republic)
column17: The Muslim community of Bornou neighbourhood erected barriers and threw stones at a Sangaris patrol, as they did not want them to patrol Bornou. At least one death and two injuries as a result.
Following the events of the previous day, Muslims held anti-French protests across Bambari, erecting barricades.
A member of the Anti-Balaka shot dead two brothers from whom he had bought fuel by the roadside and owed money to.
Ex-Seleka and Fulani attack Mbali village, killing five.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: MINUSCA peacekeepers from DRC allegedly sexually abused 4 children at the Ngakobo camp in Ouaka prefecture between 2014-2015.
In Kolo village, Anti-Balaka bury alive a woman and her child, as she had been accused of witchcraft by one of her husbands other wives.
Fulani herders set fire to Bomian village.
Fulani herders set fire to Gbanto village.
Ex-Seleka and Fulani attack Mengue village, 7km from Batangafo, killing one and injuring a number of others.
Fulani herders set fire to Ngoumbo village.
Arrests: An LRA commander named Dominic Ongwen was arrested by former Seleka forces and handed over to US forces in Haute-Kotto.

Five people were killed and several injured between 6th and 7th of January 2015 in clashes in Bambari between two Anti-Balaka groups. It is reported that the victims were, for the most part, Anti-Balaka.
Fulani herders set fire to homes in Boyo village, in revenge for a confrontation with Anti-Balaka.

Five people were killed and several injured between 6th and 7th of January 2015 in clashes in Bambari between two Anti-Balaka groups. It is reported that the victims were, for the most part, Anti-Balaka.
Following the clashes in Bambari, some Anti-Balaka went to the house of a local community leader and killed him, accusing him of betraying them. The attackers also burned his house.
Further clashes between two Anti-Balaka groups. One death reported.
Armed groups reportedly based in Cameroon attacked Boyango village, west of Koui (Ouham Pende Province). One person was killed and another injured, and houses were burned.
Fulani herders attack health workers at Ndogoli village, 176km from Bouar, killing one and injuring others. One health worker remains missing as of 10th January 2015.
A hunter was shot and beaten to death by an unidentified armed group 30km from Obo.

A large crowd of people protested at the Sangaris base in Bria, calling for their removal from CAR. The demonstrators reportedly trew rocks and grenades at Sangaris forces, while the Sangaris were said to have fired shots to disperse them. The demonstrators erected barricades throughout the town and took control of the aerodrome the following two days.
Around 30 people were assaulted by armed Anti-Balaka. Sangaris intervened to stop the beatings.

A large crowd of people protested at the Sangaris base in Bria, calling for their removal from CAR. The demonstrators reportedly trew rocks and grenades at Sangaris forces, while the Sangaris were said to have fired shots to disperse them. The demonstrators erected barricades throughout the town and took control of the aerodrome the following two days.

A large crowd of people protested at the Sangaris base in Bria, calling for their removal from CAR. The demonstrators reportedly trew rocks and grenades at Sangaris forces, while the Sangaris were said to have fired shots to disperse them. The demonstrators erected barricades throughout the town and took control of the aerodrome the following two days.

column7: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Around a hundred police auxiliaries protested in Bangui calling for the revision of their status to be fully integration to the national forces.

In the village of Beboi 4, 38km from Paoua, a group of men beat to death a village leader who had just returned to the village, having been in Cameroon since 2013. They accused him of betraying them and being an accomplice of the ex-Seleka.
Staff of the Association of Muslims of Africa NGO protested outside their building to demand the payment of salary arrears. They blocked to entrance to prevent the head of the NGO from entering.
Sixteen people were killed in the village of Konga, in Kouango, by a group believed to be ex-Seleka. Several houses were also burned.
A hunter was shot dead and his body burned by a group of unidentified people. Witnesses claim that the attackers were Sudanese.

People protested in Berberati to express their anger against the Congolese contingent of MINUSCA, which they feel does not help prevent crime. This event followed the recent killing of a hunter by unidentified individuals.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: A firefight broke out between the Anti-Balaka and the Cameroonian contingent of MINUSCA, which resulted in MINUSCA arresting General Andjilo of the Anti-Balaka.
Anti-Balaka protested the arrest of General Andjilo on the 18th and 19th January 2015 in Boy-Rabe. Several witnesses reported kidnapping attempts and robberies, and reports of one death on the 18th.
Anti-Balaka protested the arrest of General Andjilo on the 18th and 19th January 2015 in Boy-Rabe. Several witnesses reported kidnapping attempts and robberies.
The brother of Pachomius Pabandji, a well known journalist, was beaten and kidnapped by unidentified men, close to where the Iraqi MINUSCA employee was taken.

A female French aid worker who was working for the Catholic medical organisation CODIS was kidnapped alongside a local co-worker by the Anti-Balaka when they seized their vehicle. They were later released on 23/01/2014.

column9: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: An Iraqi UN staff member who works for MINUSCA was kidnapped by the Anti-Balaka. She was released the following day.

column8: EUFOR RCA: European Union Force in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: A Spanish convoy of the EUFOR-RCA force exchanged fire with an armed man and a Muslim militia in Bangui. The armed man was shot and injured and one minor injury on the part of the armed Muslims reported.

column8: EUFOR RCA: European Union Force in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: EUFOR-RCA revisit the scene of the confrontation in Kokoro for investigation. A rocket is fired at their convoy, causing them to fire warning shots. No casualties.
About 400 Muslims protested in Bangui to express their dissatisfaction at being excluded from the reconciliation process.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; IRIN; Centrafrique Presse Info; AP
column17: An 8 person team conducting public consultations ahead of the national peace and reconciliation forum were kidnapped by FPRC elements of the Seleka militia in Kaga Bandoro. The team included the regional prefect, one of his deputies and the towns mayor. They were released the next day, but their vehicle and other equipment were kept.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: FPRC elements of the Seleka militia intercepted convoys of government officials around Bria, preventing them from carrying out a planned consultation mission in the town.
Former Seleka and armed Fulani attacked villages in the Nana Gribizi region, killing at least 5 and injuring others.

column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016); RJ: Revolution and Justice
column16: RCA (Central African Republic); IRIN; AP; Radio Ndeke Luka; Centrafrique Presse Info; AFP
column17: The Minister of Youth and Sports (and leader of the Revolutionary Justice movement) was kidnapped by armed men believed to be anti-Balaka militiamen as he came out of church. He was taken at a roadblock 10km outside of Bangui, and a number of vehicles were stolen at the same time.
People demonstrated in support of the consultation team which arrived in Bambari, at the same time as a counter-protest against the consultations.

Muslim youths protested against the arrival of a consultation team. The youths looted the home of the Prefect of Ouaka and took a company car. Weapons fire was also heard, although no injuries were reported.
""9 people were killed in attacks by armed groups in Botto village (Nana Grebizi Province).""
8 people were killed in an attack on Agoudou-manga village, and another 4 in Mbrobaga village, both near Bambari, encouraging residents from Bambari, Ngakobo and Kouango to flee.
8 people were killed in an attack on Agoudou-manga village, and another 4 in Mbrobaga village, both near Bambari, encouraging residents from Bambari, Ngakobo and Kouango to flee.
28 people were kidnapped near Nzako. There were 9 unidentified men who attacked the people before capturing them and demanding a ransom.

column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column16: RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: 4 vehicles carrying FPRC elements of the Seleka threatened a consultation delegation escorted by 21 Sangaris vehicles in Bamingui near Ndele. An Operation Sangaris helicopter was sent to intercept the armed men and fired shots. The rebels mention that the shots left two killed and four injured among civilians, and destroyed 4 vehicles, while the Sangaris say no casualty was reported.
A protest march against the abduction of the Minister of Youth and Sports was held by various sports federations and youth associations.
A pastor, his wife and 4 other residents of a village in the north of the country were abducted. All were released the next day except for the pastor.
An unidentified group of youths killed a woman they believed was a witch. Police are seeking the suspects.
A young girl was reportedly abused by Ugandan soldiers based in Obo.
At least 3 people were killed and several others injured in attacks by armed Mbarara Fulani from the Kabo region on villages in the region of Kaga Bandoro.
Public sector students protested, demanding the government respect their right to education.

column7: Military Forces of France (2012-2017); MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Residents of Bambari marched to demand a return to normal for their city, and the departure of Seleka General Ali Darassa. Sangaris and MINUSCA forces were present to ensure the safety of those involved.

Around 100 young people armed with Kalashnikovs and knives gathered outside the Central Mosque IDP site and threatened to attack the displaced there following the death of one of their friends whom they accused the displaced of killing.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Former Seleka fighters and armed pastoralists attacked the Ngakobo IDP site. UN peacekeepers secured the site and repelled the attack. 7 civilians were wounded during the fighting.
A man abducted by Fulani herders on 05/02/2015 was found dead near the Sali river outside of Batangafo.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Former Seleka rebels attacked a sugar factory in Ngakobo where IDPs were seeking refuge, which is guarded by Congolese peacekeepers in Ngakobo. One of the attackers, a Fulani, was killed, while several other people were wounded. The attackers fired rockets at the sugar factory.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: A Burundian soldier was killed by ""one of his comrades"" in their lodgings at Bangui.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column9: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: Xinhua; RFI; AFP; Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: 7 rebels were killed, 9 wounded, and 20 arrested in clashes between FPRC elements of the Seleka militia and French/MINUSCA forces. The international forces notably carried our air raids on FPRC positions. MINUSCA forces claim to have taken control of public buildings formerly controlled by Seleka forces.
At least 10 people were killed and 12 others injured in an attack on Boloum, near Batangafo, attributed to armed Fulani.
An old man was found dead near Bornu. Weapons fire was heard in the area the day before. Residents of the area believe former Seleka were behind the killing.

Parts of the Muslim community protested against the eviction of a Seleka officer who had been offering them protection by international forces. They set up ""roadblocks that restricted the movement of more than 10 humanitarian vehicles.""
Leaders of some political parties, including the AFDT, ACDP, CPAPs and UPPRN, and their supporters marched to call for peace and demand full implementation of UN Security Council resolutions.

During the night of Feb.14-15 and the next morning gunfire and grenades were heard going off in PK5, a predominantly Muslim neighbourhood, following the killing of a Seleka by Anti-Balaka in the capital. Muslim militiamen killed 2 civilians in Pk5 neighborhood in retaliation the same evening.

A Seleka was killed by suspected Anti-Balaka forces near the Prime Ministers office as he was allegedly about to rob a motorcycle. Muslim militia carried out reprisal attacks against civilians later that day.
Armed Fulani attacked the village of Bolov, in the Batangafo area, killing a former anti-Balaka colonel and another man. MINUSCA elements were alerted and arrived at the village later.

During the night of Feb.14-15 and the next morning gunfire and grenades were heard going off in PK5, a predominantly Muslim neighbourhood, following the killing of a young Muslim the day before. 2 Muslims were killed during the violence.
Chadian rebels reportedly killed 3 Central Africans and 3 Congolese near Bakporo, CAR.

The killing of a young Muslim sparked violent protests in PK5, a predominantly Muslim area, including the closing of all shops. Demonstrators kidnapped 3 leaders of the Muslim community, who tried to calm them down before later releasing them. Anti-Balaka militia fighters fired their weapons and temporarily blocked traffic.

The population of Moussa, CAR, moved to Agoumar, CAR, as a result of the increasing insecurity. The next morning, some of the civilians went back to gather food and sighted 2 granaries in flames and noticed that cassava and potatoes had been stolen.

column7: Muslim Group (Central African Republic); Seleka Militia
column9: Refugees/IDPs (Central African Republic); Military Forces of France (2012-2017)
column17: Muslim and Seleka rioters threw rocks and grenades at IDPs and Sangari forces who were dismantling their barriers at Ouaka bridge in Bambari, leaving two IDPs killed and 15 injured. The rioters had been preventing access beyond the bridge for the past few days, preventing populations form accessing water and food.

column7: Anti-Balaka; MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Anti-Balaka members protested against the occupation of the Court of Appeals by Muslims, leading to clashes which killed 3 young Muslims and injured 10 others, and killed 2 anti-Balaka and injured 2. International forces fired teargas to disperse the crowds, and cleared the building. The secretary-general of the Bambari young Muslims association says they were fired on by international forces.
At least 2 people, including the mayor, were killed and several wounded in an attack on ""a village in northwest Central African Republic"" by armed Fulani and former Seleka rebels.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: A car which was discovered to have weapons in it broke down. Youths starting throwing stones at it and the occupants, which included a former Minister of Trade, before setting the car on fire. MINUSCA forces arrived to save the people on board, and fired tear gas to disperse the crowd.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Gendarmerie
column17: Anti-Balaka gunmen held up some Bouca gendarmerie in the ""4th District"" and stole their vehicle.
2 men were attacked by unidentified armed men believed to be attempted kidnappers. They both escaped but one of the men was wounded and later died at a health centre.

The association of ""Conscious Generation"" and some human rights activists held a sit-in at the ""UN rounadabout"" to demand that international forces impose strict disarmament on armed groups in the country.
The National Organization of Disabled People Associations of Central African (ONAPHA) protested over the death of a visually impaired person in Batangafo recently.

Students protested at the University of Bangui to demand the payment of scholarships. They erected barrcades and threw projectiles. Traffic was disrupted for several hours on the Avenue des Martyrs and Kongowara Avenue. French forces dispersed the protesters using tear gas.

A man who allegedly bewitched people was killed by 4 unidentified attackers. Later that day, the parents of the victim killed one of the attackers, who allegedly had proof of his involvement on his person. One other person was killed in connection with these incidents via ""mob justice"" but the circumstances were unclear.

column6: AU-RTF: African Union-led Regional Task Force (2011-)
column17: 5 LRA rebels have been killed by the Uganda contingent of the AU-RTF in Quanda, near Mboki.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Gendarmerie
column16: Centrafrique Presse Info; Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: 3 members of the Gendarmerie were killed in an ambush near the village of Nguerengou by unidentified armed men. The policemen were reportedly unarmed.

column9: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016); Women (Central African Republic)
column17: 2 elderly women were buried alive by residents of Bouchia who accused them of witchcraft. Police attempted to intervene as residents of Bouchia buried 2 women alive whom they accused of witchcraft, but the population attacked them and drove them off.
Thousands of women held a march for peace and national unity.
An ex-Seleka fighter was shot on his way to Bria when he refused an order by an ex-Seleka commander to disarm at the gate.
Women marched to protest violence against women and children and to demand respect for human rights, empowerment, and education.
A farmer was shot and killed allegedly by armed Fulani herders after a dispute between the farmer and a herder.

Following a MINUSCA operation to dismantle illegal roadblocks, Anti-Balaka fighters came back to Kouloumadja village outside of Bangui, accused a man of being a traitor, took his mother and brother hostage, then set fire to three houses.
Clashes were reported between armed groups in areas of Mambere Kadei, Nana-Grebizi, Nana-Mambere, Ouham, and Sangha-Mbaere provinces.
Clashes were reported between armed groups in areas of Mambere Kadei, Nana-Grebizi, Nana-Mambere, Ouham, and Sangha-Mbaere provinces.
Clashes were reported between armed groups in areas of Mambere Kadei, Nana-Grebizi, Nana-Mambere, Ouham, and Sangha-Mbaere provinces.
Clashes were reported between armed groups in areas of Mambere Kadei, Nana-Grebizi, Nana-Mambere, Ouham, and Sangha-Mbaere provinces.
Clashes were reported between armed groups in areas of Mambere Kadei, Nana-Grebizi, Nana-Mambere, Ouham, and Sangha-Mbaere provinces.
Around one hundred women staged a sit-in outside the MINUSCA headquarters to demand the restoration of the Central African Republic Armed Forces (FACA).
Angry students who believed their teachers were stealing school supplies rioted and injured at least one teacher.
France has begun a phased withdrawal of the soldiers participating in Operation Sangaris. So far total troop numbers have dropped from 2000 to 1700.
10 people were killed, including 2 students, and several others injured when unidentified gunmen, allegedly from Chad, attacked the Ngaoundaye area.
At least 10 people, including two children, were killed and several others injured during an armed-group attack in Nganoundaye, a few kilometres from the Chadian border
A state-certified nurse who had been seeking refuge in an IDP site was killed by alleged Anti-Balaka fighters.

column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: French forces responded to violence by armed individuals in the Boy Rabe neighbourhood of Bangui. They came under small arms and grenade attacks. MINUSCA and Central African Republic police forces joined French forces in dealing with the violence. At least 3 students and 1 French soldier were wounded during the fighting.

column6: EUFOR RCA: European Union Force in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column7: EUMAM: European Unions Military Advisory Mission in the Central African Republic (2015-)
column17: The EUFOR-RCA force has withdrawn from the Central African Republic and been replaced by a training and advisory mission called EUMAM (European Unions Military Advisory Mission in the Central African Republic).

At least 11 people were killed by a group of heavily armed Muslim herders after their cattle were allegedly stolen. They attacked villages in the Kaga-Bandoro area, resulting in residents vacating at least 9 villages and their residents seeking refuge in Kaga-Bandoro.
""An armed gang entered an INGO compound and assaulted the a guard and a driver. Both required some medical attention.""

On 24 March 2015, 3 people were killed and several others injured after a photographer who was allegedly drunk dropped a grenade in the middle of a meeting of five evangelical churches in Bozoum after they took away his camera. He attempted to flee but was captured by a group of young people who beat him to death. [size=at least several]
Protests occurred during/related to the meeting of five evangelical churches. This meeting was later the target of a grenade attack after a photographer was prevented from taking pictures.

column9: Christian Group (Central African Republic); Journalists (Central African Republic)
column17: 3 people were killed and several others injured after a photographer who was allegedly drunk dropped a grenade in the middle of a meeting of five evangelical churches after they took away his camera. He attempted to flee but was captured by a group of young people who beat him to death.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Arrests: A powerful anti-Balaka chief named Wilikondji, a.k.a. Songole, accused of ""serious crimes"" was arrested by National Police forces.

Between 9-12 Fulani herders were killed, at least 4 injured, and 50 others kidnapped by anti-Balaka fighters in attacks on 4 villages near Kaga Bandoro, allegedly in response to attacks carried out by Fulani during the weekend of Mar.21-22. Several herds of cattle were also stolen.
Young Muslims and Christians from Banguis 3rd arrondisement organized a peaceful march to demand the release of former Minister and ex-Seleka member Ousman Mahamat Ousman.
Chadian soldiers have raided a village in Ngaoundaye and kidnapped 4 women and 2 men as a reprisal for a recent attack by the CAR rebel group Revolution and Justice (RJ).
Two rival factions of former Seleka rebels battled for control of a customs post in Bema, 900km east of Bangui, leading residents to take refuge in the DR-Congo.
The Mayor of Kabo called for a general strike, which was followed by a march in support of Medecins Sans Frontieres, following a number of robberies in the town targeting MSF.
Ceasefire/Peacetalks:The Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka groups have signed a peace agreement to stop hostilities and commit to political stability.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: ReliefWeb; UN (unspecified); RCA (Central African Republic); Centrafrique Presse Info
column17: Around 400 residents of Kaga Bandoro armed with knives and other weapons attacked the MINUSCA base during protests to demand protection from armed Fulani who have recently attacked nearby villages. Gunfire was exchanged outside the base, while demonstrators threw stones and other objects at MINSUCA peacekeepers and attempted to set the camp on fire. Warning shots were fired by the peacekeepers. At least one protester was killed, and more than 12 people were wounded. Some reports have the number as high as 3.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Following the arrest of 2 suspected criminals who are Muslims in the Bornu 5 area of Bangui, a group of Fulani Muslims asked for their release. MINUSCA forces attempted to intervene to ease tensions. A violent confortation followed leading to 30 injuries, damage to the vehicles of the convoy (broken windows), at least a dozen houses burned and unconfirmed reports of a death.
LRA fighters took a hunter hostage in the Obo area but he managed to escape.

column7: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column16: RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: Police in the capital have gone on strike over ""non-consideration of their special status"" in relation to their advancement/promotions, impeding the functioning of the Ministry of Public Security and the General Police Directorate. They barricaded the road in front of the Directorate until the end of the month.
A young man was attacked and shot by armed Fulani herders in the village of Kangamon 1, 17km outside of Batangafo.

A group of young people beat a young Fulani Muslim to death whom they accused of setting a fire which led to the death of 2 children at an IDP site near Bambari. Other reports say the fire was started by the children.
Refugees from the DR-Congo staged a peaceful march to denounce their poor living conditions and demand the UNHCR take charge of them and their security guaranteed.

column7: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Police in the capital have renewed their strike and staged a demonstration in the capital.

A vehicle holding 8 passengers was fired on by unidentified armed assailants. Most of the passengers escaped but one man was taken hostage, and their goods were stolen. The vehicle was then set on fire.

column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: A march calling for freedom of mobility and goods and social cohesion was organized by the NGO Search for Common Ground. The marchers walked from Independence Avenue to Koudoukou Avenue. MINUSCA and gednarmerie forces kept watch over the march.
5 people were killed by Fulani herders after livestock was killed by farmers.
10 farmers were killed in 4 villages around the town of Kaga Bandoro by Fulani pastoralists armed with guns.

column7: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Police have engaged in a demonstration related to their strike to protest against inaction by the government to resolve their demands.
Vigilante group buried four woman suspected of witchcraft alive in Ngbodo village in Begoua commune.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Central Office for the Repression of Banditry
column17: A man was summarily executed by the OCRB in Bangui sometime between Apr.24-26.
The Coordination of Central African Muslim Organizations (COMUC) organized a peaceful march in the KM5 area of Bangui to demand more representation and respect for their rights.

column6: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column17: 1 person was killed and several were wounded in an attack allegedly carried out by FDPC rebels in which they opened indiscriminate fire on a bus in the Baboua area, traveling from Garoua-Mboulai to Bouar and Bangui.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: After the end of the Bangui Forum, what started as peaceful protests to demand the release of an anti-Balaka leader and the resignation of the president turned into riots as angry anti-Balaka leaders felt their demands were not being taken into account. Gunfire was heard, grenades went off, and barricades were raised, while MINUSCA forces responded with tear gas. Some witnesses reported anti-Balaka and former Seleka protesting together.

Several hundreds people, some in military uniforms, erected barricades to protest against the decisions of the Bangui Forum. The protesters blocked traffic with burning tires but were dispersed peacefully by police. They were allegedly largely composed of anti-Balaka members but anti-Balaka leadership said they did not condone the protests.

column6: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column17: Gunmen allegedly affiliated with the FDPC attacked public transport vehicles traveling from Gara to Mboulai and robbed the occupants, and shot a motorcyclist, injuring him. It was not clear if any deaths resulted. The head of the FDPC says their group does not recognize the forum in Bangui.
As many as 357 child soldiers were released by a combination of Christian and Muslim armed groups at 3 ceremonies in the town of Bambari.

After being expelled from adminsitrative buildings in Bria, former Seleka rebels have occupied active mining sites, including Carefree, Dawango, Kalaka, Aigbando, Mouka, and Ngbehidou Town near Bria, and demand tolls to allow entrance by miners.

After being expelled from adminsitrative buildings in Bria, former Seleka rebels have occupied active mining sites, including Carefree, Dawango, Kalaka, Aigbando, Mouka, and Ngbehidou Town near Bria, and demand tolls to allow entrance by miners.

1 person was killed when unidentified gunmen opened fire on residents of a mine site outside the town of Nzacko. They then went on to another site and assaulted more people, before stealing food and property.
As many as 12 people were abducted and at least 10 of those abducted were killed from a village between Bouca and Maraze Kozoro.
Armed Fulani allegedly from Lolo village in Cameroon attacked villages in the Gamboula area, including Koko where they were fought off by a self-defense group.

Armed Fulani allegedly from Lolo village in Cameroon attacked villages in the Gamboula area, including Saheri, Gbombo and Gadawa. At least 20 people were injured and others killed in the attack on Gbombo. Deaths were also reported during the other attacks (collectively coded as 10), houses were burned and at least 100 people were displaced in the violence.

5 young traders were attacked by armed Fulani herders outside of Kaga-Bandoro as they were returning from Baziki, with one of the traders being beaten by the gunmen before the rest abandoned their goods and bikes and fled.

A gunfight broke out between men on a motorcycle and unidentified assailants near the UN HQ in the PK5 area. At least one person, the nephew of an influentiel former Seleka leader, was injured. Two people were reportedly killed during the gun battle and subsequent riot.

column16: Centrafrique Presse Info; Radio Ndeke Luka; RFI
column17: A Muslim shopkeeper is killed on May 27 by suspected Anti-Balaka who had earlier stolen his car and asked him for money in exchange for the car in Pk5 of Bangui.

column16: Centrafrique Presse Info; Radio Ndeke Luka; RFI
column17: Following the murder of a Muslim shopkeeper on May 27 by suspected Anti-Balaka gunmen, some armed Muslim youths killed a young girl in retaliation and clashed with police, burning one of their vehicles.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Following a gunfight which broke out near the MINUSCA HQ, some angry Muslim youths gathered in front of a police station and demanded the police take a person injured in the clash to the hospital. The crowd threatened the police with knives and grenades before stealing a car, using it to transport the injured person, burning it, and returning to ransack the police station. Two people were reportedly killed during the gun battle and subsequent riot.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column16: RFI; Radio Ndeke Luka; Centrafrique Presse Info
column17: Following the murder of a Muslim shopkeeper on May 27 by suspected Anti-Balaka gunmen, some armed Muslim youths killed a young girl in retaliation and clashed with police, burning one of their vehicles.

column6: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column17: 1 person was killed and 4 wounded in an attack allegedly by FDPC rebels 18 km from Baboua on the Baboua-Garoua-Mboulai axis. Unconfirmed sources say that they attacked a Cameroonian MINUSCA vehicle, while others say it was a passenger motorcycle.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: A Burundian MINUSCA contingent and Anti-Balaka forces reportedly engaged in a heavy exchange of gunfire in the 4th District (Boganda) area of Bangui near a high school after an allege failed arrest of a Anti-Balaka leader in the area. 2 peacekeepers were injured along with as many as 40 high school students who were caught in the crossfire. The MINUSCA forces claimed that the Anti-Balaka gunmen used the students as human shields.
2 young men were killed by suspected armed herders in Dewili (exact location not available), near Kabo.
An accused thief was captured and tortured by young people before dying of his injuries.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column7: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Human Rights Watch reported that 4 civilians were detained and severely beaten by Congolese peacekeeprs serving with MINUSCA in Mambere. The incident was allegedly related to a dispute over a woman between a peacekeeper and one of the victims. 2 of the civilians later died.
To mark Fathers Day, men in Damara marched for peace and social cohesion, ending in the central market.
A young boy was assaulted by armed Fulani outside Kabo, 3km outside the village of Tago (lat/longs not available).

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: National and international forces launched an ""aggressive operation"" against gunmen camped near Zoukombo who have ambushed commercial vehicles and attacked villagers in the Baboua area. 6 civilian hostages killed (circumstances unclear) and one released, one person arrested, and livestock recovered during the operation.

column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Unidentified gunmen interrupted a ceremony to officially launch the entry of electoral lists by assaulting the deputy mayor, causing other officials to disperse to prevent further violence.

""Armed men fired upon three INGO staff members that were traveling via motorcycles on the Ippy-Bambari road. One of the staff members was seriously injured and was taken to Bangui hospital. The armed men stole the INGO worker's bag and fled.""
More than 200 Anti-Balaka from Pk12 laid down their arms and organised themselves in an association of youth in Begoua.
More than 500 merchants in the KM5 district protested against the municipalities decision not to relocate them.
2 people were kidnapped by 6 unidentified gunmen with AK47s and military uniforms in Kabo. One was later released after a ransom was paid.
An Anti Balaka commander laid down his arms announcing his withdrawal from the rebellion in Boy Rade of Bangui.
2 people were killed and 4 wounded when unidentified gunmen opened fire on a car in the village of Foro. The reason for the attack is not clear but nothing was reported stolen.
State officials/employees protested over grievances related to sub-prefecturals elections and the alleged failure to keep records.

LRA attacks Aza, Gbodjo, Malatcha, Ngoudka and Bangana localities of Yalinga in the course of one week between 4-10 July, assaulting and abducting civilians, as well as looting and burning properties.

LRA attacks Aza, Gbodjo, Malatcha, Ngoudka and Bangana localities of Yalinga in the course of one week between 4-10 July, assaulting and abducting civilians, as well as looting and burning properties.

LRA attacks Aza, Gbodjo, Malatcha, Ngoudka and Bangana localities of Yalinga in the course of one week between 4-10 July, assaulting and abducting civilians, as well as looting and burning properties.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Gendarmerie
column17: Between 6-12 unidentified gunmen, some of whom were disguised as UN peacekeepers, surrounded the state radio station but were repelled by forces of the national gendarme. At least one member of the security forces was injured.

A man from the Yabera neighbourhood of Bozoum was kidnapped and tortured for 3 days by youths who accused him of putting an enchantment on their little sister. He later died of his injuries in hospital.

LRA attacks Aza, Gbodjo, Malatcha, Ngoudka and Bangana localities of Yalinga in the course of one week between 4-10 July, assaulting and abducting civilians, as well as looting and burning properties.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: A group of around 10 unidentified gunmen attacked a police vehicle on patrol in Bangui, leaving two policemen injured and the vehicle damaged.

LRA attacks Aza, Gbodjo, Malatcha, Ngoudka and Bangana localities of Yalinga in the course of one week between 4-10 July, assaulting and abducting civilians, as well as looting and burning properties.

LRA attacks Aza, Gbodjo, Malatcha, Ngoudka and Bangana localities of Yalinga in the course of one week between 4-10 July, assaulting and abducting civilians, as well as looting and burning properties.

LRA attacks Aza, Gbodjo, Malatcha, Ngoudka and Bangana localities of Yalinga in the course of one week between 4-10 July, assaulting and abducting civilians, as well as looting and burning properties.
Patients in the hospital and university centre of Bangui protested against the departure of MSF.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: MINUSCA peacekeepers arrested 4 individuals during security operations and allegedly used excessive force, resulting in the deaths of 2 of the individuals and a third taken to the hospital (specific location of the incident not given). The peacekeepers involved, 20 in all, were repatriated to their home country.
2 Fulani herders on their way from Mboki to Obo were attacked and robbed by LRA rebels.
Gunmen believed to be Chadian soldiers attacked the Kota Gbangoro area, killing one civilian and causing ""enormous material damage"".

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: A convoy of WFP supplies escorted by MINUSCA peacekeepers was attacked, resulting in the death of one of the drivers and injured others.

column9: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: The mayor and deputy prefect of Baboua were taken hostage by unidentified gunmen. Other people were also kidnapped but they were released.
Enumerators protested for 2 days to demand that the government pay their training cost and give them access to vehicles.
Enumerators protested for 2 days to demand that the government pay their training cost and give them access to vehicles.
3 traders were kidnapped in the Nzako area, allegedly by LRA members.

column6: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column17: Former Seleka militia members from Kaga-Bandoro have created a new political party, the Patriotic Movement for Central (MPC) which has committed itself to peace and the democratic process.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: AFP; RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: A group of unidentified gunmen opened fire on a Bangladeshi MINUSCA patrol in Diba, near Beloko. At least 2 MINUSCA peacekeepers were injured.

Truck drivers from Cameroon block the Bangui-Garoua-Mboulai road and two days later begin an unlimited strike to denounce rising insecurity on the road and ask for better protection from MINUSCA and CAR forces.

column9: Military Forces of the United States (2009-2017)
column17: A man was kidnapped by armed men believed to be ex-Seleka rebels. The man was allegedly kidnapped as he was considered a traitor for working at the US army base in Sam-Ouandja.
2 people vandalized an election registration centre in a kindergarten in Bozoum.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Central Office for the Repression of Banditry
column17: Two men were summarily executed by the OCRB in Bangui.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column7: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: At least 1 MINUSCA peacekeeper was killed and several others wounded in fighting which erupted when the peacekeepers, backed by CAR police, attempted to arrest an unidentified faction leader in PK5.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Gendarmerie
column17: A constable of the gendarme was killed at his house in Bria by unidentified gunmen who stole his weapon.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 4 militiamen and 1 Cameroonian MINUSCA peacekeeper were killed in a clash with communal militia in the KM5 neighbourhood of Bangui as the peacekeepers attempted to arrest a former Seleka rebel commander. 8 other people were wounded according to MSF. Exchanges of fire were again heard between the two groups the following morning but no mentioned casualty.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: According to testimonies collected by Amnesty International, a MINUSCA peacekeeper allegedly raped a young girl during operations in PK5.
Between Aug.2-3, 4 people were killed and 4 injured in attacks by anti-Balaka on Malegbassa village, inhabited by Fulani herders, where they looted cattle.
A man who allegedly stole a solar panel was beaten by people who caught him, and later died in the hospital.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Exchanges of fire between MINUSCA soldiers and KM5 militia looking for their leader in KM5 area of Bangui after clashes that left 5 dead the day before. No reported casualty this time.
Between Aug.2-3, 4 people were killed and 4 injured in attacks by anti-Balaka on Malegbassa village, inhabited by Fulani herders, where they looted cattle.

In retaliation for an attack on their camp the day before, former Seleka members and Fulani herders attacked Ndoma village, neighbouring Malegbassa, leaving 8 dead and more wounded. They allegedly also took prisoners.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: According to testimonies collected by Amnesty International, MINUSCA soldiers allegedly shot 2 civilians, one of whom died on the spot while the other died of their injuries in hospital.
Former Seleka gunmen tortured a student in Bino, a village on the Batangafo-Bouca axis, after attempting to rob him.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Three young females report that UN peacekeepers from DRC raped them in early August.
About 60 people were taken hostage by suspected LRA members from the village of Mbari, although 45 later escaped.
4 people were taken hostage by LRA gunmen from Kpokpo village in the Yalinga area.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: A Rwandan soldier of MINUSCA opened fire on his colleagues, killing 4 other Rwandan soldiers, in their base in Bangui. He was also killed during the gunfight while 8 other soldiers were wounded. The reason behind the shooting was unclear.
LRA members kidnapped one man while he was on his way from the ""kpo-kpo site"" while he was on his way to Bria.
The village of Badibiri in Obo was raided by LRA fighters. The townspeople fired warning shots into the air to scare the rebels away, but a youth was shot by the rebels during the incident.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Prison Guards
column9: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: At least 18 prisoners escaped from a central prison in Ngaragba after taking weapons from the guards. Most of the criminals are suspected to be former members of armed groups. The prison was also protected by international forces.
Election officials in the Bimbo area protested outside the National Authority of Elections headquarters to demand payment of their registration fees.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Arrests: The secretary-general of the Kwa Na Kwa party of Francois Bozize was arrested as he was about to board a plane for Paris, allegedly related to charges of ""inciting disorder"".

AFP has reported that a ""cattle war"" is ongoing in CAR, with violence including the killing and looting of livestock, kidnapping of breeders, and killings and rapes occurring in the western regions, primarily targeted members of the Mbororo ethnic group (fatalities coded as 10).

Bertan Bea, the former Secretary General to ex-President Francois Bea who was arrested on the 15th, was liberated by militants who attacked the court in Bangui. Military and MINUSCA forces around the court reportedly did not fight back.
Anti-balaka reportedly killed a young Muslim man.

A total of ten people were killed and five injured in religious clashes between Anti-balaka and Seleka rebels plus non-Seleka Muslims after a young Muslim was killed by Christians the day before. Volunteers from the Red Cross, both local and international, were also attacked and injured with knives during the clashes.

column9: ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross and Red Crescent; Christian Group (Central African Republic); Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: Red Cross officials and CAR citizens are attacked by Muslim youth while trying to attend to the injured during communal violence between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka fighters. Later in the day, despite the initiation of a dialogue between MINUSCA and the two groups, a Muslim militia killed three Christians in Bornou neighborhood, prolonging clashes the next day.
In continued clashes in Bambari, an additional 10 people were killed over the weekend.
In continued clashes in Bambari, an additional 10 people were killed over the weekend.
Gunshots and explosions were heard in Bambari as part of ongoing intercommunal clashes.

column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: At least 5 people were killed and 8 injured in intercommunal clashes between Fulani and Anti-Balaka in the Bria mining community. UN forces intervened to help stop the violence.
A woman accused of witchcraft was killed by youths in Yamondo village, located 20km from Sibut.
2 people were killed and another died of his injuries in hospital after an attack by suspected armed Fulani herders on Bougourou village.
Ex-Seleka militiamen clashed wth anti-Balaka in Bambari, causing deaths and forcing people to flee the town (fatalities coded as 10).
Some anti-Balaka youth allegedly robbed a shop and killed the owner when he attempted to pursue them.

column9: Teachers (Central African Republic); Students (Central African Republic)
column17: A charity network has reported that former Seleka rebels and anti-Balaka forces have been attacking and looting schools, with as many as 73% of schools in the Kemo district in the centre of the country and 51% in the Bangui area affected.

column9: Teachers (Central African Republic); Students (Central African Republic)
column17: A charity network has reported that former Seleka rebels and anti-Balaka forces have been attacking and looting schools, with as many as 73% of schools in the Kemo district in the centre of the country and 51% in the Bangui area affected.

column9: Teachers (Central African Republic); Students (Central African Republic)
column17: A charity network has reported that former Seleka rebels and anti-Balaka forces have been attacking and looting schools, with as many as 73% of schools in the Kemo district in the centre of the country and 51% in the Bangui area affected.
An unidentified armed group accused of creating insecurity in the Bakouma area opened fire on passers-by at the Ndeguilo-Bakouma-Bangassou axis. No specific casualties were reported.
Looting: 4 suspected anti-Balaka members attacked and looted a vehicle of the NGO JUPEDEC, causing no injuries.
Ex-Seleka militiamen and anti-Balaka forces clashed in Bambari, after anti-Balaka allegedly attempted to steal a motorcycle from a young Muslim. No casualties were reported.
At least 1,800 new refugees were displaced to the DR-Congo following clashes in the Mobayi-Banga area of CAR between anti-Balaka and Seleka forces.

column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: ""An agent of the Town Hall was found dead"" in the Boukako area of Bambari. It is not clear under what circumstances the municipal worker was killed.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: MINUSCA has declared Bambari a weapons-free zone after rival militias clashed in the area.
Residents of Banguis 2nd district protested against power outages which have allegedly been ongoing for 3 weeks.
A group of unidentified armed men invaded invaded a village near Gbodoro, 12km from Bakouma, and stole property and money from the villagers. They also beat them before leaving.

At least 2 people were killed and 22 injured in grenade attacks by unidentified allegedly Muslim youths in Banguis 6th district. The attacks involved at least 2 grenades, at least one of which was thrown at the Air Force One bar, and another near a church in the Fatima area.
Following grenade attacks in Banguis 6th district by allegedly Muslim youths on motorcycles, youths in the area erected roadblocks to block the movement of traffic and protest against the attacks.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Rwandan MINUSCA forces were ambushed in the 4th district of Bangui by unidentified assailants armed with heavy weapons which caused ""extensive damage"" to their armoured vehicles. No casualties were reported.
A group of unidentified armed men took about 50 villagers in Gbodoro, located 12km away from Bakouma, hostage and stole their food and money before leaving their village.
Residents of Banguis 6th district engaged in a peaceful march to protest against a grenade attack which occurred on Sept.9.

An unidentified armed group attacked the village of Kpabou near Mboki, killing 3 people and attacking and robbing a motorcycle driver. According to the man who was robbed, the armed men also wore turbans and spoke in Arabic.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Gendarmerie
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; RCA (Central African Republic)
column17: Anti-Balaka protesters took to the streets and erected roadblocks to stop traffic in the 4th district of Bangui. It was not clear why they were protesting, but some sources say it had to do with the resignation of the transitional head of state. They also raided the local gendarmie headquarters and released around 15 people being held there.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: One person was killed and another wounded in a clash between anti-Balaka elements and local police in the Kounde area. The fight appeared to grow out of a threat an anti-Balaka member made to a policemans wife.
A Muslim motorcycle taxi driver was killed by alleged anti-Balaka attackers in the PK5 district of Bangui, sparking renewed violence in the city.

column16: AFP; RCA (Central African Republic); RFI; Centrafrique Presse Info
column17: At least 24 people were killed and over 100 injured during riots following the killing of a Muslim motorcycle taxi driver. The initial violence saw Muslims (including ex-Seleka members) attacking a Christian neighbourhood (which included Anti-Balaka members) in retaliation for the killing, until international forces (French/UN) intervened to end the violence. Shops and houses were also allegedly burned, and St. Michaels Parish was looted.
The Youth Association Gobongo (AJG) organized a peace march in the 8th district of Bangui to condemn violence and the erection of barricades in Gobongo market.

Residents of the 3rd and 5th districts of Bangui erected barricades following violence in their areas. The protesters were also said to be displaying hostility towards international forces and humanitarian workers, along with journalists.

Anti-Balaka militiamen retaliated against attacks on a Christian neighbourhood by Muslims (including ex-Seleka) from PK5. Gunfire was heard between the two neighbourhoods. 36 people were said to have died in all between Sept.26-27 (24 were coded in previous events).

column6: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: The government of CAR has put in place a curfew in Bangui due to the recent violence which has hit the city.

A civil society movement dedicated to re-establishing the Central African Armed Forces and restoring peace to CAR organized a demonstration at the Monument of the Martyrs which continued overnight and included a meeting the next day.

Looting: The offices of various humanitarian organizations, including IOM, Mercy Corps, Cordaid, Premiere Urgence, the French Red Cross and War Child were looted by anti-Balaka militiamen and local residents during violence in Bangui between Sept.27-28 (unconfirmed reports also said WFP offices were targeted).

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: RCA (Central African Republic); Deutsche Welle; AFP; Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: A protest march was organized and a civil disobedience movement was called in response to the ongoing violence in Bangui. MINSUCA forces allegedly fired upon the several hundred marchers who were heading to the Office of the President to demand the resignation of the President with live bullets, killing 3 and injuring several, but UN sources dispute this. Most sources agree that three were killed.
Fighting continues between ex-Seleka and anti-Balaka forces in Bangui.
Protesters in Bangui continued to maintain barricades on the streets following overnight violence in the capital.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Prison Guards
column17: At least 53 prisoners escaped during an attack on a prison in Bouar by about 30 unidentified gunmen. They captured 2 policemen and stole their weapons and looted computers. It was not clear whether they were later released.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Prison Guards
column17: 1 prisoner was killed during a mass escape by hundreds of prisoners, including anti-Balaka militiamen, from Banguis main prison. After the escape, local residents looted the prison after the gates were left open.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Anti-Balaka gunmen attacked the offices of the national radio station and offices of the national gendarmerie, but they were repelled by the security forces. 5 of the attackers were killed, including an infamous member of the anti-Balaka group, named Mazimbele.
Several people were injured when unidentified gunmen threw a grenade in the central market of Kaga-Bandoro. Some shops were also burned.
Protesters in Bangui continued to maintain barricades on the streets following overnight violence in the capital.
2 people were killed in continued clashes in Bangui. The report did not identify which groups were fighting. The violence was particularly notable around the airport.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: An attempt to dismantle barricades erected in the 8th district of Bangui led to a clash between the unidentified controllers of the barricades and MINUSCA elements. The violence reportedly also spread to the 3rd and 5th districts. At least 1 civilian was killed, although no official death toll was given.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: An attempt to dismantle barricades erected in the 8th district of Bangui led to a clash between the unidentified controllers of the barricades and MINUSCA elements. The violence reportedly also spread to the 3rd and 5th districts. At least 1 civilian was killed, although no official death toll was given (coded as 10 across the 3 events).

column7: MCADP: The Patriotic Movement for the Appropriation of the Destiny of the Country
column17: A protest was organized by the Patriotic Movement for the Appropriation of the Destiny of the Country which is calling for the withdrawal of international forces.
Exchanges of fire were heard, including fighting near the National Assembly. Two Total stations at Boy-Rab, in an anti-Balaka stronghold, were also looted and vandalized.

The National Transitional Council say that 77 people were killed and 300 injured during violence around Bangui around the end of September following the death of a Muslim motorcycle taxi driver (57 fatalities were coded in other events) based on body counts at morgues around the city. The fatalities include both those engaged in violence and civilians caught in the crossfire.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: An attempt to dismantle barricades erected in the 8th district of Bangui led to a clash between the unidentified controllers of the barricades and MINUSCA elements. The violence reportedly also spread to the 3rd and 5th districts. At least 1 civilian was killed, although no official death toll was given (coded as 10 across the 3 events).

1 person was killed and several injured during a shootout between anti-Balaka forces and armed youths from Bangui in the area of Bogoula village. The fight allegedly started after the armed youths were stopped at a barricade erected by the anti-Balaka forces.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Unidentified gunmen opened fire on the MINSUCA HQ in Bangui, prompting a return of fire from MINUSCA forces. The attackers then fled on a motorcycle. No casualties were reported.
3 people were killed and several others injured during an attack by unidentified gunmen on Lakouetene, near Mbres. The gunmen fired at youths as they were returning from their fields.
The Muslim community in PK5 organized a peace rally in PK5 following the violence experienced over the past week.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: A Burundian MINUSCA peacekeeper was killed during an attack by an unidentified group on a convoy traveling between Damaraand Ngerengou. Another was also injured by the attackers.
A group of allegedly anti-Balaka gunmen attacked a convoy of vehicles near Boali, firing on the vehicles and looting them, leading to 2 deaths and several injuries.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo); Centrafrique Presse Info; RFI; RCA (Central African Republic)
column17: MINUSCA and French forces clashed just outside the Sibut area with FPRC elements of the Seleka militia who were marching on Bangui. The clashes continued from Oct.10-11. Helicopters bombed Seleka positions during the fighting. 10 Seleka were killed over the 2 days of fighting.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column16: RFI; Centrafrique Presse Info; RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka; Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo)
column17: MINUSCA and French forces clashed just outside the Sibut area with FPRC elements of the Seleka militia who were marching on Bangui. The clashes continued from Oct.10-11. Helicopters bombed Seleka positions during the fighting. 10 Seleka were killed over the 2 days of fighting.

Anti-Balaka attacked and burned houses in Lema village on the border with the DRC between Oct.12-13, leading to a new surge in refugees crossing into North and South Ubangi. They pursued the refugees and stole their property as well.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: Former Seleka rebels from the FPRC faction raided the town of Kouango, shooting in all directions and setting buildings on fire. At least 2 people were wounded during the incident.

column9: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: Unidentified assailants kidnapped 4 MSF staff members from their office in Bangassou. They were released half an hour later, with one international employee suffering serious injuries.
6 people have been killed in the Obo area around the end of October (3 fatalities coded in another event).

3 people were killed and 7 injured after clashes between two groups of anti-Balaka related to a conflict over the chain of command. The ""author of the disorders and other anti-Balaka"" were among those killed. Calm returned after the intervention of MINUSCA forces.
