column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; AFP; Centrafrique Presse Info; RCA (Central African Republic)
column17: Three people killed and 10 wounded, primarily civilians, after anti-Balaka forces attacked the neighbourhood of PK5 in Bangui. They were opposed by self-defense committees from the district. Heavy gunfire was heard for about an hour, until MINUSCA intervened to disperse the two groups.
Looting: Unidentified gunmen looted the offices of an NGO (""Appui au developpement"") in Banguis 5th arrondissement. Several other cases of robbery were reported during the day in the capital.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; Xinhua; RFI; UN (unspecified)
column17: 7 UN police were kidnapped by a 50 member anti-Balaka force and disarmed near Boali before being released in the evening after negotiations with the government. Armaments were also returned a week later after negotiations.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 3 unidentified gunmen attacked a MINUSCA forces post in Damara. 1 assailant was killed when the peacekeepers returned fire, while the other two escaped.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: The Deputy Chairman of the National Transitional Council was kidnapped along with two police officers by anti-Balaka forces about 90km north of Bangui. They were kept for 2 hours, before being released and given a list of demands for the government.
Anti-Balaka militias based in Bogangolo attacked and killed six villagers and burned houses in the Maraze area, close to Bouca.
Some villagers hunted down and killed the alleged perpatrator of a crime. The man killed was an anti-Balaka member, leading to later reprisals (coded in a separate event).

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Central Office for the Repression of Banditry
column17: Two men were summarily executed by the OCRB in Bangui. Simultaneouslu, a woman was arrested by the OCRB, whose leader then demanded a ransom from her family before she would be released. She was freed in December 2015, but was never charged with a crime.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Central Office for the Repression of Banditry
column17: Two men were summarily executed by the OCRB in the 7th district of Bangui.
3 Christians were killed in alleged retaliatory violence after UPC representatives were attacked by anti-Balaka members.
3 people were kidnapped by suspected LRA rebels near Ligoua. They were found dead on Oct.31 in the same area.

column9: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: Anti-Balaka members attacked a delegation of 4 former Seleka rebels from the UPC in the 8th district of Bangui after they arrived in the city at the invitation of the government for talks. 1 member of the delegation was seriously injured, at least 2 were killed, and the situation for the last is unknown.
Residents of Lakouanga in the PK5 neighbourhood protested against renewed violence in the area.
Self-defense groups who do not identify as anti-Balaka or Seleka have started forming in Bangui in response to the resurgence of violence in the capital.
2 young Muslims were found dead (believed to have been killed the night of Oct.28) in a mostly Christian neighbourhood of Bangui on the morning of Oct.29.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Central Office for the Repression of Banditry
column17: The head of the OCRB allegedly personally carried out the summary execution of a man in the 7th district of Bangui.

At least 2 young motorcycle taxi drivers believed to be Muslims were killed by unidentified men in the 6th district of Bangui. It is not clear why they were killed, but the murder of Muslim taxi drivers has recently led to significant violence in CARs largest cities.

At least 4 people were killed, 20 wounded, and several houses burned, including those of the heads of the Kina and Kokoro neighbourhoods during reprisals by armed Muslims from the KM5 against the 3rd and 6th districts of Bangui following the killing of 2 young Muslim motorcycle taxi drivers in the 6th district.

At least 4 people were killed, 20 wounded, and several houses burned, including those of the heads of the Kina and Kokoro neighbourhoods during reprisals by armed Muslims from the KM5 against the 3rd and 6th districts of Bangui following the killing of 2 young Muslim motorcycle taxi drivers in the 6th district.

column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016); Women (Central African Republic)
column17: The sub-prefect of Damara was attacked in Nguerengo village by 30 anti-Balaka members, who ""brutalized"" her. Two of the assailants were wearing police uniforms. Further details were not reported.

2 people were killed and several wounded during sectarian violence between Muslim and Christian militias following the deaths of some Muslim motorcycle taxi drivers a few days before which has led to ongoing violence.

At least 3 people were killed, 22 injured, and over a hundred houses burned during clashes between anti-Balaka forces and Muslim militias from PK5 in Bangui. International forces were allegedly entirely absent during the violence.
Two unidentified assailants threw grenades in the University of Bangui, injuring students.

A woman believed to be a witch who was accused of killing a young girl was beaten to death by a group of villagers led by the leader of an anti-Balaka group (the group who killed the witch was not reported as anti-Balaka fighters).

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: MINSUCA reported that a convoy it was protecting came under attack in the 4th district of Bangui, injuring 3 people, including 2 peacekeepers.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Central Office for the Repression of Banditry
column17: A man accused of leading a lynching of a witch, who was also the leader of an anti-Balaka group in Lobaye province, was summarily executed by the OCRB in Bangui.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Anti-Balaka forces fired shots near Fatima Church in Banguis 6th district during a visit by the special representative of the UN Secretary-General. Peacekeepers returned fire but no casualties were reported.

column9: WFP: World Food Programme; Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: 2 people were killed, including an employee of the WFP, when armed men threw grenades at a barrier in PK12, in the north part of Bangui.

One hundred parliamentarians of the National Transitional Council participated in a peaceful march to denounce the recent violence in Bangui and demand the rapid rearmament of the Central African Armed Forces (FACA).

Some students protested at the University of Bangui against the dissolution of the executive of the National Association of Central African Students (ANECA) and set up barricades which disrupted activities.
Over 900 people fled a UNHCR camp near Awatche village after an attack on the area by an unidentified armed group.
At least 1 person was shot dead and several houses and stalls were burned during clashes between Muslims and Anti-Balaka forces in Bangui, particularly in PK4 and Bea-Rex neighbourhoods.

column7: COMIC: Coordination of the Central Muslim Community
column17: Members of the Coordination of the Central Muslim Community organized a rally ensure freedom of movement for Muslims and rearmament of the FACA.
1 person was killed and several others injured after anti-Balaka attacked a vehicle owned by former Seleka rebels near Liwa.
Clashes between anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka fighters resulted in 3 fatalities in Bambari.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: During clashes between anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka forces near a MINUSCA outpost, at least one Cameroonian peacekeeper was killed. It was not clear who killed the peackeeper.
Anti-Balaka and former Seleka forces clashed in Batangafo.

After 2 members of an ex-Seleka group were killed, the armed group attacked an IDP camp, burning over 700 shelters and spreading fear and violence throughout the camp, causing 10,000 people to flee to Batangafo hospital. At least 3 civilians were killed and 30 injured.
Unidentified assailants killed 2 young Muslims who were members of an ex-Seleka militia outside of an IDP camp near Batangafo.
Fighting was heard during the night in Bambari.
Clashes between PK5 militia and unidentified gunmen at Sarah in Banguis 3rd neighborhood over livestock, leaving one killed.
PK5 militiamen attacked the Notre Dame de Fatima IDP site in Banguis 6th arrondissement, leaving two IDPs killed and one severely injured.
Fighting was heard during the night in Bambari.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: UNHCR; RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: UPC forces attacked the IDP site at ""St. Joseph"" in Bambari, but were stopped by the Congolese contingent of MINUSCA. At least 4 civilians were killed, several injured and more than 30 tents burned by the attackers.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: HRW has reported that at least 8 girls were raped between October to December, 2015. Among them are two girls, one 14 years the other 18, were gang-raped by MINUSCA peacekeepers near Bambari airport.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: HRW has reported that at least 8 girls were raped between October to December, 2015. Among them are two girls, one 14 years the other 18, were gang-raped by MINUSCA peacekeepers near Bambari airport.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: 3 people were killed and several injured when MINUSCA and Sangaris forces attempted to dismantled barricades in the 3rd and 6th districts of Bangui and were opposed by youths from the areas who had erected them. Residents marched in protest against the move and re-erected the barricades.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: 3 people were killed and several injured when MINUSCA and Sangaris forces attempted to dismantled barricades in the 3rd and 6th districts of Bangui and were opposed by youths from the areas who had erected them. Residents marched in protest against the move and re-erected the barricades.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: A FACA soldier was killed by a group of anti-Balaka affiliated youths in the Damala district of Begoua.
Anti-Balaka militias have allegedly begun an embargo of the PK5 neighbourhood.
Election workers protested to demand their wages.
2 people were killed and one injured during clashes between two rival Anti-Balaka factions in the Damala district of Begoua.

column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Suspected PK5 militiamen supported by MINUSCA forces killed two people in Ngou ciment neighborhood of Bangui. Residents marched in front of the Radio Ndeke Luka office the flollowing day in protest.
Suspected PK5 militiamen supported by MINUSCA forces killed two people in Ngou ciment neighborhood of Bangui. Residents marched in front of the Radio Ndeke Luka office the flollowing day in protest.
""A national INGO staff member in Kaga-Bandoro was shot and killed when armed robbers broke into his house. Another INGO staff member from a different INGO was also killed by a gunshot wound.""

Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka forces clashed in Gala Bouruma village, near Ngaboko, resulting in at least 10 dead and 2 wounded. The clash was allegedly started after ex-Seleka killed an old man near the village.
A 73 year old man was murdered along the river to the village Ouaka Gala Bouruma by a group of ex-Seleka.
A young Muslim was killed by unidentified armed assailants outside a mosque in PK5.
Seleka militia looted goods and abducted 30 people in Mbimbi, Bedamou and Ngoro villages in Dekoa, Kemo. Three managed to escape, while another three were freed by the group.
Seleka militia looted goods and abducted 30 people in Mbimbi, Bedamou and Ngoro villages in Dekoa, Kemo. Three managed to escape, while another three were freed by the group.
Seleka militia looted goods and abducted 30 people in Mbimbi, Bedamou and Ngoro villages in Dekoa, Kemo. Three managed to escape, while another three were freed by the group.
At least 8 people were killed and 9 injured when ex-Seleka forces attacked the IDP site at Ngaboko, in retaliation for an attack by anti-Balaka forces in the area earlier in the week.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: MINUSCA forces intervened during an ex-Seleka attack on the Ngaboko IDP camp, killing 5 fighters during the clash. 2 Seleka fighters were also injured, as well as 1 peacekeeper.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Central Office for the Repression of Banditry
column17: A man was summarily executed by the OCRB in Bangui.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Gendarmerie
column9: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Protesters erected barricades and gunfire was heard in 8 districts in Bangui after the announcement that former President Francoise Bozize would not be allowed to run in the upcoming elections. Local gendarmes, police and MINUSCA forces moved quickly to dismantle the barricades.

column7: Vigilante Group (Central African Republic); Refugees/IDPs (Central African Republic)
column17: IDPs from the Don Bosco camp allegedly killed an older woman who they accused of witchcraft.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column7: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Police, FACA soldiers and local residents destroyed tents and shelters at the Don Bosco IDP camp, forcing the residents to move on, following the alleged killing of a woman accused of witchcraft by IDPs.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Gendarmerie
column17: Protesters erected barricades in Bangui to protest the announcement that former President Francoise Bozize would not be allowed to run in the upcoming elections and clashed with police, leaving several injured.
UN peacekeepers reported unrest in the PK5 district during the night before the opening of polls, including the sounds of gunfire, but no casualties.
Several hundred people marched in Bangui against the invalidation of an Anti-Balaka candidate in the presidential race. The protest ended peacefully.
3 people were injured in the district of Gobongo (around the 4th district of Bangui) which is an ""anti-Balaka militia stronghold"" amid gunfire and a grenade blast.

column7: PRGF: Popular Front for the Central African Renaissance
column17: Voting on the constitutional referendum was disrupted in the north and east of CAR by gunfire, suspected to be carried out by FPRC faction fighters.

column7: PRGF: Popular Front for the Central African Renaissance
column17: Voting on the constitutional referendum was disrupted in the north and east of CAR by gunfire, suspected to be carried out by FPRC faction fighters.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: A MINUSCA peacekeeper was injured in Bria during violence that took place during the voting on the constitutional referendum.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: At least 5 people were killed and 20 injured, including 2 peacekeepers, during fighting which broke out in PK5 during voting over the constitutional referendum (split between multiple events in PK5). During the fighting, MINUSCA peacekeepers were deployed to protect poll workers and residents while they cast their votes near a school. Machine gun fire and RPG explosions were heard during the violence. In one incident, a Muslim self-defense militia fought with a group of anti-referendum former Seleka fighters outside a school where voting was taking place.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: The leader of the FPRC Seleka faction, headquartered in Kaga-Bandoro, has declared the independence of the northeast areas of CAR under his control, naming the territory the ""Republic of Logone"".

Hundreds of residents of PK5 marched to the MINUSCA headquarters in Bangui to demand that they expel armed groups from their area and ensure they are able to vote in the elections following violence during the constitutional referendum.

column6: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Presidential and legislative elections in CAR have been postponed until Dec.30 due to insecurity and logistical difficulties, following a recent constitutional referendum that included violent clashes.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Central Office for the Repression of Banditry
column17: A man, suspected of being part of an anti-Balaka group, was summarily executed by the OCRB in Bangui.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: The UN Mission in Bangui received reports that MINUSCA peacekeepers sexually abused 4 girls in Bangui. Few details about the incident were released as investigations are ongoing.

A taxi driver of the Kaba ethnic group was killed, allegedly by members of the Tali ethnic group, which later led to ethnically-based reprisals in the Paoua area by the Revolution and Justice group (allegedly 80% Kaba).

The villages of Ndjoret, Bederee Bederee, and Ouham Pende were attacked by about 30 armed men of the Revolution and Justice group (allegedly 80% of whom are ethnically Kaba) after a taxi driver of the Kaba ethnicity was killed, allegedly by members of the Tali ethnic group, who also inhabit the villages that were attacked. 87 houses and dozens of barns were burned, and many people fled the area.
A woman was raped and a man assaulted in his field by armed Fulani herders, who also robbed the man.
1 person was killed and 2 others seriously injured when unidentified gunmen ambushed a vehicle traveling between Bakouma and Bangassou.
LRA rebels killed a villager and abducted dozens of others during two weekend raids around Diya, about 600km east of Bangui.
LRA rebels killed a villager and abducted dozens of others during two weekend raids around Diya, about 600km east of Bangui.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Central Office for the Repression of Banditry
column17: A man was summarily executed by the OCRB in Bangui.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Central Office for the Repression of Banditry
column17: A man was summarily executed by the OCRB in Bangui between sometime Jan.14-15.
Residents of Bayanga beat a woman they accused of being a witch, seriously injuring her. She was then taken to the police, where she later died of her injuries.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Central Office for the Repression of Banditry
column17: A man was summarily executed by the OCRB in Bangui sometime between Jan.17-20.
1 person was killed and another wounded by armed Fulani who attacked the village of Garo. The population fled the area afterwards.
LRA rebels killed 4 civilians and kidnapped people in the localities of Nzacko and Popo near Bria.
LRA rebels injured 4 civilians and kidnapped people in the localities of Nzacko and Popo near Bria.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Central Office for the Repression of Banditry
column17: A man was summarily executed by the OCRB in Bangui.
LRA rebels attacked the village of Tomboura on the ""Obo-Zemio axis"". They looted the health centre and kidnapped 16 people, who were later released.
RRR militiamen attacked Sangodor village, near De Gaulle, in Koui subprefecture. Witnesses said 2 people were killed.
LRA rebels looted the St. Andrew Catholic Church, injured a nun, and kidnapped two civilians in Bakouma.
4 people were kidnapped by LRA rebels in an attack on Tambourah town.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Central Office for the Repression of Banditry
column17: A man, who was a suspected former anti-Balaka fighter, was summarily executed by the OCRB in Bangui.

column7: AFDT: Democratic Alliance for the Transition
column17: Members of the AFDT enter the Ministry of Public Security to demand the cancellation of the upcoming presidential elections.

column7: AFDT: Democratic Alliance for the Transition
column17: Members of the AFDT enter the Ministry of Public Security for a second day demand the cancellation of the upcoming presidential elections.

column7: AFDT: Democratic Alliance for the Transition
column17: 4 youth members of the AFDT were arrested following a demonstration outside the Ministry of Public Security to demand the cancellation of the upcoming presidential elections.
LRA rebels attacked several places in Haut-Mbomou and Haute-Kotto on Jan.30.
LRA rebels attacked several places in Haut-Mbomou and Haute-Kotto on Jan.30.
A man was killed by Mbarara Fulani gunmen who attempted to rob him near Kabo.
Residents of Bambouti buried a man accused of killing a hunter alive in an incident of mob justice.
A butcher was stabbed to death by a member of a self-defense group after the butcher refused to pay ""taxes"" (protection money).
A woman accused of being a witch was found dead on the grounds of the gendarmerie, which is currently occupied by ex-Seleka forces.
Students protested and barricaded the Avenue of Martyrs to demand the payment of scholarships in arrears.
LRA rebels attacked the towns of Ouango and Niakari between Feb.2-4, kidnapping 20 people. They later released 9.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: The family of a butcher who was killed by a self-defense group rioted, firing automatic weapons and throwing grenades, until the FACA soldiers intervened to calm the situation.
LRA rebels attacked the towns of Ouango and Niakari between Feb.2-4, kidnapping 20 people. They later released 9.
A driver who allegedly stole fuel was killed by former Seleka after a local resident complained to their commander.
A dozen people were abducted from Akpo village near Bria by LRA rebels. They were used to transport goods that the LRA fighters looted from the town.

column7: Military Forces of the United States (2009-2017)
column17: Arrests: An LRA commander named Marck Sam (originally George Okot Odek) was arrested by former Seleka forces in Mbangana over the weekend and handed over to US forces based in Obo.
3 youths were shot dead in the city of Mbres, allegedly by former Seleka gunmen.
On 10 February 2016, a young woman was beaten to death in Bozoum after she failed to heal someone and was accused of being a witch. Her father was also shot and seriously wounded.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Central Office for the Repression of Banditry
column17: A man was summarily executed by the OCRB in Bangui.
LRA rebels have allegedly abducted as many as 296 people from CAR and DR-Congo in the first quarter of 2016, according to the NGOs Resolve and Invisible Children.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: A Moroccan soldier based in Bangassou have been accused of sexually-exploiting a woman.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Members of a Burundian peacekeeping unit in Sibut have been accused of raping a young girl.
Youth in Nzako organized a march to demand the government offer more support to Ugandan troops in the area to force the Seleka to withdraw from the city.

column6: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: Faustin-Archange Touadera was elected president of CAR. He received 62% of the vote with a voter turnout of 61%.
A group of ex-Seleka have moved into the village of Ndjim, near Bocaranga. They were joined a few days later by another group, bringing the total number of fighters in the village to 29.

A group of ex-Seleka who had occupied Ndjim near Bocaranga burned the villages market and several houses, as well as those of other villages as they moved towards Mbai-deck. The gunmen are allegedly unhappy that their demands have not been met by the authorities.
Students protested in Bangui and blocked the Avenue of Martyrs after a scholarship list put out by the government was published with 700 less names than promised.

A small dispute between two groups of students escalated into a larger clash which disrupted traffic on the Avenue of Martyrs and led to an intervention by the police, during which they fired into the air to disperse the students. The cause of the conflict was not reported.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: Arrests: Security sources say Djie Ngaibona, an Anti-Balaka chief accused of sowing ""disorder at IDP sites"", was arrested in Kaga-Bandoro.

column16: AFP; Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo)
column17: 2 Muslims were kidnapped about 10km outside Bambari by unidentified gunmen. They were later reported to have been killed (which allegedly prompted retaliatory attacks by ex-Seleka/Fulani militias over the weekend).

Students from the School of Miskine, who were part of a clash on the Avenue of Martyrs the day before, protested after rumours emerged that a student was killed by police who intervened in the clash the day before. The authorities said they had no information about any fatalities.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Central Office for the Repression of Banditry
column17: A man was summarily executed by the OCRB in Bangui sometime between Mar.4-5.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: Following the death of 2 Muslims who were kidnapped earlier in the week, former Seleka from the UPC factions, backed by Fulani militias, engaged in clashes with Anti-Balaka and their allies from the towns around Bambari. At least 8 people were killed between Mar.4-6 during the PRGFs attacks on Christian populations, with the most fatalities (5) occurring on Mar.5, including 3 civilians and 2 ex-Seleka rebels. The violence had ended by Monday. The majority of those killed were civilians, and at least some of he violence centered on an IDP camp.
11 people were kidnapped and their property was stolen by LRA rebels in Tabane in the Zemio area.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: Following the death of 2 Muslims who were kidnapped earlier in the week, former Seleka from the UPC factions, backed by Fulani militias, engaged in clashes with Anti-Balaka and their allies from the towns around Bambari. At least 8 people were killed between Mar.4-6 during the PRGFs attacks on Christian populations, with the most fatalities (5) occurring on Mar.5, including 3 civilians and 2 ex-Seleka rebels. The violence had ended by Monday. The majority of those killed were civilians, and at least some of he violence centered on an IDP camp.
Former Seleka rebels attacked an LRA position over the weekend in the Ouadda area, killing 4 LRA rebels and wounding many others.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: Following the death of 2 Muslims who were kidnapped earlier in the week, former Seleka from the UPC factions, backed by Fulani militias, engaged in clashes with Anti-Balaka and their allies from the towns around Bambari. At least 8 people were killed between Mar.4-6 during the PRGFs attacks on Christian populations, with the most fatalities (5) occurring on Mar.5, including 3 civilians and 2 ex-Seleka rebels. The violence had ended by Monday. The majority of those killed were civilians, and at least some of he violence centered on an IDP camp.
2 civilians were detained and injured by Anti-Balaka. They were also robbed before being released.
Anti-Balaka militiamen killed a woman who was accused of murdering people in the Batangafo territory and of being a witch.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Research and Investigation Division
column7: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column9: CPJP: Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace; Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016); Anti-Balaka
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo); RCA (Central African Republic); RFI
column17: Arrests: SRI officers arrested former Seleka leader of the CPJP Abdoulaye Issene, the CAR Minister of Sport, at the Mpoko airport in Bangui. Bawa (Samy Urban), a FACA soldier and Anti-Balaka commander, was also arrested in a northern district of Bangui on the orders of the Minister of Defense. He is accused of being responsible for disrupting peace in the capital.
Anti-Balaka in Batangafo buried a woman they accused of being responsible for murders in the area and of being a witch alive, resulting in her death.

column7: CPJP: Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Gendarmerie
column16: Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo); RCA (Central African Republic)
column17: After SRI officers arrested former Seleka leader of the CPJP, Abdoulaye Issene, the CAR Minister of Sport, at the Mpoko airport in Bangui, armed men loyal to him staged an assault on a gendarmerie outpost in the KM5 neighbourhood of Bangui and managed to release their leader.
At least 3 young girls were allegedly taken to a French military camp and sexually exploited by the soldiers in March 2016 in the Kemo region.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Surrender/Defect:Officers of the ex-Seleka coalition say a new battalion of Pakistani peacekeepers with MINUSCA have started forecefully disarming them in violation of agreements they had previously made with MINUSCA.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: A limitations on the movement of motorcycle taxi drivers by the FACA (CAR military forces) in KM5 in the 3rd district of Bangui led to a clash between them and the drivers, who were supported by Bazanga residents. 4 people sustained bullet wounds during the incident.
5 people were injured, 3 seriously, after a grenade was thrown during a monetary dispute between some youths at KM5 in the 3rd district of Bangui.
A young man was shot and 3 others were injured during an attack by a group of 7 Fulani gunmen on a market in Kaga-Bandoro. The attack allegedly resulted from an argument over a bike rental.
A non-aggression pact was signed March 29, 2016 in Batangafo between armed and communal groups in the city in the presence of the local authorities and the minusca.

1 person was killed and 12 wounded in a grenade attack by two people on a motorcycle who threw the explosive into an underground restaurant. 4 of those wounded were UNHCR officials and 4 were from NGOs.
Former Seleka rebels abducted a young trader in Batangafo a few days after the signing of a non-aggression pact between armed groups and communities in the city.
2 people were killed and 4 injured during a knife fight that broke out between former Seleka rebels in Kaga-Bandoro over the weekend. The fight was allegedly over management of a cattle market.

2 suspected former Seleka militiamen attacked the village of Trombekos, near Nzako, and terrorized the inhabitants. They reportedly killed one person and stole property, while injuring 2. Former Seleka were known to have settled in the area, and the LRA have also carried out attacks.
Members of Bambaris Muslim community marched from Bomu market to the MINUSC offices in their city against the new government, saying the Muslim community is under-represented.
A suspected thief was beaten to death, allegedly by members of his own family, in the 8th district of Bangui.
5 Sangaris soldiers beat up a shopkeeper in Bangui over a dispute.
Detainees in Ngaragba prison protested to demand better living conditions.

2 people were killed during a clash between former Seleka militiamen and a youth group who live near a cattle camp a few km from Kaga Bandoro. The dispute was related to cattle transportation activities.
5 people were abducted by LRA rebels during an attack on the village of Agoumar in the Rafai area. The villagers reportedly fought back, injuring and capturing one LRA fighter.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: After a communal group in Agoumar captured an LRA member, MINUSCA forces intervened when community members attempted to kill the rebel. This led to a clash, leading to at least 1 Moroccan peacekeeper and 1 civilian seriously injured. Both of those injured later died.
5 people were abducted by LRA rebels during an attack on the village of Agoumar in the Rafai area. The villagers reportedly fought back, injuring and capturing one LRA fighter.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: An Anti-Balaka chief nicknamed Fally was killed during a clash with police around the Bambari-Kouango axis, a few kilometres from Bambari.
Anti-Balaka activists held a demonstration following the death of an Anti-Balaka chief nicknamed Fally during a gunfight with police.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 500 ex-combatants from the Kaga-Bandoro area voluntarily gave up their arms and agreed to take part in DDR.

Looting: Anti-Balaka fighters aligned with recently killed leader Fally attacked the town of Gamandji to ""avenge their leader"". They looted homes and shops, demanded money from traders, and then fired at the villagers to force them to flee the town. The gunmen then set fire to the village. There were no reports of casualties.

column16: RCA (Central African Republic); Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo)
column17: A march was conducted by residents of Bambari against the validation of the parliamentary election results by the Constitutional Court of Transition (CAT) (sic). The protesters gave a memo to MINUSCA with recommendations, while also passing the Sangaris and EDF offices.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Central Office for the Repression of Banditry
column17: A former anti-Balaka fighter accused of committing armed robbery was beaten and taken to the OCRB headquarters. The leader of the OCRB then demanded a ransom from his family, before releasing him later without charges.

According to the UN OCHA, Over 10,000 people have been displaced in week-long clashes between unidentified rival armed groups in the Koui and Bocaranga areas. Attacks against civilians have also occurred in the area. No specific casualties were reported.

According to the UN OCHA, Over 10,000 people have been displaced in week-long clashes between unidentified rival armed groups in the Koui and Bocaranga areas. Attacks against civilians have also occurred in the area. No specific casualties were reported.

According to the UN OCHA, Over 10,000 people have been displaced in week-long clashes between unidentified rival armed groups in the Koui and Bocaranga areas. Attacks against civilians have also occurred in the area. No specific casualties were reported.
Anti-Balaka and armed Fulani clashed near the town of Yelewa. The reasons for the clash were not clear. No casualties were reported.

According to the UN OCHA, Over 10,000 people have been displaced in week-long clashes between unidentified rival armed groups in the Koui and Bocaranga areas. Attacks against civilians have also occurred in the area. No specific casualties were reported.
Ex-Seleka of the MPC allegedly killed a young merchant at a road-block in Batangafo. The body was found after the fact; the exact date of the killing is unknown.

Armel Sayo, leader of the RJ and a former minister, dismissed his chief of staff for ""campaigns to create disorder in our movement"". This event was included due to its potential to lead to future violence.

According to the UN OCHA, Over 10,000 people have been displaced in week-long clashes between unidentified rival armed groups in the Koui and Bocaranga areas. Attacks against civilians have also occurred in the area. No specific casualties were reported.

According to the UN OCHA, Over 10,000 people have been displaced in week-long clashes between unidentified rival armed groups in the Koui and Bocaranga areas. Attacks against civilians have also occurred in the area. No specific casualties were reported.
Suspected former Seleka militiamen broke into a mans house and ""tortured"" him after arriving in his village in the Kabo area and firing into the air to frighten the residents.
Members of the MPC, a Seleka militia, have recently arrived in Ndele in large numbers and have been ""committing abuses"" although no casualties have been reported.
10 people were wounded in an attack by suspected former Seleka militants on a vehicle traveling from Sibut to Gimari.
The youth of Bozoum say armed groups have in recent days engaged in unspecified abuses against the population in the Bozoum area.
Youth employed by ""Mains dOeuvres High Intensity"" protested outside the UN Program Development Office to demand payment of wages.
Bossoukpa village was burned down in the Bossangoa area. No casualties were reported.
Conflict between herders and farmers left 8 dead and 4 wounded in the Kaga-Bandoro area.
The MPs of Paoua and Mbres say that armed Fulani have engaged in almost daily killings and other abuses in their areas in recent weeks (unknown fatalities coded as 10).
The MPs of Paoua and Mbres say that armed Fulani have engaged in almost daily killings and other abuses in their areas in recent weeks (unknown fatalities coded as 10).

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: MINUSCA peacekeepers from Gabon and Burundi have been accused of carrying out 2 new cases of sexual abuse in Kemo province. Both of the victims were under 18.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
column17: A humanitarian worker was assaulted by police at the Bambari gendarmerie after refusing to pay fees leveled against him.

column9: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: A convoy of vehicles was ambushed by unidentified assailants who stole their goods, and killed one of their drivers. The driver was an employee of MSF.
A man working towards the reconciliation of the Christian and Muslim communities in Berberati was attacked with a machete by suspected Anti-Balaka members.
Students from Boganda high school marched to demand clarification on the list of candidates for the Brevet (BC).
Residents of Berberati protested after a man working towards reconciliation between the Christian and Muslim communities in the area was attacked with a machete by suspected Anti-Balaka members.

column6: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column17: About 100 armed men from former Seleka faction FDPC occupied the village of Bitiyo in the Baboua area.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: After an ex-Seleka member attempted to stab a trader over a personal dispute, MINUSCA forces intervened and ""won the battle"", arresting at least one Seleka member after the incident. More Seleka forces entered the town but eventually left after MINUSCA patrols were stepped up. The area is considered a stronghold of the RJ faction of the former Seleka.
After an ex-Seleka member attempted to stab a trader and an intervention by MINUSCA, young residents of Paoua burned the assailants motorcycle in retaliation.

column6: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column17: 154 members of the former Seleka militia FDPC along with their leader General Abdoulaye Miskine have ""decided to abandon the armed struggle"". They have been encamped at Zoukoumbo town and have asked for help from the government to afford to remain there.
A confrontation occurred between the residents of Zemio and Ugandan forces in the area after a quarrel between a Ugandan soldier and a resident over a woman.

14 people described either as former Seleka and arned Fulani were killed during a clash with ""internal security elements"" (described as a self-defense group in another article) in the city of Bang in the Ngaoundaye area. Negotiations had been ongoing with the Fulani to enter the city with their flocks but without their weapons, but they refused to disarm, which resulted in the clash after 3 armed Fulani youths were arrested in the morning. The commander of the brigade which opposed them and other members of the security forces were wounded in the gunfight.
Traders from Bimbo market organized a march to oppose their relocation to a new site.
At least 3 people were killed in clashes between Muslim and Christian community members which were the result of the alleged murder of a Muslim by a Christian in the PK5 neighbourhood of Bangui.
At least 17 people were kidnapped by LRA rebels in the Kadjema area of Obo. They also ""completely looted"" the town.
Clashes were reported between pastoralists and farmers near Ngaoundaye.
LRA rebels kidnapped 27 people from Modoguere in the Ippy locality and looted the village market.

column16: RFI; Radio Ndeke Luka; RCA (Central African Republic)
column17: Altercations were reported between protesters and Ugandan military forces based in Obo following the abduction of 17 people by the LRA in the nearby village of Obo. The protesters barricaded roads and burned tires, while the Ugandan soldiers fired on the protesters to disperse them. At least 1 civilian was injured by gunfire.

Protests continued related to the abduction of 17 people from the nearby Kadjema village. A young Ugandan officer was allegedly killed during the event during which Ugandan soldiers tore a Central African flag while attempting to disperse the protesters.

column16: AFP; RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: Ex-Seleka and armed Fulani attacked Ngaoundaye this morning after entering the city on motorcycles, killing at least 10 people and injuring others, ransacking the city, burning the local gendarmerie building, cutting telephone wires, and causing displacement of the population. Elements of the gendarmerie sent to the area over the previous weekend left the area for Bozoum following the attack, although no specific interactions were reported between the security forces and the assailants.
Looting: A Capuchin mission was attacked by former Seleka rebels in the Ngaoundaye area. They looted the mission for food. No injuries were reported.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
column17: After the gendarmerie attempted to disarm anti-Balaka in the Bogangolo area, Anti-Balaka militiamen attacked the gendarmerie and recovered three of their weapons.

A self-defense group from Modoguere pursued LRA rebels who kidnapped 27 people from their locality. They killed 4 rebels and released 25 people during a clash. 2 members of the self-defense group were also injured.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: MINUSCA forces arrived in Ngaoundaye following an attack by former Seleka militiamen and their subsequent withdrawal from the city.

column9: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: A driver for the MSF was killed when a convoy belonging to the group was attacked by unidentified assailants between Sibut and Grimari. The convoy was carrying non-medical supplies including fuel.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: Former Seleka UPC elements moved into the Dekoa area and occupied a Telecel building.

Clashes in the Batangafo area and later in the towns of Wandago and Gondava between Fulani herders and former Seleka militiamen resulted in 16 killed and 20 wounded, mostly on the side of the Fulani herders, between Jun.19-20. The fighting occurred in part due to the militiamen restricting cattle movement. MIINUSCA forces later intervened and stopped the clashes in Batangafo.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 6 police officers were taken hostage by self-defense groups in the PK5 area of Bangui. They were released after 5 days in captivity in return for the release of 4 prisoners held by the security forces.

Looting: Unidentified armed men looted the offices of MSF Bambari. Although the attackers identities are unknown, the area is mostly controlled by the UPC former Seleka group, but also shared with Anti-Balaka.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column7: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: A coalition of MPC-FPRC clashed with UPC fighters in Batangafo, resulting in 3 killed and 10 wounded, mostly on the side of the UPC. The fighting led to a large displacement of people, although they mostly returned the next day.

Clashes in the Batangafo area and later in the towns of Wandago and Gondava between Fulani herders and former Seleka militiamen resulted in 16 killed and 20 wounded, mostly on the side of the Fulani herders, between Jun.19-20. The fighting occurred in part due to the militiamen restricting cattle movement. MIINUSCA forces later intervened and stopped the clashes in Batangafo.

Clashes in the Batangafo area and later in the towns of Wandago and Gondava between Fulani herders and former Seleka militiamen resulted in 16 killed and 20 wounded, mostly on the side of the Fulani herders, between Jun.19-20. The fighting occurred in part due to the militiamen restricting cattle movement. MIINUSCA forces later intervened and stopped the clashes in Batangafo.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column7: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column16: Xinhua; Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo); Cameroon Tribune; RFI; AFP
column17: Bangladeshi MINUSCA peacekeepers and national forces clashed with a local self-defense group in the PK5 area of Bangui after they allegedly attacked a police station. The results of the clash 1 peacekeeper was injured by a grenade and at least 3 fatalities were reported among the attackers. 3 people were also arrested. It was also reported that MINUSCA peacekeepers had gone to PK5 to secure the release of police officers leading to fatalities, but it was not clear whether the police station attack was in retaliation or prompted the MINUSCA action.
Clashes were reported between different Seleka militia factions in Bambari, Kabo and Kaga-Bandoro.

The President of the Special Delegation to Niem-Yelewa and spokesman for traditional Fulani leaders said that the Niem-Yelewa area has been turned into a battlefield recently by clashes between armed groups, including armed Fulani cattle rustlers. He referred to many casualties caused by the clashes (coded as 10) as well as villages beinb burned and a large amount of displacement of people, primarily to Bouar.
Clashes were reported between different Seleka militia factions in Bambari, Kabo and Kaga-Bandoro.
Clashes were reported between different Seleka militia factions in Bambari, Kabo and Kaga-Bandoro.
Suspected former Seleka militiamen kidnapped 2 people during a raid on Dekoa village to carry goods looted from the area.
""An INGO staff member was killed in a hotel in Kaga Bandoro.""

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: A Senegalese MINUSCA peacekeeper was killed by unidentified armed assailants

column6: Mutiny of UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: Surrender/Defect:6 generals of the UPC have allegedly defected from the group, although it is not clear if they are now independent or have joined the PRGF.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: A public transport vehicle was attacked by heavily armed gunmen wearing military uniforms near Ndissi village after leaving Kabo for Kaga-Bandoro. At least 9 people were killed in the attack which was allegedly carried out by allies of the former Seleka militia UPC.
3 people were kidnapped from the Obo-Mboki axis by LRA rebels.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: A man close to General Zoundeko of the FPRC was killed by fighters led by Ali Daras of the UPC, resulting in a gunfight.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: Mutiny of UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: AFP; RCA (Central African Republic); Africa News; Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: Clashes in Bambari were reported between two factions of the UPC, although it was unclear if the second faction was now independent or had defected to another former Seleka militia (most likely the PRGF). The alleged catalyst for the clashes was the killing of a man close to General Zoundeko of the PRGF. At least 10 people were killed and 25 wounded in the fighting which took place near the house of Ali Daras, a leader of the UPC.
A youth was kidnapped by LRA rebels about 8km southeast of Obo.

Surrender/Defect:A senior leader of an Anti-Balaka force in Yaloke has ordered his men to surrender their weapons including AK47s, RPGs and grenades. He has said that if this gesture of peace is accepted, he will proceed to convince other Anti-Balaka groups to surrender their weapons as well.
2 people were killed and 8 others taken hostage by the LRA during an attack on the village of Kpata, during which they also looted property. 4 of the hostages later escaped.

column7: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: Young people recruited in 2013 gathered and demonstrated in Bangui to demand their incorporation into the army.
The morning after an LRA attack in Kpata, some youths from the village pursued the LRA rebels and killed 3 of them.
Farmers whose land was used to build a MINUSCA base in Bouar staged a sit-in in front of the base to demand their promised compensation.
Central African MPs have accused Cameroonian forces of illegally occupying CARs territory in Koui area and around Ngaoui.
Central African MPs have accused Cameroonian forces of illegally occupying CARs territory in Koui area and around Ngaoui.
Central African MPs have accused Chadian forces of illegally occupying CARs territory in Ouham, specifically the villages of Markounda and Kabo.

Central African MPs have accused Cameroonian forces of illegally occupying CARs territory in the Koui and Nana-Mambere areas, including the villages of Gaigo, Minimal, Cantonnier, Mbartoua, Kounde, and Ngaoui.

3 people were killed (2 more later died from their injuries) and 15 others injured in an attack by armed Fulani herdsmen and former Seleka fighters on Ngakobo in the Bambari area. Several more were injured, while hundreds fled their homes.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
column17: Arrests: Jean Francis Bozize, son of former CAR leader Francois Bozize and defence minister in his cabinet, voluntarily handed himself in to MINUSCA forces in Bangui. An arrest warrant had been outstanding for him since May 2014 for suspected involvement in human rights abuses.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column16: RFI; RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: A group of heavily-armed former Seleka fighters including a number of leaders of the PRGF faction left Bangui for Kaga-Bandoro (considered a FPRC stronghold), forcing their way through at least one police checkpoint. Both sides allegedly opened fire, but the convoy reportedly passed without any reported casualties.

Ugandan military forces have begun withdrawing from their operation against the LRA in CAR. They are currently withdrawing from their forward bases to Obo, ahead of the final departure back to Uganda.

column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column17: After a young man died under uncertain circumstances, but allegedly murdered by an MP of the Paoua area, angry residents attacked the MPs home, looted it and torched vehicles. Religious leaders intervened to calm the protesters. The MP took refuge in the MINUSCA base in the city.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: Around 35 heavily-armed former Seleka rebels were intercepted by MINUSCA in Sibut, resulting in 2 Seleka fighters killed, some injuries, and 10 captured. These were allegedly part of the group affiliated with the FPRC which illegally left Bangui the night before.

A number of former Seleka fighters have allegedly been gathering in Bria, although the reason is not known. This is in the context of a number of heavily-armed Seleka having left the capital illegally and heading towards Kaga-Bandoro.

Residents of Ngakobo engaged in a protest march to demand the depature of the Mauritanian contingent of MINUSCA after a man was murdered. The population believes the MINUSCA contingent was complicit in the mans death.

Former Seleka fighters clashed with a youth self-defense group near Woulo (3km from Dekoa) who arrived during an attack by Seleka fighters who were attempting to take hostages. At least one person was reported killed.

column7: MDRP: Resistance Movement for the Defense of the Fatherland
column17: Residents of Bambari marched to demand improved security conditions in Ouaka and the arrest of the leaders of the UPC. The event was organized by the MDRP.
The chief of Yoro village as well as his brother were killed by former Seleka fighters in a nearby field. The attack followed a clash between former Seleka fighters and a Dekoa self-defense militia.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: The forces of minusca expelled about 200 heavily armed men from Boguila. The identity and affiliation of the armed men is not mentioned. No casualties reported.
Several people were wounded by former Seleka fighters who attacked Yoro during a wake for the village chief and his brother who were earlier killed by former Seleka fighters.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Presidential Security Unit
column17: A firefight breaks out between the Gendarmerie in the Fatima neighbourhood after the Guard erect a checkpoint. No casualties reported.

column16: RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: 19 people were killed, 3,500 displaced, and 481 houses burned in an attack by former Seleka fighters on the Kouango area, including the villages of PK9 and PK13, after a Muslim was allegedly killed in the area.

column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; RCA (Central African Republic)
column17: A young Muslim was allegedly killed in the Kouango area, leading to later retaliations by former Seleka fighters.

column16: RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: 19 people were killed, 3,500 displaced, and 481 houses burned in an attack by former Seleka fighters on the Kouango area, including the villages of PK9 and PK13, after a Muslim was allegedly killed in the area.

column7: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column16: Cameroon Tribune; RFI; AFP; Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: After Anti-Balaka forces arrived in Ndomete allegedly to oust ex-Seleka fighters from Kaga-Bandoro (controlled by the FPRC), the ex-Seleka forces ""besieged"" the district, forcing the retreat of the Anti-Balaka forces. Over 2 days of fighting, at least 4 people were killed in Ndomete according to MINUSCA, although other sources claimed as many as 19 fatalities. MINUSCA intervened to separate the two groups.

column7: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column16: RFI; Cameroon Tribune; Radio Ndeke Luka; AFP
column17: During ongoing clashes with Anti-Balaka forces in the Ndomete area, ex-Seleka fighters attacked the civilian populations of Kaga-Bandoro (controlled by the FPRC) over 2 days, killing at least 2 people in the city according to MINUSCA, although other sources said as many as 5 were killed. Looting was also reported, specifically of houses belonging to peacekeepers.
Between Sept.13-22, Colonel Sidikis Anti-Balaka fighters killed dozens (coded as 12) in at least 2 attacks on the Koui area.
The forces of Colonel Sidiki based at Sangrelim were allegedly attacked by an unidentified force, resulting in retaliatory violence against civilians in the Koui area.

column7: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column16: Cameroon Tribune; AFP; Radio Ndeke Luka; RFI
column17: After Anti-Balaka forces arrived in Ndomete allegedly to oust ex-Seleka fighters from Kaga-Bandoro (controlled by the FPRC), the ex-Seleka forces ""besieged"" the district, forcing the retreat of the Anti-Balaka forces. Over 2 days of fighting, at least 19 people were killed in Ndomete, although it was not clear how many of these were civilians. MINUSCA intervened to separate the two groups.

column7: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa

column17: During ongoing clashes with Anti-Balaka forces in the Ndomete area, ex-Seleka fighters attacked the civilian populations of Kaga-Bandoro (controlled by the FPRC) over 2 days, killing at least 2 people in the city according to MINUSCA, although other sources said as many as 5 were killed. Looting was also reported, specifically of houses belonging to peacekeepers.
On September 19, the Lord's Resistance Army attacks Tabane 1 village, 20 kilometres from Zemio, led to the displacement of about 700 people.

6 people were killed, including the village chief of Dangobira, after fighters led by Colonel Sidiki (believed to be Anti-Balaka fighters) attacked several villages in the Koui area, including Sangre, Bouzou, Sangaldoro, Kelamawele and Dangobira. The actions were allegedly prompted by an attack on Colonel Sidikis forces which had been based at Sangrelim.
Between Sept.13-22, Colonel Sidikis Anti-Balaka fighters killed dozens (coded as 12) in at least 2 attacks on Degaulle town, Koui area.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: A leader of a former Seleka faction organized a march against MINUSCA which was intercepted by police who arrested him and another leader of the march. The march was allegedly banned although its leaders claimed they weren't informed.
600 prisoners at the Bangui prison house protested against their conditions and alleged physial abuse by guards.

RRR militiamen attacked the De Gaulle area of Koui subprefecture, torturing at least one civilian and killing at least 5. A number of women and girls were also raped (around 23). Some people were also taken hostage during the attack.
An INTERSOS office/dormitory was attacked and robbed by unidentified assailants. Humanitarian workers from the organization were beaten and had to be hospitalized.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Deployment:MINUSCA forces have been deployed to Bocaranga in the Koui area following violence by Anti-Balaka fighters under the command of Colonel Sidiki.

Anti-Balaka fighters under the command of Colonel Sidiki ""besieged"" Koui, firing heavy and light weapons in the locality as they stormed the village of De Gaulle. Many people were displaced in the violence. The siege continued till Sept.29, 20 civilians were killed and at least 8 people were seriously injured on Sept.27.
A man was killed at his residence in Kaga-Bandoro in an alleged robbery by former Seleka fighters staying in the city.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: After a man was killed by alleged former Seleka fighters, residents of Kaga-Bandoro stormed the front of the MINUSCA office in the town and demanded the departure of the Pakistani contingent. The protesters were dispersed peacefully by the UN.
A number of hostages taken by RRR militiamen during an attack on De Gaulle village in Koui subprefecture were tortured afterwards.

Anti-Balaka fighters under the command of Colonel Sidiki ""besieged"" Koui, firing heavy and light weapons in the locality as they stormed the village of De Gaulle. Many people were displaced in the violence. The siege continued till Sept.29, 20 civilians were killed and at least 8 people were seriously injured on Sept.27.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column9: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Residents of the Gbakondja Yassimandji neighbourhood of the 5th district of Bangui protested to demand the municipality provide electricity and deal with garbage collection which has become backed up in their area. MINUSCA and local police were on hand but no incidents were reported.

Anti-Balaka fighters under the command of Colonel Sidiki ""besieged"" Koui, firing heavy and light weapons in the locality as they stormed the village of De Gaulle. Many people were displaced in the violence. The siege continued till Sept.29, 20 civilians were killed and at least 8 people were seriously injured on Sept.27.
Abdul Dandas militia took a man hostage in the KM5 area. It is not clear what the reason behind his kidnapping was, but he was released two weeks later after the new cardinal of Bangui intervened.

At least 15 humanitarian workers have been attacked since Sept.14 in the Kaga-Bandoro area following increased tensions between ex-Seleka and anti-Balaka groups caused by MINUSCAs dismantling of barriers and toll stations used to tax local populations. These assaults were largely connected with robberies.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: The commander of CARs army (FACA) was killed and his son injured in an attack by a militia led by Abdul Danda in the PK5 neighbourhood in Banguis 3rd district leading to unrest in the city. Abdul Dandas militia have allegedly been involved in numerous abuses against civilians according to the COMUC. After the death of the commander, FACA soldiers attempted to arrest members of Abdul Dandas militia, resulting in 2 self-defense fighters killed and injuries to 4 soldiers. MINUSCA forces intervened to separate the two armed groups. Abdul Danda later died his groups involvement.

Following the death of the commander of CARs army, self-defense militias in PK5 erected barricades to prevent entry/exit to the district where the commander was killed. Violence broke out in this area as well as the 3rd (where PK5 is located), 5th and 6th districts of the capital, resulting in a number of injuries. 3 Fulani farmers were reported killed in retaliatory violence during the unrest. MINUSCA forces intervened to end the clashes in the various districts. According to MINUSCA, in total 11 people were killed, 14 are missing, and 11 were injured during the violence (5 fatalities not coded in other events spread across the 3 districts).

Violence broke out in this area as well as the 3rd (where PK5 is located), 5th and 6th districts of the capital, resulting in a number of injuries. 3 Fulani farmers were reported killed in retaliatory violence during the unrest. MINUSCA forces intervened to end the clashes in the various districts. According to MINUSCA, in total 11 people were killed, 14 are missing, and 11 were injured during the violence (5 fatalities not coded in other events spread across the 3 districts).

MINUSCA forces intervened to end the clashes in the various districts. According to MINUSCA, in total 11 people were killed, 14 are missing, and 11 were injured during the violence (5 fatalities not coded in other events spread across the 3 districts).
3 Fulani farmers were killed in retaliatory violence during unrest in Bangui following the killing of a FACA commander.
About 300 people staged a peace march in PK5 following recent violence in the district.

column7: RPRC: Patriotic Movement for the Rebirth of the Central African People
column17: Some ex-Seleka fighters attempted to steal a generator belonging to a community radio station stored in a private residence. Some residents intervened and killed one of the robbers with an arrow and wounded another before the rest fled. They were allegedly members of the Patriotic Movement of CAR (RPRC).
The first Catholic cardinal of CAR based in Bangui led a peace march in the city.

column7: RPRC: Patriotic Movement for the Rebirth of the Central African People
column17: After an ex-Seleka fighter was killed and another wounded in an attempted robbery, members of the RPRC attacked an IDP site and buildings of the local bishopric, burning the rectory, bishops house, and many other houses in Kaga-Bandoro. A number of civilians were killed (coded as 10) in the violence before UN forces intervened. At least 5,000 people took refuge around the MINUSCA base in Kaga-Bandoro during and after the events. In total, the violence in the city resulted in 30 killed and at least 60 wounded (20 coded in another event).

column7: RPRC: Patriotic Movement for the Rebirth of the Central African People
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: RPRC members attacked an IDP camp and clashed with MINUSCA forces in and around Kaga-Bandoro. A helicopter flight and reinforcements were dispatched to support the peacekeepers. At least 12 attackers and a number of civilians were reported killed in the violence which occurred during clashes between the ex-Seleka and peacekeeping forces. In total, the violence in the city resulted in 37 killed and at least 57 wounded (10 fatalities coded in another event).
2 people were killed by ex-Seleka fighters in Kaga-Bandoro. No further details were reported.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: A clash broke out in Gbakomalekpa, near Bambari, after anti-Balaka forces stopped a civilian convoy carrying livestock which was protected by MINUSCA peacekeepers and demanded money, which the peacekeepers refused to pay. 2 anti-Balaka fighters and a civilian were killed, while 3 civilians and 5 peacekeepers were injured in the resulting violence.

column9: ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross and Red Crescent; Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: Several administrative buildings and local NGOs were looted by unidentified armed men during the violence that followed an violence and clashes between ex-Seleka and MINUSCA forces in Kaga-Bandoro. An ICRC member was reported killed during the incidents.

column7: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 11 people were killed and at least 10 wounded in an attack allegedly by ex-Seleka members of the UPC against an IDP camp in Ngakobo. MINUSCA patrols were stepped up after the attack.
1 person was killed and 3 kidnapped in an LRA attack on Derbissaka village. 2 days later the hostages were released.
Residents of the Beaver neighbourhood of Bangui protested against the perceived negligence of peacekeepers in Kaga-Bandoro in terms of preventing abuses of the population by ex-Seleka.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: RCA (Central African Republic); AFP; Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: A dead city protest strike was observed in Bangui against MINUSCA during which barricades were erected on various roads. At one point MINUSCA peacekeepers deployed alongside national police personnel allegedly used tear gas and aerial firing to disperse some crowds in the Sango neighbourhood, resulting in 4 people killed and 11 others wounded, including 5 peacekeepers. A MINUSCA spokesman said that peacekeepers had not fired on civilians but had intervened to dismantle barricades manned by armed individuals. Gunfire and looting were also reported in other areas of Bangui. A partial dead city protest strike was also observed against MINUSCA in Nzako on the call of civil society groups. Only the cities administration remained closed however.
Dead city protesters threw stones at people boycotting the dead city strike in KM5 and Banguis 3rd district. No casualties were reported.
Dead city protesters threw stones at people boycotting the dead city strike in KM5 and Banguis 3rd district. No casualties were reported.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Clashes between Anti-Balaka rebels and Sidiki elements of the armed movement Back Claim and Restoration (RRR) in the village of Mokonzi Wali, 20 km from Koui.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka elements and ex-Seleka had caused 15 deaths and a number of wounded in Mbriki and Belima, near Bambari.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Three villages located 27 kilometres from Paoua were burned by armed groups. These attacks are attributed to elements of the group Revolution Justice (RJ) Armel Sayo and the Seleka elements. No report of casualties.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Six UN policemen and four civilians were killed Friday morning during an ambush on the Bambari-Grimari axis. A child of seven was wounded and is being treated by peacekeepers Mauritanian.

At least 10 people, including a self-defense group leader, were killed and many wounded in the PK5 neighborhood in clashes between the vigilante Mohammed Ali Fadul and two other groups led by Issa Kapi, aka 50-50, and Abdul Danda. Among the dead would appear the murderer of a commander of the Central African Armed Forces (FACA) killed in PK5 there three weeks ago.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Two civilians died and one peacekeeper was seriously injured in an attack by an armed group on a convoy on Grimari Bambari-axis. Anti-Balaka is accused of the attack while they denied any responsibility.
Members of the Muslim community have decided to take revenge after the discovery of a Muslim body suspected to be murdered by Christians on Saturday night"" in the 3rd district of Bangui.

column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Clashes between Seleka and FPRC near the town of Bria. A hospital source said two bodies were taken to hospital in Bria and one wounded. No population movements are reported at this time.
""An INGO male staff member was shot and killed by armed men while he was driving his motorcycle to work.""

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: An aid worker of the Danish Council for Refugees NGO (DRC) was tied up and beat to death by armed people in an ambush, over the night between Tuesday and Wednesday close to Nana-Bakassa.
Anti-Balaka fighters killed a Fulani man in the Bocaranga area.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: Arrests: Two men, included the rebel generals henchman Amadou Ousmane, close to General Sidiki, rebel leader in Ouham Pende were arrested this Friday at Bangui MPoko airport as they tried to leave the capital for the town of Paoua.

Clashes between the group of self-defense and armed men affiliated to Ex-combatants Seleka and Revolution Justice (RJ) took place this Sunday in the village Gouze 20 km from Paoua on the Bozoum axis. According to Percus Kette, MP for Paoua 4, the area is in the hands of the assailants.

column17: Militants of the Unit for Peace in the Central African Republic (UPC) and those of the Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa (FPRC) have clashed for since Sunday in the village Kalaga located 45 km from Bria. No casualty toll is yet available.
