column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: Clashes continued between suspected UPC and FPRC forces

The RRR (3R) militia is reported by Human Rights Watch to have killed at least 50 civilians in the Bocaranga and Koui subprefectures of CAR between Nov.21-27 (50 fatalities coded across 14 events). They are also accused of having raped women and girls and burned/looted villages.

The RRR (3R) militia is reported by Human Rights Watch to have killed at least 50 civilians in the Bocaranga and Koui subprefectures of CAR between Nov.21-27 (50 fatalities coded across 14 events). They are also accused of having raped women and girls and burned/looted villages.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: 5 Peuhl (Fulani) civilians were killed outside Golaga, near Bria, by unidentified assailants with guns, machetes and knives. 3 others are missing and presumed dead. FPRC fighters are suspected due to ongoing violence between them and the PRGF and the UPC, which is a mostly Peuhl group.

The RRR (3R) militia is reported by Human Rights Watch to have killed at least 50 civilians in the Bocaranga and Koui subprefectures of CAR between Nov.21-27 (50 fatalities coded across 14 events). They are also accused of having raped women and girls and burned/looted villages.

The RRR (3R) militia is reported by Human Rights Watch to have killed at least 50 civilians in the Bocaranga and Koui subprefectures of CAR between Nov.21-27 (50 fatalities coded across 14 events). They are also accused of having raped women and girls and burned/looted villages.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: A youth was killed by UPC fighters 3km outside Bria. A witness said they fired without warning.
2 people were killed in a clash between two Anti-Balaka factions over cattle ownership.

The RRR (3R) militia is reported by Human Rights Watch to have killed at least 50 civilians in the Bocaranga and Koui subprefectures of CAR between Nov.21-27 (50 fatalities coded across 14 events). They are also accused of having raped women and girls and burned/looted villages.

The RRR (3R) militia is reported by Human Rights Watch to have killed at least 50 civilians in the Bocaranga and Koui subprefectures of CAR between Nov.21-27 (50 fatalities coded across 14 events). They are also accused of having raped women and girls and burned/looted villages.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: A suspected UPC member (described as a uniformed ""Peuhl fighter"") shot at a civilian outside of Bria but did not hit him.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: A suspected UPC member (described as a uniformed ""Peuhl fighter"") shot and killed a civilian outside of Bria in the Gobolo area.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Unidentified gunmen attacked MINUSCA peacekeepers protecting an IDP camp in the Kaga-Bandoro area. No casualties were reported.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: Two former Seleka factions, the UPC and FPRC, clashed in the Bakala area.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: UPC fighters forced FPRC fighters out of Piangou village where they had been based for several days.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
column8: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column17: A gendermarie officer was taken hostage by MPC fighters in the Paoua area.
The deputy-chairman of the special delegation of Dana Gboudou commune was killed by unidentified assailants in Ouaka.
Abubakr Sidikis Anti-Balaka group RRR allegedly took over the city of NDjim. RRR is active in the Ouham-Pende region.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column9: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: Ex-Seleka members of the RJ and UPC attacked a gendarmerie station in Paoua. MINUSCA peacekeepers came to their aid and assisted in repelling the attack.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: Residents of Bakala say at least 186 people were killed during clashes between the FPRC and UPC between Dec.11-12. It is not clear how many were combatants or civilians, or if civilians were targeted specifically during the fighting.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: The UPC ""quickly started to kill civilians"" on the same day that they took Bakala from the FPRC. At least 2 civilians were reported killed by witnesses.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: The UPC took control of Bakala from the FPRC. No casualties reported.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: Residents of Bakala say at least 186 people were killed during clashes between the FPRC and UPC between Dec.11-12. It is not clear how many were combatants or civilians, or if civilians were targeted specifically during the fighting.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: UPC fighters executed 25 civilians at a school in Bakala after they took the town earlier in the week. The same day UPC fighters also killed 7 people as they returned from a nearby gold mine. They accused those killed of having supported Anti-Balaka forces.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Non-violent activity: 15 December. During the week, 3R occupied the village of Besson. The group reportedly came to the village following reports of cattle theft by the FDPC.
A breeder was kidnapped by LRA fighters just outside Obo.
LRA rebels kidnapped 17 people, including a religious leader, in Kono village near Nzako.
LRA rebels raided another town near Nzako.
Unidentified assailants attacked Bondiba near Baboua, killing one person and wounding several others. The assailants were allegedly searching for oxen stolen by FPRC fighters.
National Urban Transport Company (SONATU) staff and Central African Telecommunications Corporation (SOCATEL) staff staged demos in different parts of Bangui over backpay.
A hunter was kidnapped by a group of armed men in Djiba village, near Baboua.

A clash between two youths, which resulted in one dead, led to a larger gunfight in Batangafo. Few details were reported but it seems the fight may have happened in a stronghold of ex-combatants of the Seleka coalition. The source said it did not hold any reliable information to confirm whether the ex-Seleka had fired shots.

column9: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: An MSF staff member was wounded in a robbery by unidentified assailants in the Bambari area.
Residents of Ngaoundaye protested and barricaded the main road to Bangui over the withdrawal of Cameroonian peacekeepers from their area.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: A large number of FPRC fighters from Ndele, Bamingui and other localities have gathered in Mbres following recent clashes in Bria. This has caused issue with the local population and ""paralyzed activities"" in the city.

column9: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: A second attack on MSF workers was reported in Bambari, although no injuries were reported.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: At least 10 civilians were reported killed in a UPC attack on Yambele, southeast of Bambari, by HRW.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: AFP; Maghreb Emergent; RCA (Central African Republic)
column17: 2 Moroccan peacekeepers were killed in an attack by unidentified gunmen on a MINUSCA convoy traveling in the Mboki area. 2 soldiers were also injured.

Clashes were reported in the Ouham-Pende localities of Pende and Santouwane between RRR and Anti-Balaka fighters. As many as 6 RRR fighters were killed in these clashes, and 2 Anti-Balaka fighters seriously injured. The fatalities were disaggregated between the two locations. The coordinates for Santouwane are approximate, based on information provided in an ACF report.

Clashes were reported in the Ouham-Pende localities of Pende and Santouwane between RRR and Anti-Balaka fighters. As many as 6 RRR fighters were killed in these clashes, and 2 Anti-Balaka fighters seriously injured. The fatalities were disaggregated between the two locations.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: MINUSCA fighters were attacked in the Bocaranga area by Anti-Balaka fighters, resulting in at least one Bangladeshi peacekeeper killed. RRR forces were also reported in the area, but it was not clear if they participated in the event.

column6: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column17: Women whose husbands are part of the former Seleka coalition have been attacked recently by MPC members in Kaga Bandoro. The MPC are allegedly looking for information on their relatives who are fighters.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: UPC fighters have allegedly set up a base in Ngolo village, located a few kilometers from Bakouma

A woman was attacked by a group of youth in Berberati after being accused of being a witch and involved in the death of a young man in a hunting accident. MINUSCA forces intervened and saved the woman.

Looting: Suspected LRA forces attacked Gambatoure, CAR. They were armed with AK type weapons, and dressed in military and civilian clothing. The group consisted of men, women and children.They looted food and communications equipment from the community.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: A man and his two children were killed by UPC fighters in Mourouba, near Bakala.

Suspected LRA forces attacked a pastoralist camp near Yangou Brindi, CAR, killing 3 cows and taking the meat. The group was comprised of men, women, and children. The men were armed with AK-type weapons and wore a mix of civilian and military clothing.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: In January, Human Rights Watch documented other killings of civilians by the UPC, including 2 civilians killed in Kpele.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: In January, Human Rights Watch documented several killings of civilians by the UPC in the Bambari area, including an unknown number in Ouropo and at least four in Moko.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: In January, Human Rights Watch documented several killings of civilians by the UPC in the Bambari area, including an unknown number in Ouropo and at least four in Moko. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.
LRA fighters abducted 3 civilians northwest of Mboki. One of the hostages was given money to buy supplies in return for the release of the other two.
Taxi and bus drivers engaged in a work stoppage over harassment by the police.

Suspected Anti-Balaka fighters shot some civilians in Bozoum after the local MINUSCA contingent withdrew from the city over allegations of trading in liquor. The base was looted soon after the contingent left by suspected Anti-Balaka fighters as well.
2 Ugandan soldiers were killed by suspected LRA fighters who ambushed them in Kitife village in the Zemio area. Several civilians were also wounded during the ambush.
Anti-Balaka fighters ambushed a vehicle near Bozoum and robbed its passengers.

Looting: LRA forces attacked 3 traders 10 km from Mboki, CAR. The assailants wore a mix of civilian and military clothing, and were armed with AK-type weapons. They spoke Sango, Acholi, and Zande. A trader was looted of cassava and meat.

6 suspected LRA forces including 2 men and 4 boys of less than 18, attacked a camp in a field north of Mboki, CAR. They looted peanuts, cassava, a motorbike battery, and palm wine. They abducted 3 people and forced them to porter the looted goods.
Young people who accused a woman of witchcraft in the Bougoumara area near Batangafo buried her alive.

Suspected LRA forces attacked the mining camp of Gbodio, 7 km south of Malacha in Haute-Kotto, CAR. The assailants were armed with AK-type weapons, and wore a mix of civilian and military clothing. They looted food and non-food items from the mining camp. Coordinates are approximate based on location 7km south of Malacha.

Suspected LRA forces attacked a pastoralist camp near Zemio, CAR. The group of assailants was comprised of men, women and children. Some of the men were armed, and wore a mix of civilian and military clothing. They killed a number of cows.

A large group of suspected LRA forces attacked a motorcyclist on his way to Zemio, CAR, from Banangui, CAR. The group of assailants was comprised of men, women, and children. They asked the man for food and temporarily held him captive.
A group of young Anti-Balaka members attempted to set fire to the house of a man and lynch him for allegedly causing the death of a deputy in Damara using ""sorcery"". The man escaped unharmed.

Looting: Suspected LRA forces attacked a cyclist on his way to Mboki from Obo, CAR. The assailants wore a mix of civilian and military clothing, they had AK-type weapons, and spoke Acholi and Sango. They looted all of his belongings as well as a bag of sugar.

A large number of former Seleka fighters from several groups have been gathering in Bambari recently, causing concern among the population and administration of the city. The UN also warned the former Seleka groups against any conflict around the city which is a major aid distribution point.
Suspected LRA forces held 3 women captive overnight near the community of Bahr, CAR.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Deployment:MINUSCA forces have been drawn in from smaller bases and redeployed around Bambari after recent fighting between different ex-Seleka factions and fears of an impending attack on the town.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: Clashes were reported between UPC and Anti-Balaka fighters in Ngaboko. At least one Anti-Balaka leader was killed and another seriously injured, while at least 2 civilians were reportedly left in comas after the fighting.

RRR fighters attacked Bocaranga in the early morning on Feb.3, firing into the air to scare the population before looting several shops and vandalizing a church. At least 50 people took refuge at the local MONUSCA camp. At least 10 people were reported killed in the attack. Both the Danish Refugee Council and IRC were allegedly looted during the attack.

15 people were killed in clashes in and around Bocaranga between 3R and Anti-Balaka fighters. Some casualties were reported among the town's civilians, and many people were displaced. MINUSCA forces intervened in a clash between Anti-Balaka and 3R fighters in Bocaranga, opening fire on both sides to end the fighting.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column7: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: RFI; RCA (Central African Republic); Agence Congolaise de Presse
column17: FRPC-MPC and UPC fighters have engaged in clashes in the Ndassima between Feb.4-7, resulting in at least 20 people killed (fatalities coded across 4 events). The UPC fighters allegedly withdrew from the areas to Bamodo, but later took the cities back.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column7: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: RFI; Agence Congolaise de Presse; RCA (Central African Republic)
column17: FRPC-MPC and UPC fighters clashed in the Djoubissi areas of Ouaka. The UPC allegedly withdrew from the area but later retook it. No fatalities were reported.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column7: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: FRPC-MPC and UPC fighters have engaged in clashes in the Ndassima between Feb.4-7, resulting in at least 20 people killed (fatalities coded across 4 events). The UPC fighters allegedly withdrew from the areas to Bamodo, but later took the cities back.
A suspected LRA group abducted 13 civilians in Ngoulia, CAR, to porter looted goods from the community.
Looting: Suspected LRA forces attacked the mining camp of Yangou Bayoka, CAR (near Mbangana), twice on the same day. They looted sugar, rice, and cassava flour. All the miners fled in the bush.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column7: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: FRPC-MPC and UPC fighters have engaged in clashes in the Ndassima between Feb.4-7, resulting in at least 20 people killed (fatalities coded across 4 events). The UPC fighters allegedly withdrew from the areas to Bamodo, but later took the cities back.
Several hundred people protested on the tarmac at Mpoko airport to demand the disarmament of armed groups in the PK5 neighbourhood of Bangui.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
column17: The leader of a PK5 militia, Youssouf Sy (aka Big Man), one of his fighters and 2 civilians were killed during a joint operation by MINUSCA and CAR gendarmerie in the PK5 neighbourhood of Bangui. 3 gendarmerie personnel were also injured in the raid.

column9: Journalists (Central African Republic); Christian Group (Central African Republic)
column16: RFI; RCA (Central African Republic); AFP; AP
column17: A journalist and a pastor were killed and at least 24 people wounded in neighbourhoods around PK5 during reprisals after Youssouf Sy (aka Big Man), the head of a PK5 militia, was killed by a joint MINUSCA-CAR gendarmerie operation. At least 2 churches were also set on fire by the fighters.

Members of Youssouf Sy's militia from PK5 stormed a local UN-run health centre where some people injured in recent reprisals following the death of their group's leader were staying. No casualties were reported however.
At least one person was killed in an attack on Bera village by armed Fulani. Houses were also set on fire.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: The FPRC says it has taken control of Ippy ahead of their advance on Bambari to dislodge UPC fighters.

column6: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column17: Following an attack on the village of Bera by armed Fulani, members of the FDPC pursued and caught up with those responsible, recovering some of the property they stole. No casualties were reported.
3 people were killed and as many as 365 homes looted/burned as suspected former Seleka militiamen attacked Bowai village in the Nana-Bakassa area.
2 women were abducted and homes/businesses were burned in Derbissaka village (Rafia) by LRA rebels.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: The chief of staff of the FPRC and another fighter were killed in a MINUSCA airstrike on FPRC fighters as they advanced on Bambari. An FPRC spokesman said 3 civilians were killed and 5 others wounded, as well as houses destroyed during the airstrike. The attack took place just a few kms outside of Ippy at Ngawa 1. MINUSCA has declared attacking Bambari a ""red line"" that should not be crossed.

column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: Armed men from Chad wearing military uniforms entered Kaga-Bandoro and began shooting in the air, causing many residents to flee the area. They announced their intention to join the FPRC in their offensive against the UPC in Bambari.
LRA fighters attacked Karmada village, near Derbissaka. No details reported.
In mid-February anti-balaka fighters ambushed a group of civilians on a truck in the village of Ndoussoumba (central regions), killing at least 16 Peuhl civilians.

Suspected LRA forces attacked Derbissaka, CAR, and looted a number of households of food and non-food items. The assailants reportedly fired warning shots with AK-type weapons and abducted 4 community members as porters, including 2 women.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: MINUSCA peacekeepers clashed with FPRC fighters near Ippy, killing one and wounding another.
A suspected thief was killed by unidentified assailants in the Bozoum area following a robbery.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: The leader of the UPC, Ali Darass, and some Anti-Balaka leaders left Bambari after a request by MINUSCA and protests by its inhabitants. This is in the context of threats by the FPRC-MPC that they would attack the city to get at the UPC. Many UPC fighters remained in the city.

Residents of Bambari protested to demand the departure of Ali Darass, the leader of the UPC, from the city. Two marches occurred, one from the IDP camp protected by Sangaris and another from the Kidijigra neighbourhood of the city.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 4 MINUSCA peacekeepers were injured, one seriously, in a clash with FPRC fghters near Ippy.
People in Bangui's 2nd arrondissement protested to demand the collection of garbage in their area which has fallen behind. They blocked traffic for a few hours.
Looting: Suspected 4 LRA forces speaking Acholi, Zande, and Sango, looted a cyclist south of Ngouyo, CAR. The victim reportedly ran away, abandoning his bicycle.
A commercial vehicle was attacked by suspected former Seleka militiamen, killing one and injuring several others in Yagarandji village in the Kaga-Bandoro area.

Looting: 4 suspected LRA forces speaking Acholi and armed with AK-type weapons looted 3 cyclists south of Ngouyo, CAR. The victims reported that the assailants told them they were separated into two groups, one in the north and on in the south.

3 suspected LRA forces ambushed a cyclist near Ngouyo, CAR. The assailants spoke Acholi, Sango, and Zande. They wore military clothing and were armed with AK-type weapons. The assailants looted him of clothes, shoes, and 22,000 CFA, and held him captive overnight.

5 LRA forces abducted 11 civilians in Gambara, CAR. The assailants wore a mix of civilian and military clothing, boots, and they spoke Acholi and Zande. They looted the community of cassava, peanuts, rice, clothes, shoes, and handheld FM radios.

A large group of suspected LRA forces ambushed and abducted at least 7 civilians south of Ngouyo, CAR. The assailants looted salt, bags of clothes, money, an MP3 player, phones, and shoes from the victims whom they forced to porter the looted goods.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: One FPRC fighter was killed and at least 7 others wounded in a helicopter gunship attack by MINUSCA on a column of 40 FPRC fighters advancing on Bambari.

A suspected LRA group attacked pastoralists northwest of Rafai, CAR. The group of assailants was comprised of men, women and children. They killed 2 cows and reportedly held the pastoralists captive for a few hours.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Looting: Vehicles being escorted between Grimai and Bambari were stopped and looted by Anti-Balaka fighters. It was not clear if the two groups fought during the incident.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: A Senegalese peacekeeper was injured by unidentified assailants in Bangui, and later died of his wounds in hospital.
3 hunters were kidnapped by LRA fighters near Zemio. One of the hunters later escaped.
5 people were abducted by LRA fighters, including a village chief, during a raid on Kpiyamou village, 40km from Rafai. They also looted and ransacked the village. The chief was later released.

At least 11 people were killed by an unidentified armed group in the Danga-Gboudou locality in the villages of Mambissi (9) and Tagbara (2) between roughly Mar.8-12. Several other people were wounded and headed to Bambari for treatment.

Looting: 6 suspected LRA forces ambushed and looted 6 travelers on their way to Zemio, CAR. The victims were looted of clothes, mobile phones, an MP3 player, and money. The assailants wore a mix of civilian and military clothing, and spoke Acholi, Swahili, and Lingala.
A clash was reported between Anti-Balaka and former Seleka fighters in the Bamou neighbourhood of Kaga-Bandoro. No casualty figures were reported.

Students from the Faculty of Economics and Management at the University of Bangui protested and blocked the entrance to the school's administration to demand an extension to the registration period after as many as 1,500 students were unable to register before the deadline. The PM intervened to defuse the situation and reassure the students.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: The UPC has accused the FPRC of burning villages in the Agoudou-Manga area and killing as many as 45 civilians. The FPRC disputes these claims.
2 traders were killed and 7 people kidnapped by LRA fighters in a raid on Koumbadoule village, 16km from Zemio.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: The FPRC has accused the UPC of killing as many as 80 people in the Agoudou-Manga area.

Anti-balaka fighters attacked three Peuhl men in Yassine, a town in a gold- producing area northeast of Bambari, which had been under UPC control since 2014. Two of the men died - three witnesses described both men as local butchers who had not participated in fighting. A third man said he narrowly escaped after a bullet grazed his shoulder.
7 suspected LRA forces looted the community of Louete, CAR. They stole food and abducted a 15-year-old girl. They spoke Acholi and Sango and were armed with rifles and AK-type weapons.
One person was killed and 4 kidnapped in an attack by unidentified assailants on Bagari village on the Nguia-Bouar road. Livestock was also reported stolen.

column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: At least 10 people were killed during a clash between Anti-Balaka and former Seleka militiamen of the UPC in villages around Bakouma.
25 people were reportedly kidnapped by LRA fighters in the Djema sub-prefecture.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On March 20, anti-balaka and FPRC fighters in the towns of Wadja Wadja and Agoudou-Manga, suspecting an upcoming UPC attack, ordered town residents to move to Yassine for their safety. However, at about 5 a.m. the next day, UPC fighters attacked Yassine, killing at least 18 civilians, including at least 10 children.
A person kidnapped from Bangari village was killed during an attack the next day on Bodiba village in the same area. Livestock was stolen in both villages.

column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: Clashes between Anti-Balaka and suspected UPC fighters in the Bakouma area were reported to have moved into the city. A military source said 20 people, mainly civilians, had been killed during the clashes (10 coded in previous event).

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: At least 50 people were killed and dozens more injured, allegedly by UPC fighters, in the Agoudou-Manga area, including in Yassenemem, Agoudou-Manga and Nyouyanza villages. UPC denies their involvement.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: UPC sources say FPRC fighters have been raided villages in the Agoudou-Manga area controlled by the UPC. No casualties were reported.

column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: RFI; Radio Ndeke Luka; RCA (Central African Republic)
column17: Anti-Balaka and former Seleka militiamen (either UPC or FPRC, but both accused the other) clashed in Bria after the death of a youth in the city. MINUSCA later intervened to separate the two groups. At least 2 people were reported killed during the incident before MINUSCA's intervention.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: After MINUSCA forces intervened in a clash between Anti-Balaka and former Seleka forces, Anti-Balaka members allegedly opened fire on them, resulting in 1 killed, 2 wounded and 9 arrested among the assailants and one civilian wounded.

Looting: Suspected LRA forces ambushed 2 cyclists on their way to Dembia, from Rafai, CAR. The group of assailants was comprised of men, women, and children. The men wore a mix of civilian and military clothing, and they were armed with AK-type weapons. They looted money.

9 suspected LRA forces ambushed 6 civilians who were fishing north of Mboki, CAR. They looted a bag of fish, a jerry can, clothes, and a hunting rifle from the victims. They then allowed 5 of the victims to go, but abducted the sixth victim, a 14-year-old boy.
Unidentified gunmen killed a shopekeeper of PK12 and her motorcycle taxi driver in the north of Bangui, leading to protests.
After a female shopekeeper was killed in the Damara area, other female shopkeepers protested and closed their shops to demand an investigation.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column7: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 01 April. MINUSCA and military forces of CAR rescued 15 people abducted by LRA from Koubou village. The location of the recovery is not known. Clash assumed.
Local authorities say that RRR fighters have occupied the administrative buildings of Koui, including the local gendarmerie barracks.

MSF personnel reported that they had witnessed summary executions in Bria and seen bodies of those killed by armed groups in reprisals against the civilian population. The report was made following a recent trip to the city by MSF personnel (unknown fatalities).

column6: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column17: Former Seleka fighters of the MPC faction backed by RJ fighters allegedly took control of Ngaoundaye, causing many residents to flee the area. A number of deaths and casualties were reported, while the militiamen also allegedly looted churches in the area (unknown fatalities).
Looting: Anti-Balaka fighters looted Ngaoundaye and Bang following the withdrawal of Seleka fighters who had occupied and looted the Ngaoundaye for a day earlier in the week.
Looting: Anti-Balaka fighters looted Ngaoundaye and Bang following the withdrawal of Seleka fighters who had occupied and looted the Ngaoundaye for a day earlier in the week.
Residents of the 2nd arrondisement of Bangui protested to demand consistent electricity.

Unemployed graduates organized this Monday, April 10 a sit-in in front of the Renaissance Palace. They demanded that President Faustin Archange Touadera authorize their integration into the civil service.
A suspected LRA group attacked 2 men traveling to Banangui, CAR. One of the men was killed by the assailants and the other was seriously injured by a machete.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: A MINUSCA peacekeeper was injured by a stone thrown by a protester in Bambari. The protesters were angry over insecurity following the recent killing of an individual in the area.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: The town of Nzako was attacked by UPC fighters, resulting in several people killed .
Community relay officers demonstrated in front of UNICEF headquarters in Bangui to demand payment of their allowances of eight months.
2 members of a self-defense group in KM5 were killed by a youth from another group (not clear if it was another self-defense group).
LRA forces attacked pastoralists in Dembia, CAR. A woman was killed and 2 men were injured uring the attack.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: UPC fighters attacked the city of Zemio and the MINUSCA base there. 2 UPC were killed and several wounded during the incident.
MSF teams witness summary executions and recover mutilated bodies in Bakouma and Nzako since 26 March.
MSF teams witness summary executions and recover mutilated bodies in Bakouma and Nzako since 26 March.

column6: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column9: Christian Group (Central African Republic); Men (Central African Republic)
column17: Month of April 2017, MPC forces attacked a village near Kaga-Bandoro. They killed at least one woman, her children, and a boy (coded as 4). MPC also abducted six men and one male teenager (they were all Christian and accused of being Anti-Balaka). The group were subjected to sexual violence and beaten during their captivity.
Civilians in the town of Kabo have reportedly been targeted by unidentified gunmen from Chad since MINUSCA withdrew from their area, including the killing of Peuhl herders (unknown fatalities).

4 people held hostage by the LRA, including the chief of the Mbago village, were killed in the Nzako area after they carried out some tasks for the group. The LRA fighters then set fire to Mbago village.
Residents of Obo organized a peaceful march to demand the redeployment of FACA to the area before the withdrawal of American and Ugandan forces based in the region who have been tracking the LRA.

column8: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: During a visit in Bangui, the leaders of CAR/Cameroon agreed to expand security cooperation, including the setting up of a joint border-security force to police their shared border which has been the site of consistent transnational violence.

LRA forces attacked the community of Bangassou Nzakara, CAR. The assailants spoke Acholi and Zande. They were armed with AK-type weapons. They looted food and communications equipment and abducted 6 civilians (2 women and 4 men).
At least 7 people were abducted by unidentified gunmen in Rafai. 6 of those abducted were later found dead.

column6: Military Forces of the United States (2017-)
column17: Deployment:US forces deployed to Obo to track the LRA have suspended their operations and have begun withdrawing from the area.
""The remains of an NGO aid worker were discovered in Selim. He had been abducted by gunmen with suspected associations to the LRA while travelling on a motorbike between Selim and Rafai.""

column16: RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: Residents of Kaga-Bandoro protested, built barricades and burned tires after it was announced that Rwandan/Burundian peacekeepers would be replaced by Pakistani peacekeepers which the population suspect of having sympathies with Seleka groups. At least one person was seriously injured during the protest but it was not clear how this occurred.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 27 April 2017, a clash between self-defense groups and peuls in Nguia-Bouar resulted in the killing of 6 people. The clash took place in the context of seasonal transhumance.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: LRA rebels stormed the village of Fode, pillaging houses before abducting several people and killing two.

On 4 May 2017, LRA forces attacked the community of Balifondo and clashed with local militia forces there. LRA forces killed one civilian and two others during the incident. The LRA group was reportedly comprised of men, women, and children.

column7: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)

column17: 38 FACA soldiers expressed their discontent about the their missed replacement: they built barricades blocking the main roads of the town. Deployed for 6 month in June 2016, they have not been replaced yet.

Clashes from May 6-7 in Alindao between sectarian rebel groups killed dozens of people.

column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; RCA (Central African Republic); RFI
column17: UPC and Anti-Balaka clashed in Alindao. At least 130 bodies were reportedly found by the local red cross after the clashes. The population gathered within the Catholic Church. UPC controls now the town. A truce was reached two days later.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Suspected Abs attacked a MINUSCA convoy travelling through the village of Youngofongo between Bangassou and Rafai. The attack resulted in the deaths of five peacekeepers (four Cambodians and one Moroccan) and left another ten wounded (nine Moroccans and one Cambodian). Eight ""anti-Balaka"" attackers were killed and several wounded in the crossfire, according to MINUSCA.

column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 9 May, Anti-Balaka elements attacked UPC troops in the town of Alindao. UPC repelled the attack and the Anti-Balaka subsequently withdrew along the road to Mingala. At least three people were killed and 11 injured in the incident. A reported 14,382 people sought shelter at the catholic mission. Some 329 houses in the town had been burnt down as of 18 May.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa

column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; RCA (Central African Republic)
column17: MINUSCA base was attacked by armed men associated to Anti-Balaka. MINSUCA sent helicopter and air-strikes to counter them. Civilians left the city to take shelter in church or in the countryside. 12 killed. Later on, Anti-Balaka denied their involvement in the clashes, stating that possibly foreign mercenaries have to be held responsible. In the meanwhile, the overall account of clashes grew to 32 dead and 44 wounded. On May, 18th, the Red Cross stated the dead were 115.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: UPC soldiers attacked the Kotchio village, between Tagbara and Boyo. Two civilians died, and forced population living on the route to leave their villages.

column17: 24 May. After an armed man entered the Bangassou hospital (run by MSF and the Ministry of Health) and assaulted a nurse then seized a patient and another civilian, a local defense group closed off all access to the hospital. Gunshots were heard and two female bodies were found outside of the hospital wall.

column17: MINUSCA killed a civilian who was trying to hide.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 28 May. UPC forces assaulted, gang raped, and robbed male residents of Ngbougou.
Clashes took place between rival gunmen on the Alindao-Kongbo axis. Tens of thousands of people were displaced to Alindao.
23 civilians were kidnapped by unknown gunmen. The assailants requested a ransom of 500000 XAF per head.
Clashes opposed two rival armed groups on the axis Mobaye-Kongbo.
Looting: LRA forces ambushed a cyclist and looted him of all his belongings including a mobile phone, a computer, and 25,500 CFA, near Kadjemah.
Unidentified armed groups clashed at Kpokpo on the Nzako-Bria axis. No mentioned casualty.
LRA forces attacked 4 hunters and abducted 3 near Rafai, CAR. The fourth hunter managed to escape and reported that the group of assailants was comprised men, women, and children.

column17: Bangassou Women Association marched to protest crimes against civilians.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: A woman was reportedly shot in town's market. No further info available.

LRA forces tried to attack households 13 km west of Zemio. A local defense group, referred to as anti-balaka, defended the households and clashed with the assailants. The LRA group was comprised of men, women, and children. They wore mixed clothing

Clashes opposed two unknown armed groups in Franco, North-East of Gamboula: 7 civilians dead, 5 wounded and several displaces people.
Pavica (20 km from Alindao) was attacked by armed men: 10 civilians dead and 10 wounded.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme

People discovered 5 dead bodies in the village of Dindiri, 8 km from Obo.

column6: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: MPC reportedly abducted four herders in Moyen Sido around July. As of 31 July, two had been released, while two remained detained.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: A health agent was reportedly killed in the weekend.

An LRA group attacked the community of Kotto 3, CAR. The assailants were armed with AK-47s and wore a mix of civilian and military clothing. Community members reportedly retaliated and killed an assailant. A civilian was also killed during the clash.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: ""One national staff member of an INGO was killed by fighters from the Popular Front for the Central African Renaissance which is an ex-Seleka faction. There are no other details about this incident at this time.""

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: FPRC elements reportedly kidnapped around 30 people, including two Caritas humanitarian workers and their families, after anti-Balaka kidnapped a Muslim girl in Bangassou. They were later freed through MINUSCA.
Members of an unidentified armed group buried alive two people accused of witchcraft 18kms away from Bria, Haute-Kotto.
A Muslim woman was kidnapped by presumed ABs.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: A MINUSCA patrol was attacked by ABs: they fired back killing an assailant.

Unknown gunmen assaulted two people in Lundi-Warago, Ouaka, leaving one killed and the other injured. Gunmen associated with the victims retaliated at an unclear date, leaving several killed including a village chief and two of his sons. Hundreds of people were displaced.
Clashes between unidentified armed groups in Bakofolo village, Alindao, Basse Kotto. Casulaty numbers not available at the time of reporting.

Unknown gunmen assaulted two people in Lundi-Warago, Ouaka, leaving one killed and the other injured. Gunmen associated with the victims retaliated at an unclear date, leaving several killed including a village chief and two of his sons. Hundreds of people were displaced.

An LRA group attacked camps in fields north of Bakouma. The group of assailants was comprised of men, women, and children. They reportedly abducted a number of children between the ages of 12 and 15.
Unidentified gunmen tied up and tortured a displaced person from the PK3 camp in Bria. MINUSCA intervened. He survived. On 31 July and 1 August, gunmen also abducted three IDPs from Bria's PK3 camp.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Local sources claimed Bangladeshi elements of MINUSCA killed a man and kidnapped another two whom they suspected of being self-defence elements in Bangassou. MINUSCA denied the allegations.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme; Xinhua; AP
column17: At least 30 people were killed when UPC and FPRC elements clashed in Gambo in Mbomou, including six Red Cross volunteers who had gathered to discuss the crisis in a local health centre.

An LRA group attacked Ndenguilo (Denguiro, Mbomou community). They looted sugar, cassava, rice, and other non-food items. A man who escaped reported that 32 men and children (including him) had been abducted by the assailants prior to the attack.
Clashes between armed groups at Karama village 7km of Alindao on 4 August left around ten killed and seven injured.

column16: UNOCHA; Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Clashes between unidentified rival armed groups at PK2 of Bria left one killed and one injured. Attacks on villages and tensions in and around Bria have continued to be reported following clashes between armed groups mid-June.
Unidentified gunmen killed the chief of the health centre in Pavika, 20km from Alindao on 5 August, suspecting him of supporting rival gunmen.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Former AB and Seleka combatants protested in front of FAO's office in Bangui to call for the distribution of packages promised by the organisation during a training they attended. On the same day, wood sellers in Bangui went on a 3-day strike to protest authorities' seizure of their suspected illegal items.
Clashes between Abs and ex Selekas in Bema, Mbomou. Several people believed to have been killed.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 3 trucks carrying WASH material were unloaded and the material seized by UPC elements.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: More than 200 substitute teachers protested in front of CAR's revenue authority offices in Bangui to denounce work and salary arrears.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 3 civilians were killed while looking for food by ex-seleka men.

column9: Civilians (Central African Republic); Labour Group (Central African Republic)
column17: The assassination of a trader prompted the retaliation of victim's community: 3 dead, two wounded, three houses burnt down.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: Clashes between A-B and FPRC men: trivial quarrels quickly escalated into armed fight. 10 dead (3 civilians) 7 FPRC and 10 A-B wounded over 15-16 August.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Clashes between A-B and FPRC men: trivial quarrels quickly escalated into armed fight. 10 dead (3 civilians) 7 FPRC and 10 A-B wounded over 15-16 August.

Looting: LRA forces looted the mining camp of Yangou Dacko, CAR. The assailants were part of a group comprised of men, women, and children. They wore a mix of civilian and military clothing. Some of the men were armed with AK-47s. Toll unknown.
Armed Fulani and Janjawids attacked Zemio's hospital, police station and NGOs, while self-defence elements attempted to fire back. 14 dead.

LRA forces attacked Kadjemah, CAR, looting communications equipment and medication. They also abducted 7 community members (4 males and 3 females) including a 6 year-old girl. They killed a hunter as they were leaving the community
Humanitarian personnel's house was attacked and plundered; the watchman was assaulted.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Violence reported in Boto, 8 km from Kaga-Bandoro: houses were burnt down and people are fleeing, numbers of casualties are unclear.
50 traders' hangars were burnt down by unidentified men.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: Clashes between FPRC and A-B are reported: casualties toll stretching between 2 and 20 dead. Agence France-Presse reported at least thirteen deaths relying on a medical source.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: UPC occupied Kouango.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: Clashes between FPRC and A-B are reported: casualties tool stretching between 2 and 20 dead. Agence France-Presse reported at least thirteen deaths relying on a medical source.
Two displaced people were executed by armed men.
Clashes broke out between 3R and A-B armed groups. Episodes of livestock theft triggered the clashes. 63 dead are reported (60 ""bandits"" and 3 3R men).
Clashes broke out between 3R and A-B armed groups. Episodes of livestock theft would trigger the clashes. 63 dead are reported (60 ""bandits"" and 3 3R men).
LRA kidnapped three people fleeing Nzako.
Clashes broke out between armed groups on August, 24 and 25. Several dead reported.
Clashes broke out between 3R and A-B armed groups. Episodes of livestock theft would trigger the clashes. 63 dead are reported (60 ""bandits"" and 3 3R men).
Several clashes were reported around the city of Bria. 8 dead and 29 wounded.
Clashes broke out between armed groups on August, 25 in Pavica. Several dead reported.
Clashes broke out between armed groups on August, 24 and 25. Several dead reported.
Clashes between armed groups were reported at Boungou 2 village (25 km from Bria) on the axis Bria - Ouadda. Several civilians dead.
Clashes between armed groups were reported at the Ngoungoa village (19 km from Bria) on the axis Bria - Ouadda. Several civilians dead.
RRR occupied the city after some clashes with Abs. 3 people were executed.
Clashes between armed groups close to the Catholic church refugees' site. No toll available.
Two people were killed while going to the fields.
Clashes between armed groups were reported during the 28/08 - 03/09 week. 3 people killed at the village Mbaro, axis Aigbando
Clashes between armed groups were reported during the 28/08 - 03/09 week. 7 people killed on the Bria -Ippy axis.

LRA forces abducted a man and a woman who were working in their field near Djemah, CAR. The assailants looted 2 bags of peanuts and 3 boxes of cassava. A neighbor who was also working in a field witnessed the abduction and reported it to the authorities
Clashes between armed groups were reported during the 28/08 - 03/09 week. 7 people killed in a farm south-east PK3 refugees' camp.
Sudanese mercenaries plundered the Catholic church in Zemio. Several dead reported.
RRR left the city.
LRA soldiers attacked a construction site. Several civilians dead.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: ""One INGO staff member is in critical condition after being stabbed by a person reportedly affiliated with the ex-Seleka faction, the Popular Front for the Central African Renaissance. The incident took place in front of a hospital in Bria and the motive for the attack is unknown.""

The creation of a new armed group was announced last week: Rally of the Republicans (RDR) founded by Gaetan Boade with Junior Kenguemba as spokesperson. Boade was a leader of Anti-Balakas, though allied with FPRC in Bambari and Bria. He stated that his objective is fighting mercenaries who infiltrated rebel groups (UPC and FPRC) and prevent the partition of the country.

""One INGO aid worker was killed in Bogidi when gunmen with possible associations to the ex-Seleka faction raided the organization's distribution site. The victim and two other INGO aid workers were told to follow the perpetrators to the authorities. Sometime during the transfer, they singled out the temporary worker (hired for the day) and drove away with him. He was later killed for reasons that remain unclear. The two other staff members in the car were released.""
07 September. A NGO employee was killed by an unidentified group in Batangafo.
7 Sep. 5 civilians died in violent clashes (assumed among rioters) in Batangafo after an aid worker was killed earlier in the day.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa (Amidou Faction)
column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa (Ousta Faction)

column9: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Clashes between FPRC faction. MINUSCA forces intervened to divide the two factions: 10 dead and several wounded.
3R men attacked the Vacap village (30km from Bouar): houses were burnt down. 3 civilians dead and several wounded.
Abs blocked the Bouar-Niem Yelewa axis claiming the Bangladeshi Blue Hemlets to be the cause of the region insecurity.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Abs taken as hostage the NGO Cordaid basis in Bocaranga, asking for a ransom. After a pacific negotiation, the Abs left the city.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: Abs and UPC elements clashes following the assassination of a man and the fire of the Apostolic church. Provisional toll unavailable.
11 LRA forces looted a field near Ngouyo, CAR, and abducted 6 men to porter the looted goods. They later killed 3 of the abductees after they tried to steal the LRA group's weapons and escape.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Following the attempt to arrest Anti-Balaka General Ndale, militias opened fire all over the city. One dead.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Following yesterday events, Anti-Balakas blocked a city neighbourhood.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: A Moroccan peacekeeper was wounded when a MINUSCA convoy was attacked by Abs in Gambo.

Looting: Looting: An LRA group attacked an NGO vehicle traveling from Obo to Mboki, CAR. The assailants looted the 20 victims of their belongings, including several computers. They were armed with AK-47s
3R armed men attacked the city of Bocaranga: Abs retaliated but they did not stop 3R to occupy the city. Several dead reported.
An LRA group attacked the community of Kpabou, CAR. They looted the community of food and non-food items and abducted 23 community members.
Abs entered Zemio city and clashed with Janjaweed and Fulani controlling the city since late July. Several dead are reported.
Looting: Looting: A group of suspected LRA forces comprised of men, women, and children looted a peanut field near Sam Ouandja, CAR.
16 armed men suspected to be LRA looted several households northeast of Ouanda Djalle, CAR. The assailants abducted 3 men as porters after looting peanuts, corn, cassava, and sugar.
More than 300 people went to the street protesting the lack of government engagement in the region's security.
In September/October, 4 children were kidnapped and killed by unidentified men.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
column17: Gendarmerie station in Baboua was attacked by armed men: they opened fire on the building before seizing a kalachnikof. The only policemen escaped by the window. The armed men kidnapped a women along the route in village Ndiba (km 17 Gallo route). She was freed at km 20.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013) Gendarmerie
column17: Gendarmerie station in Baboua was attacked by armed men: they opened fire on the building before seizing a kalachnikof. The only policemen escaped by the window. The armed men kidnapped a women along the route in village Ndiba (km 17 Gallo route). She was freed at km 20.
Several villages around Bangassi were attacked by armed militias. Casualties not reported

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: MINUSCA forces entered Bocaranga and expelled 3R forces: one dead and one wounded among the 3R.

About 20 Muslims have reportedly been killed in the town of Kembe, in the southeastern Central African Republic, following an attack by a self-defence group. ""The attack took place on the morning of Tuesday 10 October in this small town situated between Alindao, under the control of UPC's Ali Darass, and Bangassou, in the hands of self-defence militias since May, "" the report said, adding that the ""militiamen entered the town and launched an attack against Muslims who went to seek refuge in the mosque"".
Clashes between armed groups were reported in Kembe. Toll unavailable.
Armed men attacked Pengue village (7km from Mobaye). 2 dead.
Clashes between armed groups: 11 dead.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Clashes are reported in Zemio between Abs and Fulani militias, supported by foreign mecenaries. Provisional casualties tolls: several dead and wounded.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Former Seleka armed men reportedly killed the Kagoue 2 village chief and a youngster, as reprisal for the death of Seleka leader in Houngo, on October, 13th.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column16: UNOCHA; Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Former Seleka forces clashed with Anti-Balaka on the Batangafo-Bossangoa axis (area of Kagoue, Ouogo and Kambakota): Ouogo Seleka leader and his body-guard were killed.
A woman was assassinated by armed men. 2 other civilians were tortured in the fields by armed men.
Armed men attacked Bamatara village: 4 dead 2 wounded and 450 deplaced people.
2 people on a motorbike were killed by armed men.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Armed group attacked Alindao: MINUSCA forces answered back. 2 dead, 3 wounded.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: Clashes between Kembe and Gambo in Pombolo: 26 dead and 2 peacekeepers wounded. Updated toll: 100 dead and 50 wounded.

A day of mourning was observed in Bangui for Pombolo's dead. Several public spaces held close during the whole day. During the night, several gunshots were heard, prompting the displacement of many inhabitants.
4 civilians were accused of sorcery and tortured.
In Langandji (22 km from Mobaye, on the axis Mobaye-Kongbo), two people were killed on October 23.

column6: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On October 23, a Seleka faction assimilated to that of General Alkatim attacked the village of Saragba located about one kilometer from the city of Batangafo. Several houses were burned down and 16 people were killed by the ex-Seleka from Kaga Bandoro and Kabo. Antibalaka repelled the attack.

column9: Fulani Ethnic Group (Central African Republic); Women (Central African Republic)
column17: LRA forces attacked a Peuhl camp west of Mboki, CAR. The assailants were armed with AK-47s and wore a mix of civilian and military clothing. They abducted a woman and a girl. They also looted peanuts and bushmeat

LRA forces ambushed and temporarily abducted 5 travelers on the Mbangana-Sam Ouandja axis, CAR. They looted the victims of all their belongings. The victims were forced to porter the looted goods before being released several hours later.

On 27 October, clashes between two armed groups were reported in Ngouala village (12 km from Mobaye, on the Mobaye-Zangba axis). The interim report, provided by local sources, reports 15 deaths, houses burned down and looting of property of locals.

DETONATION: 4 people were seriously injured following the explosion of a grenade in the Fatima district in the 3rd arrondissement. As a result, some households in nearby neighborhoods have left their homes to find shelter, elsewhere until Sunday, October 29

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Two people were killed and another kidnapped by LRA elements in Pambayamba, a town 120 km from Sam-Ouandja on 28 October.

On October 28, a man was assaulted by 3 unidentified individuals in Ofa (about 7 km west of Kouango center). The circumstances of this aggression remain imprecise. The victim was admitted to the Kouango Health Center for treatment. Following this incident, members of an armed group equated with the victim's community of origin carried out reprisals in which one person was killed and four others seriously injured.

On October 28, a man was assaulted by 3 unidentified individuals in Ofa (about 7 km west of Kouango center). The circumstances of this aggression remain imprecise. The victim was admitted to the Kouango Health Center for treatment. Following this incident, members of an armed group equated with the victim's community of origin carried out reprisals in which one person was killed and four others seriously injured.

LRA forces looted the mining community of Yangou Waka, CAR. They reportedly fired their weapons upon arriving in the community and looted rice, sugar, soap, and cassava flour. They abducted 8 men and forced them to porter the looted goods.
A man was killed in Lakouanga neighbourhood by armed group's men.
A vaccination agent was kidnapped by armed men and freed on November, 7th following the MINUSCA intervention. An international organisation agent was assaulted by armed men on the same day.
Clashes between armed groups in Noufou.
Looting: LRA forces ambushed and looted 2 motorcyclists who were traveling near Pambayamba in Yalanga area of Haute Kotto.

column6: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column17: Clashes between armed groups were reported in Kabo, 60 km north of Batangafo. 21 wounded, plus several houses burned and dead bodies. The locality of Batangafo and surrounding villages have for several weeks been the scene of violent clashes between the self-defense groups and the MPC that operate in the region.
A humanitarian worker was killed in Kaga Bandoro

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: RRR men kidnapped a civilian and asked for ransom.
60 people were kidnapped between 4 and 9 November in Kembe by armed gunmen.
Reports of violence on civilians during the past weeks has led to 695 displaced persons from the Benamkor locality. Exact details not provided.
17 people were kidnapped on November 8 about 5km south of Dimbi.
Clashes between armed groups since November 9th, on the Bria Ouadda axis.
On November 11, a grenade attack was recorded during a cultural event at the 5th arrondissement town hall, killing 4 people and injuring 20. The perpetrators and their motivations remain unknown.

column9: Aid Workers (Central African Republic); UN: United Nations
column17: ""A UN agency mechanic that was traveling as part of a humanitarian convoy was physically assaulted and robbed. The convoy was on its way to Kaga Bandoro from Nana-Outta village when the attack occurred. The mechanic was later treated for his injuries at Kaga Bandoro hospital. The convoy was escorted to its destination by a patrol without further incident.""

Following a grenade attack, a series of acts of reprisals were reported to KP 5 and the surrounding neighborhoods of the 3rd district causing at least 5 deaths. Automatic gunfire was heard in the zone during the night of November 11th to 12th and in the morning of Sunday, November 12th. Fatalities split between events.

Following a grenade attack, a series of acts of reprisals were reported to KP 5 and the surrounding neighborhoods of the 3rd district causing at least 5 deaths. Automatic gunfire was heard in the zone during the night of November 11th to 12th and in the morning of Sunday, November 12th. Fatalities split between events.

""On 14 November, South Sudanese refugees attempted to loot an INGO warehouse. During food distribution, one NGO worker was assaulted by the refugees and suffered injuries that need to be treated at Obo Hospital.""

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: November. MONUSCO removed 3R forces from Bocaranga

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: November. MINUSCA deployed to Mobaye to reinforce protection hotspots
Clashes between armed groups on the Dimbi-Langandi axis. Several dead and 10 wounded.
Clashes between armed groups since November 16th, on the Bria Ippy axis.
Clashes between armed groups at the Mbopouloubou 75km from Alindao. No casualty toll available.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: The town of Dembia (Mbomou) has been attacked by UPC rebel units. ""The rebels broke into the area and killed two people, and the residents hid in the bush in fear, and the rebels took advantage of this absence to loot the houses"".

column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: Clashes between armed groups including UPC: 60 dead and several wounded, 75% of houses burned down and looted.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa (Adam Faction)

column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa (Hissene Faction)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Elements of Noureddine Adam's FPRC coalition and Ali Daras's UPC have launched an assault on several localities near Bria in the east-central region since 20 November against the Hissene's FPRC faction. Several dead and wounded and the burning of homes were recorded.

column9: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Looting: The base of the Medecins Sans Frontiere (MSF) organization in Bangassou, in the east of the country, has been looted by armed men. The NGO decided to withdraw its staff following this act.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Three Minusca vehicles were burned by a group of protesters who accused the mission's convoys of causing two accidents. Three peacekeepers injured when they intervened.

column7: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column17: The trials scheduled to be held on 23 November in Kaga-Bandoro have been prevented by members of the MPC group. This is a first hearing after the unfortunate events that have occurred in this city since 2013. According to a witness contacted by RNL, ""a few moments after the arrival of the president and prosecutor of the district court of Bandoro, Seleka elements have invaded the place to hunt everyone.

column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: Clashes between armed groups including UPC: 60 dead and several wounded, 75% of houses burned down and looted.
LRA men kidnapped some civilians for a week.
3 civilians killed by armed group as reprisal for a cattle theft.
Clashes between armed groups. No reports of agents involved.
Around 100 people have been kidnapped by armed men in the periphery of Kembe between 13 November - 4 December.

More than 2,000 people fled the town of Pende to take refuge in central Paoua because of abuses perpetrated by armed men of the RJ-Ex seleka coalition. Abuses in reprisal for the killing last week of 4 breeders by strangers not far from Paoua center.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: An Egyptian blue helmet was killed in an ambush in southern CAR. He was part of a convoy from Bangassou and was attacked by Anti-Balaka a few kilometers from Pombolo.

A large group of suspected LRA forces ambushed 5 motorcyclists near Pambayamba in Yalanga area of Haute Kotto. They held the victims captive for a few hours, looted them of all their belongings, and released them.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Violent fighting is recorded in the surrounding localities of Bria. Details of attackers not given.
22 people were kidapped in the periphery of Dimbi. They were freed by a MINUSCA patrol.

column17: Following the death of a man at the Bangui M'Poko airport, displeased youths expressed their anger at the entrance to the airport guarded by international forces. According to the deputy, the international forces fired live bullet into the crowd, causing two deaths.

column9: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa

The attack followed the liberation of several hostages held by the anti-balaka and the arrest of several of the assailants by the MINUSCA forces a few hours prior.
A national aid worker working for an Italian humanitarian organisation was killed after gunmen stormed his home overnight in Kaga-Bandoro.

The aid worker, age 35, died in the hospital. According to reports, at least 10 people have been killed during the week-long clashes between armed groups.""

Clashes between armed groups were reported in Djoubissi and Ndassima.

A group of suspected LRA forces attacked the mining town of Mbangana, CAR. They killed a man who refused to porter looted goods for them and forced another 5 to carry the goods they had looted from the community members.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Three villages near Batangafo were attacked between 31 and 1 January 2018. Humanitarian organizations registered houses burned down and deplored the lack of humanitarian assistance. Several dead.

""The armed men of RJ and the Antibalaka have been disbanded for lack of ammunition"". Many villages ""were burned and looted"" but no fighting reported at the time.

column17: In Kaga Bandoro, armed men assimilated to the elements of the FPRC, branch of the ex-Seleka, attacked the population. At least twenty deaths have been reported in the last 48 hours. This assessment follows the reprisals of ex-Seleka claiming the killing of one of them by a crowd Sunday.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: Since January 2 and according to the local MP, the ex-Seleka General Ahamat Bahar (ex-MPC, ex-FPRC, and co-founder and leader of MNLC) occupies Betoko, Bedaya, Bemal, Bebora 3 and Gadoulou. ""The armed men of RJ and the Antibalaka have been disbanded for lack of ammunition"". Many villages ""were burned and looted"" but no fighting reported at the time.

Three people were killed and two wounded in an attack by armed men at the ""Chinese"" site. In retaliation, elements of an armed group assimilated to the community of origin of the victims launched attacks against an opposing armed group located on the Bria-Yalinga axis.

The population of Mboum-Mbindoye was displaced to Ndim and Kounang following a clash between armed groups in Kowone village located 20 km from Pougol axis. Following this incident, about thirty houses were set on fire.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: In Paoua in Ouham-Pende, fighting took place between elements of ex-Seleka General Bahar and those of the Justice Revolution (RJ). More than 100 deaths reported. Fatalities split between events.

In Paoua in Ouham-Pande, fighting took place between elements of ex-Seleka General Bahar and those of the Justice Revolution (RJ). Some civilians were directly targeted by gunfire or were attacked with machetes, while others are collateral victims of the clashes. More than 100 deaths reported. Fatalities split between events.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: Four rebels of the Revolutionary Justice (RJ) armed group and two ex-Seleka rebels were killed Wednesday in a clash in the Central African city of Markounda (north-west) while six wounded cases were recorded, Xinhua told Xinhua. local source.

column6: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column17: In Paoua (Babessa) in Ouham-Pande, the security situation is still worrying after the Wednesday fighting between ex-Seleka General Bahar elements and those of the Justice Revolution (RJ). According to a provisional report provided by the local authorities, there are already more than a hundred deaths and 35,000 displaced people arrived in Paoua.

A Catholic priest was attacked with a knife Thursday night in Bangassou. Father Alain Blaise Bissialo is the chairman of the peace committee, a body of Christians and Muslims known in the area for mediating between different armed groups in recent months.

column6: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column17: In Paoua in Ouham-Pande, the security situation is still worrying after the Wednesday fighting between ex-Seleka General Bahar elements and those of the Justice Revolution (RJ). According to a provisional report provided by the local authorities, there are already more than a hundred deaths and 35,000 displaced people arrived in Paoua.
In the first week of January, 2 dead bodies were found at the Djoubissi village.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: The city of Kembe was the scene of a violent armed confrontation. The fighting, which broke out around 8 pm, lasted all night. They opposed General Ali Darassa's UPC fighters to members of the self-defense group. 15 dead and 1000 houses burnt.

Looting: 11 LRA forces ambushed 26 bicyclists and motorcyclists traveling in a convoy southwest of Sam Ouandja, CAR. They proceeded to loot the victims of all their belongings and money before letting 16 of them go and forcing the other 10 to porter the goods.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: The city of Kembe was the scene of a violent armed confrontation. A relative calm would have returned in the locality thanks, in particular, to the interventions of the MINUSCA forces coming from Pombolo (22 km of Kembe) and Dimbi (17 km in the West of Kembe).
2 cases of kidnappings were reported on the PK3 PDI site.
A person accused of witchcraft was tortured and died on the PK3 PDI site.
Looting: Traders from the Batobadja and Aobadai villages (respectively 30 and 35 km on the Bambari-Alindao axis) were victims of extortion by elements of armed groups.
3 persons were killed by armed groups.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 09 January. The MNLC abducted five people from Beboura 3, Paoua.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 09 January. MNLC members killed a civilian in Begatara.
A man was killed in Bambari.
11 January 2018. An armed man, wearing military fatigues, looted a traveler on the Obo-Mboki road. The assailant stole a hunting rifle, ammunition, and other goods from the traveler.
Looting: Regional Health Direction No. 4 was vandalized by armed men. Medical and nutritional inputs as well as office supplies were swept away by thugs.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 13 January. Clashes between MNLC and RJ on the Markounda-Kouki axis. Civilian displacement reported.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: January. MINUSCA deployed to Paoua to reinforce protection hotspots

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 15 January (on or around). The MNLC carried out reprisal attacks on civilian populations it believed supported the RJ, killing 50 civilians in the areas of Bedam, Bemal, Betoko, and Beboura (disaggregated to 13 fatalities for Bedam and Bemal, and 12 fatalities for Betoko and Beboura).

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 15 January (on or around). The MNLC carried out reprisal attacks on civilian populations it believed supported the RJ, killing 50 civilians in the areas of Bedam, Bemal, Betoko, and Beboura (disaggregated to 13 fatalities for Bedam and Bemal, and 12 fatalities for Betoko and Beboura).
