Looting: Over January-June 2018, reports of at least monthly incidents of lootings by the Siriri coalition in the Amada-Gaza, Mambere-Kadei, area.

Suspected LRA elements ambushed the village of Ngouyo, CAR while community members were in a funeral procession marking the death of a 15-year-old girl. The assailants came in firing AK-47s, killing a merchant in the crossfire, and looted many homes.
Continued fighting reported in Bria and on the peripheral axes because of ongoing tensions in the city and continued fighting on the Bria-Yalinga axis. Further details not accessible.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 15 January (on or around). The MNLC carried out reprisal attacks on civilian populations it believed supported the RJ, killing 50 civilians in the areas of Bedam, Bemal, Betoko, and Beboura (disaggregated to 13 fatalities for Bedam and Bemal, and 12 fatalities for Betoko and Beboura).
Clashes between armed groups. No further info available.
5 dead bodies were found in Kotto river.
Looting: In the space of two weeks (10-24 January 2018), four security incidents directly affected humanitarians.

PK5 was rocked by gunfire following a grenade explosion on a football field. According to information collected by RNL, one person died in the Gbaya Dombia district with. From Gbaya-Dombia neighborhood, the tension shifted to the PK5 shopping center where a shop was burned and a man died.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 20 January. Bere-Bere, a local anti-balaka militia leader who is believed to be responsible for an attack on MINUSCA in 2017, surrendered to MINUSCA and brought to Bangui
3 dead bodies were found in Nzelete, 20 km from Alindao.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: A woman living in the village of Nanzembe, escaped the popular rally organized by local youth. She is suspected of witchcraft according to a village source.

Looting: A suspected LRA group near Zemio, CAR, looted a group of women, one of whom had an infant. The assailants spoke Acholi and broken Zande and Sango, and attempted to abduct a women and her baby, but the other women convinced them not to do so

8 people were killed in community-based violence in Alindao. Originally, a supposed thief was lynched by locals. As retaliation, young people from the victim's community attacked people who were gathered around the City Hall.
3 dead bodies were found in Alindao.

A person was lynched in Paoua, northern CAR, by displaced people in a renewed tension following the arrest of 18 people by UN force, the Minusca. The lynched man was a displaced Muslim Fulani, who was in front of the base. He was lynched by the angry mob and his body was burned, according to concordant humanitarian sources in Paoua.
A refugee was killed, as suspected of being part of an armed group.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 25 January. Suspect RJ combatants ambushed a MINUSCA vehicle in Pounambo. One perpetrator was killed during the clash.
2 people were executed in Poudjo.
Looting: Several security incidents and abuses by armed groups against civilians were reported in Bria, and more particularly at the PK3 IDP site.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: A NGO vehicle was seized by armed men. The driver was kidnapped.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 28 January. Anti-Balaka forces exchanged fire with a MINUSCA patrol in Bangassou.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 28 January. RJ forces clashed with a joint MINUSCA-FACA patrol in Pounambo.
Movement of forces: Several sources reported a growing presence of LRA elements in the area of Sam Ouandja (325 km from Bria). The real intention of this group is not known.

Several security incidents and abuses by armed groups against civilians were reported on the Bria-Ippy axis. Arrests, torture and assassinations were perpetrated. One man was killed and 3 women raped.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: People demonstrated in Bangui after a police officer killed a motorcycle taxi driver who gave him a head whip. Carrying the corpse on their shoulders, the protesters went to the nearest police station to loot it. The policemen repelled the demonstrators by blank shots.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Weapons seizure: 29 January. UPC forces stopped an Ecolog International (a MINUSCA contractor) vehicle, which was being escorted by MINUSCA. Upon searching the vehicle 1,727 rounds of ammunition, as well as drugs were discovered. One of the drivers is believed to have regularly smuggled ammunition from Congo to hunters and Anti-Balaka in Bria, Bambari, and Ippy.

Movement of forces: On the week of 29 January, an incursion of elements of armed groups was reported in Tagbara (about 70 km north-east of Bambari, Bambari-Ippy axis). No information is yet available on the humanitarian implications.
Looting: armed groups were reported to have made several incursions into the Berberati-Gamboula axis, in particular in the Nassole and Ndongo villages (50 and 59 km from Berberati respectively).
Looting: armed groups were reported to have made several incursions into the Berberati-Gamboula axis, in particular in the Nassole and Ndongo villages (50 and 59 km from Berberati respectively).

column7: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 30 January. The Revolution and Justice (RJ) group under leadership of former Minister Armel Sayo handed in their arms, becoming the first armed group that voluntarily dissolves itself in CAR

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column7: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column17: ""A national staff member was kidnapped on January 29th in Ouhman Prefecture. Two INGO vehicles were reportedly intercepted by combatants from the Mouvement Patriotique pour la Centrafrique / Front Populaire pour la Renaissance de Centrafrique (MPC/FPRC). An international staff member that was traveling as part of the convoy in another vehicle was also stopped but allowed to continue. The abducted staff member was found on February 2nd in critical condition after having been tortured.""
A shooting attack was reported: one wounded, one missing.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Change to armed group: A new armed group named Noufou appeared in Nguia-Bouar (140km from Baboua). Their motivations are not yet known.
Two women were killed by unidentified armed men while collecting wood.
